reviewText:
gonna review the game after i finish it but for now here are some troubleshooting for common problems (i didn't encounter any of them)

1. Screen tearing: Force v-sync through nvidia/amd control panel
2. Audio issue: Set audio frequency to 48khz or below, 98khz will give you the problem
3. AVG issue: AVG is detecting false positive for Zestiria files, put the game folder to whitelist
4. Crash issue: switch to Windows sound Config or take off your headphones
5. No voice when character speak: turn the audio to stereo not surround and it should work.
6. Rebinding keys doesn't work: try restarting the game after rebinding.

don't rush into refunding, try those fixes for now till the devs patch the game soon.

reviewText:
You can put a cat on your head.


Edit:
Due to certain induviduals expressing their displeasure with my review, and probably many others as can be seen from one out of every 4 people finding it not helpful in any way, i have decided to expand upon this comment on the game, and give my true opinion.

This was my first tales game. I have long been a fan of RPGs, mostly in the form of final fantasies, but i have never found the oppurtunity to play from the tales series, mostly due to the lack of them on PC.

While this may be common knowledge to some, it will not be to all. To start off, i will talk about the battle system. To be honest, i found it very confusing at first. It's all real time fighting, and everything is based off of combinations of clicks and certain keyboard keys. you use your left click for basic attacks, and your right click for attacks such as special techniques or spells. later, after learning more abilites, you will be able to set certain skills to different combinations of buttons. for instance; right+mouse button = a move, left+mouse button = a different move. when you get the hang of what keys to press for what move, you will have a LOT more fun. It's simply learning the games mechanics. While this takes time, when you learn how, you will have an amazing experience exploiting weaknesses and finding cool technique combos.

Combat summary - difficult at first, but very fun when you learn how to use your techniques well. Doesn't take a lot of time, but be prepared to learn new things. 8.5/10

Now, we come to the equipment and skills it comes with. Each piece of equipment you find in either a chest or an enemy drop will have some ability on it. Examples being; +4% attack, +10% attack against this certain type of enemy, +10 hp gained when blocking, etc. While these may be useful, it does not make or break fights. The certain item you get is far more important, leaving the little perks it comes with to be fairly insignificant. You can also fuse two of the same items together, allowing the new item to be everr so slightly stronger, and with perhaps new abilites. I went through the entire game without fusing a single piece of equipment or trying to find the best setup of abilites. The ONLY time i needed to make custom gear with lots of fusing was for the most difficult, optional, and final boss. Also, it's confusing as ♥♥♥♥. Here's an example of what you can get if you spend 10 hours farming for specific equipment.


http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=586438763


Equipment/fusing summary - interesting, but too confusing to pay attention to. Can easily go through the game without having to worry about it. Unless you're a min-maxer, don't worry about fusion unless you really want to. 6/10

Finally, the story and characters. I've heard many complaints about the characters, and how it's difficult to be attached to them. I, on the other hand, absolutely love them. This may be because i have little experience in the tales games, but i found the main protagonist to be a perfect fit. Naive, courageous, a little innocent, and an incredibly strong willed induvidual. While i don't like some as much as others, there is a lot of variety among the group. you'll get a lot of good laughs with certain interactions and side conversations, while also feeling quite emotional at points. I'm keeping this vague because i would like to keep this review as spoiler free as possible. Which is why, with the story explanation, i will keep it short. I very much enjoyed the story. While the pacing seemed a little weird at times, and some things were a bit rushed, hard to follow, and sometimes never even explained, it was largely unnoticeable due to the large amount of positives you'll find throughout your journey. If you read all of the dialogue (no skipping please), you'll find the storyline very interesting with some very unique concepts.

Storyline/characters summary - against popular opinion, i found the characters to be very funny and easy to get attached to. While the story is a little rushed at times, it's overall a very cool experience. Don't skip the dialogues. 8.5/10


Would i recommend this game to a friend? Of course. Would i recommend this game to everyone who is even a little interested? Of course. As long as you're willing to put a bit of time and effort into learning the mechanics, and have previously had an RPG or JRPG that you have played and enjoyed, this is a must have.

Also, you can put a cat on your head. :3 Love the costumes. Love cats.

And you can do this
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=592402361

And this
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=592402153

THE BATTLE SYSTEM
When you encounter an enemy
column39: a wide circular area will be closed around you to form the field of battle. You can move around freely
column42: attack and defend in real time
column43: and issue generic commands to the party members you're not controlling directly (spread out

column53: each element is associated to a status ailment (e.g. Water to Poison) and a character stat (e.g. Void to Attack). Every single arte you use will have one or more elements
column54: and every arte of a given element has the potential to cause the respective element's status ailment or give you a buff to the corresponding stat when used. Enemies also have Types (e.g. Flying

column57: your SC (Spirit Chain) and your BG (Blast Gauge). BG is used for certain especially powerful artes and for a unique mechanic called Armatization. SC is what you use for actually fighting. Your maximum SC is always 100 and everything you do in battle except running and blocking costs some SC. SC recovers over time during the battle

reviewText:
Great new JRPG addition to the Steam Library and here's why:

Pros:
+ Equipment efficiency system for learning skills on your gear.
+ Cool fusion system to upgrade equipment with same name and get newer skills.
+ You don't mindlessly equip stronger equipment over your old, weaker ones due to equipment having synergistic skills that boost character stats or gives specific advantages in battle.
+ Character personalities and interactions are enjoyable.
+ Music and Sounds are fantastic to listen to- alot of wind instruments, drums, and an orchestra-esque style.
+ Scenery and environment are refreshing and nice to look at.
+ Action Battle system is fantastic (running around chaining combos and using magic).
+ Removing the TP system (MP in other JRPGs) and replacing it with a resource that all your attacks and magic use.
+ Combat is pretty fluid.
+ It feels rewarding to time attacks with allies to lock an enemy down instead of mindlessly attacking with your character alone (in higher difficulties anyway)
+ Encountering an enemy triggers a fight right there in the environment which adds great immersion to the gameplay.
+ Last but not least, the option of dual audio (Japanese/English) as well as English subtitles.

Cons:
- Because battles take place in the environment instead of a seperate battle screen, sometimes the battle camera derps and zooms in really close so its hard to see when fighting in small areas or backed against a wall.
- 30 fps locked (I personally don't find this to be an issue as the original was 30 fps and Namco Bandai has stated multiple times that they tried but the costs (gameplay performance) of upping to 60 fps outweighed the pros).
- Some graphical issues like a little screen tearing (can be fixed by tinkering with graphics card settings and V-Sync).
- Story is a little slow at the beginning.

My rating: 9/10

reviewText:
I'm updating to remind everyone that this review is just my opinion. There is no need to defend yourself against me. If you have a differing opinion on the game, I encourage you to write a review of your own. I do NOT encourage you to leave nasty comments and/or personal attacks on this review (nor does the Steam SA). You're welcome to disagree with my opinion, but please be civil and decent.
First of all a lot of the Tales combat will feel very familiar. Characters have regular attacks, special moves called Artes, and magical spells. Regular attacks and Artes can be chained together while magical spells require charge time, so the caster must be protected from enemies who want to interrupt their spells. The CC system appears to have been replaced by something called the Spirit Chain system, which looks like a mix of TP and CC. You spend SC to use Artes, and they replenish as you attack. As with CC, precisely timed side-steps, blocks or dodges can fill the SC gauge.

One of the more interesting elements of the game is Armatization, a super-powered combat mode that is similar to the Chromatus in Tales of Xillia 2. Armatization requires Sorey and one of the Seraphim (Team Members). Each of Sorey's Seraphim pals is tied to a specific element, and when Sorey uses Armatization, he fuses with them to gain access to new moves and weapons based on their element. For example, Mikelo provides a bow and magic-based arts while Edna gives giant stone fists and earth-based arts. Instead of the traditional Tales character swapping (Like in tales of Symphonia for example), there is a focus on different fusions to change Sorey's play style.

When you hit an enemy's elemental weakness or elemental resistance, the game displays a big glowing icon to notify you. This also makes me suspect that enemies can swap resistances on the fly, requiring Sorey to do the same.

The dungeon exploration in Zestiria feels very familiar. You'll probably have a good idea of what to expect if you've played recent games in the franchise. This game lacks any sort of puzzles in the dungeons, similarly to Xillia. So, for anyone hoping to a return to dungeon puzzles like Symphonia, will once again be disappointed. However, the dungeons are spacious and well suited to the game’s “Real Map Battles” system.

Tales of Zestiria doesn't look to reinvent the wheel. The core Tales combat system that people know and love is still there, and while there have been some changes to the basic design, longtime fans will still enjoy the game. There are some new features, such as the Armatization fusion mechanic and the new on-field battle camera, to keep the game feeling fresh, and the story is hella intriguing.

There are two last things to call attention  to before closing this review out. First, the cutscenes. Every scene with dialogue in Zestiria is actually more like a cutscene. Text bubbles have been removed in favor of the text showing up on the bottom of the screen like subtitles, and the entire scene has motion and acting to it. However, even with that all being the case, you can still press buttons to skip through lines quickly. It’s really implemented incredibly well!

Second, are the anime cutscenes. Ufotable handles all of the animation for the game, including the cutscenes (of which there are surprisingly many that are animated) and the opening sequence. Every single bit of animation that Ufotable handled in the game looks stunning and absolutely gorgeous.

I'd DEFINITELY recommend it if you are an Tales of fan or newcomer!, unless you find yourself allergic to the typical trappings of such games (you can see the typical zomg 30 fps outrage on the forums already). But it’s still a Tales of game… isn’t it?

reviewText:
I'm a veteran of the tales series and I'm a bit torn about Zestiria.

PROS:

-Combat is GREAT.  Might be the most satisfying combat in a tales game yet.  Every boss has a different feel and you have to constantly change up your combos, characters, and tactics to suit the enemy.  Very rarely do any two bosses feel the same.

-The gear system is non-linear.  At first I was skeptical, but this ended up being a lot of fun.  It offers tons of customizations to suit your playstyle.  I could write an entire review on how great the gear system is in Zestiria.

-The game doesn't feel 'grindy' and encounters occur instantly and in the actual environment instead of teleporting you to a seperate battle scene.

CONS:

-Story.  Tales games are known for aweome stories, memorable characters, and massive plot twists.  Zestiria's story is You are the chosen one.  Bad dude is doing bad things.  Assemble team of one-dimensional RPG stereotypes.  Go beat up bad dude to stop him from doing bad things."  I've never finished a tales game and felt so dissatisfied with the story

-Camera.  You'll get used to it quickly if you're a veteran gamer

reviewText:
THIS GAME IS SO AWESOME!

I never quite got into JRPG (because I'm no good at turn-based games) and this was also my first Tales of game, but a few hours into the game, I was most certainly sold! After watching an LP video of the game, I was intrigued by the animation and the non turn-based aspect of the game, and when a Steam friend had a pre-order copy to let go at the original price, I jumped at it.

+ Great animation, the world is just so beautiful.
+ Great soundtrack.
+ Top notch voice acting.
+ Characters are so likable and lovable. I was hoping for more back stories though.
+ Immersive plot.
+ Vast world to explore.
+ Different skills in combat for each characters.
+ I've put 68 hours into this but I still wish it was longer.

- A lot of long running between places in a vast world.
- Camera is wonky during fights.
- Repetitive lower level enemies.

Also, about the heroine in the story,  I'm glad they changed the heroine, because I really love Rose. She is just so awesome!

I'm really glad that I picked this up. Since a lot of reviewers rated the story as 'meh' while I really loved it (note: ToZ is my first Tales of game), I really look forward to Tales of Symphonia in 2016.

Meanwhile, I think I still have one side quest to finish (Katz Korner) and Alisha's DLC to complete.

My Rating: 10/10

reviewText:
Kind of a mixed-bag where your enjoyment of this will come down to how much you like the combat and the character interactions.  I found both enjoyable enough to overcome most of the game's flaws.

First off, the port is really good.  There are arbitrary resolution options, easy and well-done keybinding, instant switching of button prompts upon switching from keyboard to game controller, graphic options and I didn't suffer one crash while playing Zestiria or experience any kind of framerate issues.  The UI is solid and doesn't have any glaring issues. This is a very pleasant surprise for a Japanese series's PC debut.

Zestiria also has a lot of small touches that make it easy to play.  For example, you can save anywhere.  The game calls it a quick save, but it's a permanent save you can use anywhere and doesn't delete after loading it.  You can also line-skip dialogue and cutscenes, which is great for fast readers and for when you just want to hurry along a cutscene without just straight-skipping it.  If you die against a boss, you can just retry the fight immediately after being given a chance to rearrange your equipment/party instead of having to load a save and make a run back to the boss.  Another big thing with Zestiria is you get a bunch of dumb costume accessories that have a ton of editing possibilities and all costume changes are reflected in-game.  This is always a cool thing.  All this adds up to a hassle-free experience and I give the dev team a lot of credit for these features.

You'll spend a ton of time in combat, so let's talk about that a bit.  Zestiria decided to have battles not transition to an imaginary plane but instead take place in the current environment.  Honestly, I don't really see the advantage to this gameplay-wise, other than as a testing phase for future implementation,  It makes getting a feel for the whole battlefield practically impossible and also can cause the camera to spaz out at times.  While I didn't find the battle camera to be as problematic as most (like 90% of the time it was a non-factor), there will be times when it gets caught on a corner or you get too close to an enemy and it just starts to wig out.  Other than that, the game uses a pairing system called armatization that lets you combine characters, mainly to exploit elemental weaknesses, which are a big thing in Zestiria.  Bosses can be problematic though, as they tend to get incredibly aggressive when weakened and it's extremely likely you'll get a full-party wipe in a matter of seconds a number of times.  I liked the combat and found it mostly satisfying with the above issues plaguing it a bit.

The character interactions are one of the main draws of the series and it's really good here.  The skits and humor are mostly well-translated, particularly all the puns.  At times the translation gets a bit too meme-y♥♥♥♥♥♥encey at times but on average, it's a very good adaptation.  The biggest problem character-wise is that non-party members might as well be non-existent and don't do anything to make you care much about them.

The story is bad, and this is coming in with low expectations for it.  The first two-thirds are kind of boringly generic, but not really holding the game back or anything, then the last third of the game comes and suddenly there's a huge emphasis on the story and it's just bad and there's a lot of it.  Even things like quest design start to fall apart, like there are numerous times where the game sends you to some place, only to arrive there and then immediately be told to leave and go someone else.  The home stretch of the game also arbitrary locks some fast-traveling locations so you end up just trying to power through it to get back to killing stuff and doing sidequests.

Dungeon and music is uneven.  The parts of Zestiria that feel fully cooked, like the entire middle section of the game, have some decent design, like the shrines for example, and really cool, uninterrupted music.  Other areas, like most random ruins and transitional areas, are rather copy/paste with unmemorable tracks.  The team really dropped the ball by not having Sorey's theme be the generic overworld music because it rules and is insanely underused in the game.

The last negative is the equipment system, which is terrible unless you love micromanaging between a bunch of screens.  They tried to reinvent the wheel here and just messed up.  I won't bother to explain how poor the implementation of it is, but thankfully you can largely ignore it as long as you're playing on the higher difficulties.

All in all, if you're interested in JRPG's for the PC, this is a pretty solid choice, especially considering how slim the pickings are.  Yeah, it's about 15 hours too long and the story and equipment system are poor, but ultimately I found it a fun game to play, especially once you get your primary party, all the way through the shrine trials.  There's a lot of replayability here due to how the series handles new game+ features, as well.  So if you're looking for a combat and character-oriented JRPG, Zestiria is probably one of your best bets on PC.

reviewText: Here's my SPOILER FREE binge review.\n\nFor those unfamiliar with the series, Tales (of) games tend to be heavily story loaded throughout the entire game. The newer games easily have 5 hours of main story dialogue at a minimum, and Tales of Zestiria likely continues this tradition. They all feature some variant of the original Linear Motion Battle System (LMBS) which is where primary combat occurs on a straight line, with moves resembling a beat-em up or fighting game. Aside from an early game or two, Tales games also pioneered optional bits of dialogue called skits"

reviewText:
As I do not do numbers, nor can I compare this game to others in the franchise (having not played many of them), I will provide a list of facts (from personal experience) and then some personal opinions.

Things to Expect:
Most of this game is its battle system. Expect to fight a lot of monsters, just about all the time.
Characters constantly talk in battle. It can become more noise than wanted, but can be turned off.
Upgrading equipment can be convoluted, as it technically may not be as simple as buying new equipment in town stores.
The camera in battle can get caught in places at times that obscure your view of the battle.
There is a lot of optional treasure to be found through exploration, but none of it is crucial or immediately game-breaking.
The game's battle difficulty can be adjusted via in-game menus.
This game is very anime. By that, I mean the characters are at times very hammy or just act weird for those lacking context.
Opinions:Firstly, anything blanked out spoils the story and not the gameplay. As this is a JRPG, the story is the motivation for the gameplay. The story starts out simple and cliche, focusing on helping Angels fight off a Ever-Present-Evil and Monster Army, but it does develop into something more. However, the story tends to leave lingering sentiments that left me unfulfilled. Constant vagueness and intentional crypic nonsense from certain characters wore thin quickly, and the jokes character makes regarding such defuse anything potentially dramatic. Questions are posed, and then left either lingering or are simply taken as is despite whatever notion of doubt I felt or saw in characters.

Suffice to say, the main character resolving to save the big bad by doing what he has been doing for the whole game: hit him with a sword made of angels, left me very underwhelmed when I thought that was the heroic resolve climax. I expected something more personal, rebellious, and ridiculing of the Seraphim that have esscentially been using the main character without explaining the whole situation.

Without spoiling directly, the game's story attempts to subvert cliche by being vague (for reasons that make sense in the game) and while I could understand why they acted in such a way, it was not entertaining.

The whole reason the bid bad exsists is because of human folly, but angels allowed it to happen despite knowing it could. They demand worship to push back Evilness, but remain aloof and hidden despite the obvious mutual benefit. While the game shows how blind zealous worship can be as bad as greed/selfishness, there is a lack of passion to it and it all became muted. The angels' passive aggresive attitude toward humans, and the main character in general, had me frusterated to the point of wondering how blindingly trusting the main character is to these people. Friends that intentionally hide and with-hold information so he can learn and decide things for himself... while being the only ones to provide him the means to fight monsters and the big bad.

They let themselves be used as tools, and use the main character as a tool. I do not understand how such trust could persist in such relationships, but they all fall in line with it.

There is a distinct emotional wall between characters, and the situation this creates in this universe may be lost on people without heavy RPG context.

ConclusionI recommend this game for its combat, which is simple enough to get into and there are complexities to master. But such complexities aren't needed to complete the game. The game is made in such a way that battles can be made more difficult to satisfy needs for challenge. Equipment is not hard to gain, but does take time. You're never expected to invest more than you wish to in gaining said equipment.

The story has strong characters, though I have mixed feelings about the story. With a game like this, it comes down to personal opinion. That in itself is worth reccomending, if you are willing to think deeply about what is typically taken for granted or ignored in games regarding religion and long-lived beings like elves.

reviewText:
So here is the thing, TOZ is a great game, no really a great game, but not one without flaws, however this game is also the pin point change of the franchise to the famous open world genre, its a test for the future and my vision tells me is a nice step to it, hopefully Berseria (coming one) will have perfected everything I am going to tell.

PROS:
-Open World : this is the next step for the franchise and its a nice step they took it with Zestiria, everything looks awesome and pretty well connected, travel around it as much as you want and the battle transition is so seamless you will feel you are playing a game without loading screens.
-Combat: the addon of SC as a combat mediator is amazing, it will avoid the player to resort to hack'n'slash in the battle, thinking of timing, defense, evasion and new tactics makes the battle liver and more intense.
-Characters: the same as every Tales of game I have played, entertaining, funny, you get to form a bond with them and understand their problems and vision of the world, I actually cared for these characters a lot. The amount of skits is also nothing close to small and they are pretty interesting to see, I often resorted to just listen to them instead of playing.
-Animation: even with the casual hate for 30fps the game has a great animation you wont even think you are playing at 30fps, the technology behind the game make everything very vivid and inmmersive for an anime looking JRPG.
-Soundtrack: the music behind the game is astonishing mainly the music from certain dungeons and the song RIsing Up inspired me so much that I have them with me all the time.
-Story: the history is pretty much inspired in the good vs the bad, its nothing new in the genre however the way of telling is what is different in a world when only a few ones can see the Seraphim race, the telling of the Sheperd becomes a more related one to the tales of Don Quixote de la Mancha, where the Sheperd is fighting a giant golem and everyone sees simply a rock, funny and yet makes you think what lies beyond the common eyes.
-Tons of quests and customization: from the equipment to fashion, from simple quests to quests that can customize the very influence you have in certain areas of the map that will affect not only the enemies you fight but the rewards you will get.

CONS:
-Combat: even if the combat is going in a good direction is not one without flaws, the 3rd person camera becomes almost a 1st person one when combating in narrow spaces or when the back of the player is against a big object. Also the camera being so close to the character makes it really difficult to observe your surroundings, a fix is using the Free Run abililty however since it disabled the SC recovery its a double edge sword.
-Story: even if the telling is amazing the main bone of it is very basic compared to other Tales of games, mainly compared to the next entry in the PC realm, Symphonia, its not bad but for the first entry as an open world is lack lustered, not many inspirational moments will be found in this game.
-Skill/Fuse interface: the whole game interface is really good however the other side of the coin is when you are going to fuse an equipment it becomes a pain to distinguish how it will affect your equipment skills (which are tremendously important in the game, if you dont keep them checked you are going down), I ended up leaving the fuse window to check which skills I was going to get and back again to check which fusion will benefit me the most, a pain certainly.
-Open Empty World: even if the world is wide open and big, the empty spaces between enemies is pretty big so sometimes it feels like a very empty world, dont be discouraged by this but be prepared by it.
-Sorey is your only character outside the map. You wont change it, its a minor thing but since in the other games you could change them I feel like a backstep when I discovered this.

MIXED
-Party Setup: the party is stucked at the two humans characters meaning you wont move them from the party, the only thing you can customize is the initial seraphims that will start the battle with you, fortunately this can be changed at any point even during battle with ease. This also is influenced by the story of the game, thats why its a mixed opinion. I didnt liked it at first but seeing how the story unfolded I understood it has to be done.

DLC
*SPOILER ALERT REGARDING ALISHA*
-Alishas Story DLC: many think this was bad since Alisha should be a permanent character in the main game, but as with the mixed opinion I had with the party setup Alishas Story is also mixed, I think it Alisha should have stayed in the main game however the story unfolded so well I didnt see a problem with her separating from the main cast. This DLC made me realize it was a brave move and I support it fully.
*END OF SPOILERS*

-Costumes: all the costumes are amazing and hilarious, they are unneeded and they do not affect your gameplay but after playing for many hours you wish you could change your characters a few things here and there, costumes are for that. There are some unlockables in the game but most of them will appear as future DLC, so get your card ready ;)
-Free Skits: get this DLC its full of funny skits that will make you laugh a lot! HOWEVER! Listen to this Skits only and ONLY when you have finished both the main game and Alishas Story DLC so you wont be spoiled of some elements of the story and characters.

TIME TO FINISH IT: Straight forward 30hrs, with side quests and extra dungeons: over 65hrs
GAME RATED: 75~80/100 = GREAT
RECOMMENDED: YES!
BEST IN THE SERIES? Nope, but its the first being an open world so its understandable that the transition will take its toll somewhere.

reviewText:
For a 'Tales of' game, Bamco definitely tried pushing certain gameplay elements instead of the story/cast this time around. The story wasn't anything overly impressive, but it felt right. The cast wasn't very strong in terms of personality, most being one dimsenional, though a few stand out like Edna.  Skill system quite complicated, could be a pro or con depending if you like the needless complexity. The amount of content in the game felt shorter than older games in the series, but maybe I've missed a bunch of hidden side quests?

Pros
[+] Tales of Zestiria's combat system was quite different compared to older Tales of games like Vesperia or Symphonia, but the combat system felt fluid and fun with the extra Blasts and possible combos.
[+] Kamui/Armatization added more ways to play your party.
[+] Bamco did a splendid job with the music in this game, the music felt perfect for nearly every area/event in the game.
[+] Everything is voice acted! (at least most of what I remember).

Cons
[-] Locked party, especially due to Kamui and reasons in the story (makes me sad I can't play as four with whichever characters I want).
[-] Camera angle definitely gets horrendous shots during battle.

Bamco tried to push the skill system even further since previous Tales games ( I haven't played Xillia/2), but it got very complicated and a lot of info is hidden. With the world using seraphim and humans, the party is essentially locked due to story reasons" and limits who a player wants in his party. This is reminiscent of the Xillia series which I've only read about that had locked parties. Seamless battles were added to allow fights to occur in the exact same layout as your party is walking in on the world map. While great
date: the camera felt terrible at times where it got stuck directly behind your characters back
recommended: making it incredibly frustrating to fight.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: the game isn't anything amazing or special in my eyes
voteText: but it is fun and I recommend to 'Tales of' fans and others alike."

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria is a very good Tales game and the first on Steam. If you like Tales you will like this. If you don't like Tales you won't like this. If you are unsure I think it is worth checking out on sale.

Pros:
+ Improved combat (now takes surrounding landscape such as doorways and rocks into account)
--------> + No longer limited by TP/forced to run up and smack things as a caster to be able to cast spells
+ 2 waifus for the price of 1
+ Lots of gameplay & story for the money (compare to 8 hour 'cinematic' AAA titles that show up a few times a year)
+ Large maps with signage make you feel like an adventurer (less like Tales of Graces F, more like Ocarina of Time)
+ No Carol, no Teepo, no highpitched whining crybaby, etc; all the characters are pretty likeable

Cons:
- One of the 2 waifus leaves the party early on with practically no warning and is replaced by the 2nd waifu who uses different equipment. Do not waste time on the first waifu.
- 30FPS lock with no in-game way to change it. Not very noticeable most of the time and doesn't affect gameplay, but birds flapping their wings looks weird af because of it
- Local coop only (didn't honestly expect internet play though)

I wouldn't call this a con but if you are unfamiliar with Tales they are LOADED with cheese as far as dialogue and themes so if you can't handle saving the world through the powers of friendship you should look elsewhere.

reviewText:
There are 4 difficulties when you start the game: casual, normal, moderate and hard.
I was playing on moderate difficulty, knowing that:

What is good  Battle system is solid, rewarding for your actions in battle. Correct actions in battles result in reduced cool downs. Playing fights well earns you grade, which in turn results in rewards.
Item Customization is great, items offer abilities and can be mixed.
Items can be fused
Cinematics are awesome
ToS with preorder. :)What is not good, but not bad  Music is okay, there are some songs that are really good.
Story is okay, is predictable for the most part.
You have to constantly change party memebers, or fights will take a long time.... so if you like having a specific party always, prepare for some long fights as your attacks will not be effective. (low damage, no stuns). You have to adapt to the battle.
What is bad  Dungeons feel generic, caves look the same, forests look the same.
AI is terrible, even though you can assing specific actions to the party, on boss battles the AI will either go fight and die to a SINGLE combo of the boss, or if you assign defense they will dodge everything prefectly...and not attack at all.
They removed the overworld from other tales games, now you have to navigate thru a vast empty map.
Fights now take place where you touch the enemy, which is cool except that camera angles are HORRIBLE most of the time when in caves or dungeons.
30+ hours in the game, you still get how to play" messages..since you will most likely forget everything the game tells you.
My experience/opinion Game gets repetitive after a while

reviewText:
Haven't finish my first playthrough yet, but almost there. (on chaos mode)

I haven't played all the tales series (played the Phantasia, and the Abyss), but I have to say that Zestiria has done a good job living the series' rep.

Here's my thought.

Visual and FXThe game looks nice vitually, anime-style. Towns and Fields are interesting to explore. Dungeons are a little too plain, not in a bad way, but I feel that they can be more vivid.

Characters are good, but there is a number retextured enemies. some looks not as good as the original, but they do their jobs as variations.

GameplayThe combat is a bit unique, a result from mixture between controls and camera. It can be engaging and challenging at times.

However, the camera kills. On opened field, it works nicely. In closed area with walls, corridors, your camera can be your worst enemy, it will zoom in from the worst position possible, making you lost track of the combat field, and often KOed by it.

Battle difficulty setting changes the way you play the game.

On Normal or Hard, you won't find much trouble in progressing as long as you don't rush through it. (who rush this kind of game anyway ...)

Intense and Chaos is where the game truely shine. Artes and Skills selection will play significant part on how you perform, especially in Chaos where the game force you to use everything at your disposal. The combat becomes tactical, button mashing often gets you KOed. The needs to adapt your loadouts will put you into the grinding hell. ;D

StoryYour typical janime-style plot. I love it. There are several jaw-dropping moments, and many of smiling-with-yourself scenes (eww, creepy)

SoundEng voice is okay, but cannot compare to the original Jap voice. It has done an excellent job bringing life into characters.

For the soundtracks, it's ... where can i get the OSTs disk ? ;)

OverallIt is worth the purchase, too bad my rig can't run at a stable framerate while recording though.

If you are on the fence, and not waiting for other game atm, get it ! (it takes quite some times to finish the game, especially 100% it)

reviewText:
Bit rough around the edges but I find the game to be pretty enjoyable overall.

I'll start with what I don't like though:
- Fusion system is absolute donkey butt. It wasn't anything the Tales series needed, and back in Tales of Vesperia, it wasn't intrusive or forced on you unlike in this game. All-in-all, it's not an interesting system, and sometimes is really roundabout when you want specific skills, and fusion is NEEDED if you want to get stronger. That's just a no in my book.
- AI really needs work. Higher difficulties are fun and all, but nothing can sour you more than when the AI just refuses to guard when an enemy is telegraphing an attack, or doing an unblockable move (denoted by a !!").
- Early on a lot of the wide open spaces are pretty bland

Recommended for those who like JRPG or all RPG games."

reviewText:
If you have any questions, don't be afraid to ask me.
I shall update this review as I progress through the game.
Let me start by saying. I have been a huge fan of Tales of Series" ever since I played their more popular game titles like Tales of "Symphonia" way back on the Nintendo Gamecube with over 800 hours invested in it with god knows how many playthroughs 8-9-10? I am overjoyed to see Bandai Namco reach out to more than just consoles.

This is why I love them so much.
They still follow the old business model for video games no matter what happens.
(Trial and Error) Example: Their more recent Tales of "Xillia" I'm not going to lie was a bit of a let down BUT it was their first attempt at a more *Dark* focused storyline rather than a few elements of darkness covered up with a happy/joyful theme
date: which they quickly regained my and a lot of the fanbases support with Xillia 2 and it's dark and twisted as heck plotline
recommended:
amazing character developement and CATS! SO MANY CATS!

I have since gone back an played a majority of their first games including...
Tales of "Phantasia" (Holy f... so much fun especially for a SNES game)
Tales of "Destiny" (Fing...Passport Finding Simulator...)
Tales of "Eternia" (Those voice actors tho...)
Tales of "Destiny 2" (By far the best sequel storywise that made sense)

Besides these I have also played...

Tales of "Symphonia" over 800 hours of gameplay on record.
Tales of "Symphonia Dawn of the new world" It wasn't the best... but it was something new
Tales of "The Abyss" I absolutely hated LUKE for the majority of the game until he grew up

reviewText:
[TL;DR at the bottom]

Tales of Zestira is your typical JRPG - you've got your inconspicuous, a bit socially awkward protagonist, his childhood-friend who'd never leave his side, the nameless heroine whoiscertainlyofnoimportancewhatsoever *wink wink nudge nudge* and your set-up of We're looking for a chosen one to save us from the demons."
Now then. How does ToZ manage to elevate itself into what is at least considered a highly-above-average JRPG?
Well - aside from the mundane story

votesFunny: but to emphasize with him during the game when the albeit few
commentsCount: yet very strong choices come up.\nThis is very important for Zestiria because although the story is as straight-forward and predictable as it gets

column22: may convey gameplay-explanations such as equiment fusion or may actually give some insight in the characters themselves. Though every single Skit is absolutely cleverly written and it is what always keeps the player hooked on the story and character progression
column23:
rather than violently seperating it's Gameplay from any form of party interaction.

The gameplay is not as in-depth as you may expect. What the game does is giving you a Rock-Paper-Scissors System which is called Artes. M. Artes > Mg. Artes > S. Artes and so on. Though this Artes System comes down to basically a combo system which you are expected to keep up with by learning needlessly complex Weapon Effects and how the different combat-aspects can be combined with one another.
You now might think "What is your problem with that? Sounds to me like a very in-depth system!" - This is only half true

You have to learn the Shortcut on your Pad and press it everytime you want to move as you like.\n\nThe thing that really kills this system though is that all this is not really necessary

column28: this makes some bosses a nightmare. As the game requires you to learn patterns for bosses which may or may not result in 1-HKO's otherwise. Not being able to control the party AI properly is a big (-) in that case. Otherwise bosses tend to overscale horribly contrary to the laughable trash-mobs you encounter in any dungeon.\n\nIs the combat system inherently bad though? Not really.. but it is definitely not the optimal mix between semi-strategy and action you might hope for
column29: when thinking of buying this game. Many combat mechanics are just impractical
column30: leaving the player to just stick with their standart-combos
column31: which don't require you to learn some new shortcut
column32: to rebind your new combos to any new button and so on. This of course also means
column33:
that players who want to get the maximum out of their character can still do so. It just requires a lot of getting used to and is in many cases just a wasted effort.


TL;DR
+ Great soundtrack
+ Clever character/party interaction
+ No separation between story/character progression and gameplay
+ In-depth customization (Gameplay + Characters)
+ Rewards exploration
+ NG+

- Generic JRPG Story
- Too much Info-dumping (Tutorial Messages throughout the game)
- Camera issues (Can somewhat be fixed by unlocking your movement in combat: See the next point)
- Some basic combat mechanics have to be unlocked first (e.g. Moving freely)
- Combat needlessly complex (at least when playing on anything below Hard-difficulty) and bad control over the rest of your party

Now many of these flaws are very subjective. I found myself enjoying the story despite its flaws
column34: as Zestiria just presents itself so well - with the beatiful graphics and the outstanding soundtrack coupled with the character design of which I talked previously. The rest of the negatives are just my personal issues with the combat system which may very well not apply to you. Thus I recommend checking out a gameplay video on Youtube
column35:
before buying Zestiria.
All in all it is a very good JRPG for a reasonable price. Is it a must play? No. Certainly not. Fans of the genre will still have a wonderful time with it.

reviewText:
I've been a fan of the franchise for the last 10 or so years and I'm very pleased with this game so far.
This review is targeted towards other fans of the series, so it won't make much sense for newcomers, but feel free to read it to get another perspective.

Pros:
-The world map feels more natural than that of Xillia 1 & 2.
-If you played Vesperia you'll have no problem with the controller setup, but you can also change the key bindings, so you can play the way you want to play it.
-Even on mid range rigs this game will look awesome; I have all the settings on high without any kind of problem.
-A more lively environment; the NPC's make it seem a little bit more alive.
-The camera work improved and there aren't many awkward silences during cutscenes or conversations.
-IT DOES HAVE JIGGLY PHYSICS!!! (Edit)

Not a con but not a pro:
-There are some markers that tell you where to go, that kills a little the exploration part.
-Conversations between characters during gameplay sometimes seem like a subtle" way to tell you where to go next
date:
they don't seem "organic" or "natural"; a little bit forced.
-Not completely open world.
-Some assets were taken from Xillia 1 & 2.

Cons:
-The camera while fighting is not that comfortable.
-Despite the fact that the models look more human on their movements
recommended:
their facial expressions look odd; and during some moments you'll feel uncomfortable looking at their expressions.
-Skits aren't as common as in other games of the series.
-SO MANY TUTORIALS AND TIPS!
-IT IS NOT THAT EASY TO WATCH THE JIGGLY PHYSICS IN ACTION!!!! (Edit)

This is my experience so far; what may be an issue for me may not be for you.
Although I said many things during this review
hoursPlayed: I'm still loving the game."

reviewText:
Cheeky anime youth that don't seem to have any sort of real world responsiblilities? Check.
Dumb skits where characters talk like you and your friends did when you hung out all the time? Check.
Beating stuff up and summoning elemental ablilities like it's no big? Check again.

This is certainly a Tales game and a fine one at that so far.  I have not enjoyed a title in this series since I played Tales of The Abyss on my 3DS.  Aside from a battle system that seems to just keep growing and growing (really, at 7 hours in I am still getting tips that tell me about different mechanics you can use), this Tales picks up quick and does away with hours worth of exposition that some of the previous titles had.  Want a good JRPG where there is lots to do, and replaying it doesn't feel like a chore?  Get this, it'll make you feel like you woke up early Saturday morning, eating some sugar cereal, at the age of 15 (unless you are 15, then ignore this), with your whole life ahead of you.  It is good stuff!

reviewText:
Note: This very brief review is only about the characters (MC in particular) and how it compares to previous Tales games I've seen.

Honestly, after going through the Main Characters that I've hated in games such as Graces F, Hearts R, Xillia 1 (didn't hate Xillia 2's Main Character): Zestiria's Sorey was such a wonderful breath of fresh air.

Things this game has that none of the games mentioned above have:
>Main Character didn't make me want to choke him at any point in the game? -- Check!
>Unique dynamic brought about by the existence of Seraphim and how they interact with humans? -- Check!
>NO set Female Heroine anime archetype for our MC? -- CHECK!

I know that none of that matters for quite a lot of people, but for me that pushes this game way above any other tales games I've gone through. It's just so refreshing to have a tales game not so laden with anime tropes that I am frankly sick of at this point. I also love how straightforward the story of this game is. No world bending plot twists, just the simple story of the Shepherd Sorey's journey with his human and Seraphim friends, with little twists and turns along the way. I know this is a negative for plenty of other players, but it's another thing that I found quite refreshing. I at least enjoyed it more than the other games mentioned above.

P.S. Yes, I know Tales of Vesperia. Yes, that game is still better than this one. Yes, I'd pay top dollar for that game to come to Steam. I also still plan to play Symphonia and Abyss though.

reviewText: I love the Tales series. Every single game in the series I've been able to play has been incredibly compelling from start to finish, and really felt like more than the sum of its parts. Sadly, Zestiria is the exception to that latter part. It's every bit as compelling as most of the series, yet while every element of a Tales game is present and correct, each feels severely undercooked.\n\nThe game's characters are perhaps its strongest points, but still fails to reach the bar set by most of the previous games I've played in the series, coming out just ahead of Graces F. The best Tales game feature a protagonist who is both interesting and develops in something other than power as the plot progresses. Yuri and Luke were great examples of this archetype. Jude was not, but Milla as a joint protagonist meant it didn't matter. Sorey (this game's lead) is a bit of an Asbel (from Tales of Graces) - he's simply not interesting. He exists to be the protagonist. There is a hint of potential for Sorey: he grew up surrounded by Seraphim, human-like creatures most humans cannot see. He's never met another human, but is thrust into a great adventure. The stage is set for an nice traditional small town kid in big city" sort of arc
date: then completely ignored from about 2 horus into the game. Sorey pooters from place to place

A lot of the complexity is wasted on encounters that feel like processions anyway.\n\nThe core is split in two - the first half sees you control a single character in real time. column25: which at a basic level recharges when you're not attacking. To reduce the waiting and encourage aggressive play
column26: successful attack dodges refill SC. You can extend action chains beyond four by spending part of your Blast Gauge (BG) to do a special sort of atack
column27: itself refilled by guarding and dodging. It's a cool system that generally rewards agressive battles.\n\nThe second half is the Armatus - spending a BG to combine your controlled character with another party member. You get super powerful elemental attacks
column28: lots of health and it looks awesome. The bigger your combo when you activate it
column29: the more damage you do initially. Sadly
column30: after the combat clicks
column31: we get the procession I mentioned above: for every encounter
column32: your partner with the Seraph matching your enemy's weakness
column33: build a combo then Armatize to win. BG is so plentiful
column34: there's little reason not to Armatize to ease through fights quickly. And you'll want to
column35: because you'll be fighting a lot.\n\nPart of this constant fighting is due to the dungeon design
column36: which apparently exists in 2 types. Story dungeons are at least reasonably unique
column37: especially the elemental temples. They have a few interesting puzzles here or there
column38: and are pretty good fun to get through. However
column39: many are visually similar - there's far too many long hallways and open rooms and not a lot else outside of the elemental temples
column40: and little in the way of interesting visuals. The side dungeons are worse: cut and paste collections of corridors and open spaces that go on
column42: and on. They're dull trudges from easy fight to easy fight
column43: that get longer and longer as the game goes on.\n\nThe visual blandness in dungeons is a shame
column44: as the game can look quite pretty outside of them. The pre dungeon field areas are almost universally home to interesting layouts and fun to explore. Initially gloomy
column45: restoring blessings makes them look alive and beautiful. Pendrago's exterior is a real highlight. It makes entering the average dungeon a disappointment
column46: because it means another hour of trudging through corridors.\n\nFinally
column47: the skill system. I mentioned the barrage of tutorial popups earlier
column48: but the undisputed champion of poor explanation is the skill system. To attempt to explain it
column49: each piece of equipment will boost two stats
column50: and has four slots for skills. Each skill has an element and a group. Each element corresponds to arow on a grid
column51: and groups correspond to a column. Equipping gear fills in your skill grid with the skills on the equipment. The idea is you equip gear such that you fill in 3-in-a-row
column53: or stack multiple of the same skills. This boosts their effects
column54: and bestows powerful bonus skills - fill in the first column for a character
column55: and all stats get a 20% boost. You can fuse together items of the same type to combine their skills and improve their stats.\n\nIt's a cool idea
column56: but hamstrung because the amount of grinding it will take to deliberately make rows and columns makes it far more effective to just equip whatever gear gives the right character the right stats and treat skill matches as a happy accident. Mechanics are in place to boost drop rates and the chance of dropped gear having specific skills
column57: but it's not a fun prospect fighting the same enemies over and over hoping that the right type of gear will drop for the right character
column58: with the right skill for hours at a time
column59: knowing that you'll get stronger gear eventually anyway and have to do it all again.\n\nSo that's Tales of Zestiria. Recognisably a Tales game
column60: and there's fun to be had for JRPG fans. But aside from some cool ideas (seriously
column61: battles taking place on the overworld/dungeon itself rather than in a seperate arena is a great touch)
column62: the entire game feels sorely undercooked."

reviewText:
Overall, not a bad game if you're a Tales' fan.  I've played a few in the past, and will just say that this one kept me entertained but didn't knock my socks off.  Worth a play-through (My logged hours are up there from falling asleep while playing, which probably says something about the game). As to some of the other reviews I’m reading on here, I personally really like the equipment customization/fusion aspect of the game.  It gives some breadth and actually easily allows you to manipulate your fighting style should you get bored (not that having 6 characters to choose from doesn’t allow that).

I also didn’t really ever have trouble with the camera as a lot of people are saying.  The combat system was very refreshing, and as someone who loves grinding it didn’t feel like I had to do much, if any, for the game given how much the equipment customization affects you and the regenerating stat herb items that can be found EVERYWHERE.  However, by the end of the game I found myself just fast –traveling and using enemy-repellant holy bottles when I was running around in the fields.

As for the insane amount of goofy, irrelevant cut scenes that come along with Tales’ games, at a certain point, puns become annoying.  There are other comedic devices you can use.

Which leads me to my biggest con of the game, the story/continuity…

Coming in, I'd expected (Knowing Tales’ games) the story to be convoluted and not make sense at various points.  I was not disappointed. Of the various times I asked myself “What’s going on here?”,  I will say that by the end of the game the story as a whole seems to make sense.  It’s indulging the writers to get there that’s tough.  The game is filled with so many holes and unresolved plot events that ruin continuity I can’t begin to go into them all. But the biggest, most massive, undeniably huge one is its basic premise (semi-spoiler)…

To not overcomplicate things with specifics, there’s 3 types of characters in the game: Humans, Seraphim, and Hellions.  Essentially, the story goes that Humans (minus our protagonist Sorey and company) are unenlightened, ungrateful, hate-producing low-lifes that normally can’t see Seraphim and Hellions.  Seraphim are enlightened, elementally powered spirit beings who live amongst humans.  Hellions are evil/corrupted humans and seraphim.   To try not go into a long diatribe with specifics on just how many times the game contradicts this most fundamental law it sets up for itself (It’s literally laughable), it is single-handedly the biggest issue I have with the game as it totally screws with continuity and any sane person trying to relate to the story would think that Sorey isn’t some sort of savior, but a bat$hit crazy person that talks to ghosts.  For instance, when he is conversing with secondary characters AND having conversations within their core group, wouldn’t it seem like he is talking to the air or that there are insanely long awkward pauses while our seraphim are discussing amongst themselves?

I’ll also say that character development is pretty flat throughout the game.  Barring the major event to set up the game’s ending, nothing really happens to change any of the characters’ outlook or core values.  And even that event doesn’t change much, as it’s more of a “I know what has to be done now” moment and Sorey continues to go on as a one-dimensional, pure of heart, do-gooder.

Looking back at the game, I’m thinking that the developers probably had a lot more content to put in. There’s a solid game in there but it’s just empty compared to other Tales’ entries.

reviewText:
As a huge RPG- and JRPGfan, i give this game a very small thumbs up.

Good.
- Controls
- Graphic
- Cutscenes
- Soundtrack
- Secrets
- Crafting
- Level System

Now, here comes the sad part. I only enjoyed the first half of the game, after that the game drops the whole quality.

Good than bad.
- Story: First it's cool and you are pumped. Later you will skip most of it.
- The World: Beautiful and alive. Later everything feels unfinished or rushed.
- The Group: The Character you play have some cool moments, but later they are annoying.
- Combat: First you learn cool moves and spells, most of them are useless and you spam 1-2 combos.

Bad.
- You have to learn Worldspells to discover everything but you learn them way to late. You want to discover Dungeons but its dumb because near at the end of the game you have every spell to fully discover them.
- The game have some moments and scenes and they should be epic but even maincharacter deaths are boring.
- The whole endgame. Run to town A for a boring 5 minute scene than run to Town B and repeat.

I really, really liked this game the first ~10h, after that you only want to make it end.
My playtime is so big because on weekends i fell asleep while playing it.

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria is a game that focuses on the many hardships of life, making friends and what becomes of us when the greed, hatred, despair, jealousy and all negative emotions flood us. Its a journey to stop what is almost a Plague.
Now, that description or any description in any case won't do the story/game justice, you would need to play the game for yourself to fully experience the storyline.
The soundtrack is probably one of the biggest points of the game. Go Shiina's works are just amazing, and if you've played Tales of Legendia and loved the soundtrack there, you'll love it even more here. Why? Because they both have the same composer!
The battle system has evolved in this game too! Now instead of a separate battle arena, you will have continuous battles that take place where you encounter the enemy. With the bonus of aramantization and a rock, paper, scissors type of mechanic!

PROS:
- Soundtrack
- Amazing storyline
- Japanese Voices w/English subs
- Interesting and tactical combat system (hard~)
- Aramantization
- Beautiful Graphics
- Sense of exploration
- Many different play-styles/combos.
- Appealing characters
CONS:
- Stuttering from time to time (not too serious)
- English voice acting (better than Graces but not amazing)
- Adventure Items DLC....really Bandai???

reviewText:
So in the time of writing this review I've played about 11 hours and the game has been out for almost 3 days. Just putting this on record since I will mention some bugs that may not be here in the future.

Short Version: I quite like this game. It has some problem here and there but nothing that'll turn me off about it.

Long Version:
So 11 hours in, I guess that's a good place to be in for a first impression on a JRPG. So like many JRPGs, it's a slow burn. For a Tales game, it might be one of the slowest burns. In terms of story, it's pretty standered... in the start. That said, it does take a while before it gets intesting. Combat is pretty much the same way. With the initial skills and the enemy difficulty, combat doesn't start too interesting. A suggestion for the start, I suggest using your partner character (Mikleo) and if you're an old time Tales player, try going for the higher difficulties. Ok, with that initial start, lets get into some detail.

Graphics:
The game looks nice. From how the enviorment looks, to the character models there is a ton of appeal to the game visually. There are however some shortcomings. You will notice that the outline for the characters aren't as clean as some would like. It's not too big of an issue unless you're really looking for it though. There are also times when the characters are holding something and it looks like it kinda flouts there but I imagine that's more of an engine problem than anything. There is also one particular part in the first dungeon that doesn't look to amazing. You'll come across a certain door with a certain seal" and well it doesn't look like it fits into anything else there. Now for some bugs. There are some parts of the game where the background shutters and the character models get streched out. That said

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria is a classic JRPG. It reminds me of JRPG titles such as Dragon Quest and Final Fantasy. On top of the classic JRPG components, Tales of Zestiria added some new elements, such as narratives, customization, and a polished battle system.

Story: The story moves at a pretty nice pace and keeps you engaged. A lot of characters interaction, as well as dynamic events happening in the world around you.

Music: Beautiful BGM. The Japanese voice acting is great as well.

Art style: Great designs. A lot of details on the characters and the surrounding world.

Battle system: The battle system feels a bit awkward at first, and may take some time to get used to. Overall, the battle system keeps the battle at a fast pace with nice flashy effects.
One downside though is that the battles feel a little bit too easy; most of the battles can be won by smashing the buttons. For that reason, I really recommend setting the difficulty to high when you're comfortable.

TL:DR: Great story, music, characters, and polished battle system. However the gameplay is not very challenging. If you are a hardcore RPG fan, you may be disappointed by the easiness of the game. That being said, I still really enjoy my time playing Tales of Zestiria; and I would definitely recommend it.

A good pick-up for any JRPG fan. It is also a good entry title for people new and trying to get into JRPG. However, don't get it if you're looking for a challenging hardcore RPG experience.

reviewText:
This is my 4th Tales game. I thought Symphonia was excellent. I remember Destiny and Vesperia being pretty good. Sadly, Zestiria was a disappointment for me. I didn't start to enjoy it until about 20 hours in when I decided to change the difficulty setting, as I felt the fights were too easy. I would have quit were it not for the combat, as everything else was severely lacking. I wanted to like the game because I have faith in the Tales series, but I found myself pushing for the end just to see what would happen with the story. My feelings after completion of the game can be summed up as oh" and "that's it?"

PROS:

• Abilties that look and sound cool when executing; you feel strong in battle.
• Various difficulty settings that can be changed at any time and make defeating bosses feel sufficiently challenging.
• Good music.

CONS:

• Characters are flat and don't feel genuine. You are told insead of shown who they are.

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria (RPG)

Story 5/10
Characters 7/10
Gameplay 8/10
World 5/10
Sound 8/10
Graphics 6/10
Verdict: Good with a few flaws

TLDR: Chances are if you're a Tales fan, you'll probably enjoy this game.

The Good:
All the standard hallmarks of a Tales game are here - the combat is as robust as ever, akin to a fighting game where you chain together combos. The game has one of the better soundtracks for an RPG. The skits(short scenes with the characters interacting with each other) are fun to watch.

The Meh:
The random loot system is in-depth but feels under-utilized. Graphics are servicable but strictly average. The setting has lots of potential but in the end, it sort of  hindered how the game was played.

The Ugly:
The story is painfully average. While there's nothing wrong with a classic Good vs Evil storyline, the plot feels barebones and the characters, while well written, feels under-developed. It's just not executed very well.

Conclusion:
Tales of Zestiria brings in some fresh ideas while sticking to a classic formula. Most of them work well to bring the series to the next stage.  It'll be interesting to see how the series contine to evolve in the next game.

reviewText:
Issues with the combat camera, repetitive dungeon design and the 30fps lock will try to scare players away, but those who decide to give it a go are rewarded with amazing music, a story that will have you question and think about topics that are usually brushed aside, and characters that just grow to your heart. For everything this game lacks, it has something else to offer and will want you coming back for more.

This game is not perfect by all means, but the almost seamless immersion makes it more than
good enough for me to recommend. :)

reviewText:
So, I've been around the block with the Tales series since 1999 after playing Tales of Destiny. With the series constantly hanging around the Playstation consoles while also having some appearances on Nintendo systems and one appearance on the Xbox 360, a PC version of a Tales game was something I thought would never happen. But here I am reviewing the first Tales game to appear on Steam. If anything, the game itself, while flawed, isn't as bad as people made it out to be, particularly during the original Japanese PS3 release of it, and as a PC port, does put its best foot forward despite some issues.

The Tales series isn't really known for pushing system specs to the limit, but the visuals do have a vibrant look to them with small details of leaves blowing in the wind in the fields.

With the music of Graces & the two Xillia games, I did feel like Motoi Sakuraba was pretty much phoning it in for those installments. Zestiria was a huge improvement in the music department this time thanks to Go Shiina contributing tracks alongside Sakuraba. While I actually hold the unpopular opinion that Go Shiina's previous soundtrack contribution to the series, Tales of Legendia, isn't really all that great, his talent really shines for me this time with some great dungeon music.

The story had some controversy because of how one particular character was handled. After seeing it for myself, it was nothing to really freak out about. The story itself, for better or worse, does follow typical Tales quality (I did enjoy it though). The character are likable and engaging, though it's also on the typical Tales quality, for better or worse.

Now, for the highlight of the series, its real time battle system. It's like a simplified fighting game, moving the character, linking attacks together to combo the enemy in real time movement. This time, the battles are done on the same exploration screen. However, there's issues with the camera, specifically if the area you're in battle at happens to be a narrow corridor. The camera will be too zoomed in for you to assess the battle field until you move into a better location. There's no way to rotate the camera during the battle (the best you get would be in the menu). It's not enough to condemn the game, but it's going to be an issue at certain times. The battle system is still as fun as ever as you combo the enemies to grind for experience & money.

As far as the PC port is concern, I'll deal with the elephant in the room and say that it's a bummer that it was locked at 30 FPS but I was able to live with it. Outside of that, the port does have the graphics tweaking option that is supposed to be there, along with keyboard & mouse support to the point where you can navigate the menu using the mouse cursor.

Overall, the game was not as bad as it was made out to be. The story is pretty much not high literature and can be enjoyable alongside the characters with the typical Tales quality. The battle system still shines as bright as it ever has despite some issues. If you can handle that this PC port locked the framerate at 30, I can still give this a recommendation.

Welcome to PC gaming, Tales series.

reviewText:
It's a good game but it has it's Pros and Cons. I'm a fan of the Tales of franchise, so I was excited to play this game. After giving this game some time I've noticed lots of points to know.

As a Tales of game the story starts off rather strong and becomes rather weak around the middle to end. They take their time investing your interest into the initial main heroine just so that they could kick her out of the party and add her later on as optional DLC. You spend time getting to like her and she just leaves without question.. No one tries to stop her..

As for gameplay, the worst part is the camera angles.. The game doesn't feel as fluid as most other tales of games.. Normally the game lets me know if an enemy is able to block or tank hits or if they are vulnurable to attack, this game is kind of a coin flip. One big defect is the frequent copy paste monsters..

All in all, I'd play it, I don't know if I would recommend it to other people who havent played any of the games in the franchise though. I look forward to future tales releases though. Tales of Graces, Symphonia, Vesperia, Abyss, Xillia, etc..

reviewText:
The port is amazing. On high end rigs, and with the mod, it runs at 2160p supersampling 60fps on fairly high powered systems without a hitch. The keyboard controls are never ideal for this type of game but god damn they tried and it shows. No advanced rendering options, but Tales games are always about the art style graphically, not the BLEEDING EDGE GRAFIX!!!1one, it's mostly just LOD options.

The gameplay is pretty well put together. It's not standard Tales fare, it's a janky beast of its own. Skill won't win the day here, you'll have to overprepare due to the amount of jank and lack of polish. Armitization, dualizing with the spirit characters, eliminates all but the highest levels of difficulty, then the game throws the party systems to the wind at interspersed spots through the game taking the crap from under you.

The story, oh god the story. Don't even bother. A strong start belies a rampant case of Author Tract. Rose goes from being a mild annoyance to an actual main character. I'm not kidding. Hideo Baby, it's reported, trainwrecked his own story because he got a raging katana over Rose's voice actor, turning the once actually-well-nuanced stories of Tales games into Rose's Mary Sue Adventures featuring Sorey the ♥♥♥♥boy (Who the ♥♥♥♥ Is Alisha Edition). The localization gets amazingly bad and disjointed later on, having people sound like they're having two halves of a conversiation and hinting at things that aren't even relevant concepts.

Go Shiina and Motoi Sakuraba put their heads together for standard Tales over-orchestration for the battle themes, sounding entirely more grand than the next batch of mooks to fight. It's a welcome return to form.

If you're a Tales fan, prepare to cringe hard. If you're here for the PC port, there's a lot to love with its flaws. Tentatively recommended.

reviewText:
After I fcked myself in Chaos mode and finished it, I can finally write this review.

In short, Tales of Zestiria is a charming JRPG with an okay story, great animation, great voice acting, great soundtrack, great combat system, and great local co-op experience.

Pros :
- Story is not the best compared to the other Tales of games, but it's still good.
- TONS of FANTASTIC soundtracks.
- Beautiful world design to explore.
- Challenging, satisfying, complex combat.
- Great local co-op experience, especially if you are playing in insane-chaos difficulty.
- GREAT voice acting, both English-Japanese.
- Memorable characters.

Cons :
- Wonky camera sometimes made me really frustrated in some fights.
- 30 FPS lock, but you can use community's mod to fix this problem and get 60 FPS instead.
- You might get bored at certain points in the game, especially in the middle of the story.
- You can't swap certain characters in your party. You will always have them in every single battle. Why? It's the story's fault.

I don't regret my pre-purchase, absolutely worth it. 8.5/10.

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed this game... and I mean thoroughly, with 133 hours under my belt!

Tales of Zestiria is a fantastic achievement in the series, but like any game does have it's quirks - although they're minor inconveniences in contrast to how phenominally fun it is to play.

That said, here's my no-particular-order bulletpoint overview:

PRAISES:  Familar real-time battle system for fans of Tales of" games
date: and would be easy to learn for newcomers to the series too.\n"Battle Actions" settings let you automate some otherwise difficult-to-master moves
recommended: and can add both perks or challenges to battles.\nOpen-world is HUGE to explore and a very welcome addition. Gorgeous & immersive scenery all through the game.\nBrilliant storyline and memorable
hoursPlayed: relatable characters.\nSave points are everywhere
voteText: and fast-travel between them (once unlocked) is very helpful.\nQuick-save feature available anytime. (Except for when you're standing in a doorway
helpfulPercent: oddly enough.)\nThere are very few (if any) "limited window" objectives you can miss. I always found I was able to go back and do something / get something if needed
votesHelpful: and never had to revert to a prior save file.\nA character attribute (once unlocked) lets you speed up travel through the world & dungeons.\nWonderfully animated
votesTotal: both in the 3D scenes and drawn character cut-scenes.\nMusical score is magnificently beautiful
votesFunny: setting the audiable ambience for every single experience in utterly perfect fashion. The composer(s) should be nominated for the highest awards
commentsCount: and given expensive top-shelf cocktails upon demand. Absolutely above-par for any "Tales of" series game .... holy s**t
column16: I cannot express my eargasm pleasure enough here.\nOutstanding voice-acting
column17: and PLENTY of amusing akward moments (and some toucing ones
column18: too) between the characters. Excellent humor and comic relief at all the right times.\nEquipment & items can be traded for points toward valuable geographic region perks
column19:
rather than having to battle-grind to earn the points.
Multiple of the same piece of equipment can be "fused" multiple times to create a stronger piece of equipment.
ENORMOUS variety of equipment! Almost too much so if you don't periodically fuse equipment or clean-out your inventory.
No "carry limit" on variety of different items in your inventory. (Although you are limited to 15 of each kind of item.)
Herbs (which improve various character attributes) are located all over the world
column20: and will re-spawn in the same places after a duration of time.\nChests can re-spawn once the required "boon" (perks for geographic regions of the game) is obtained\nGetting side-quests involves simply talking to your companion: Although you sometimes must talk to NPCs to get the sidequest

No bulletin-boards or guilds to travel to.\nCurrent main objective is shown on the map screen so you don't forget what to do.\nNo rediculously-difficult storyline bosses or enemies. If you get stuck

reviewText:
Tales of Zestria jadi seri Tales pertama yang dirilis di PC dan kedua yang saya mainkan setelah Tales of the Abyss. Saya sendiri cukup menaruh ekspektasi besar pada seri ini.

Cerita (7/10)
Bercerita tentang Sorey, manusia yang dibesarkan oleh kaum seraphim. ToZ berpusat pada petualangan Sorey & para seraphim mengalahkan hellion yang disebabkan oleh malevolence dan sumber malevolence, Lord of Calamity.

Cerita ToZ sangat berpusat pada Sorey sebagai karakter utama, namun karakter Sorey sendiri terasa kurang di-explore. Hanya karakter Edna & Zaveid yang terasa begitu unik, selebihnya terlalu generic. Hubungan antar karakter pun minim konflik & emosi, pusat cerita ini hanya 1, bagaimana mengalahkan LoC.

Alur plot yang terasa datar, tidak ada yang dapat membuat kita merasa excited kecuali saat menjelang akhir cerita.

Namun di antara itu semua? Hal yang paling tidak bisa diterima sebagian besar fans adalah karakter Alisha yang begitu banyak dipromosikan lewat berbagai media, bahkan dijadikan anime, pada akhirnya akan meninggalkan party kita secara permanen di sekitar 10% awal progress cerita. Untuk apa? Cuma untuk menguatkan konsep cerita.

Satu yang menarik adalah skit dialog yang muncul di saat2 tertentu yang dapat menutup plot hole pada cerita utama. Banyak scene yang bisa di-unlock setelah mengalahkan optional boss tertentu yang mampu menjelaskan sisi lain karakter & cerita pendukung. Beberapa cukup lucu dan menghibur, mengingat cerita utama ToZ cukup 'dark'.

Grafis (6/10)
ToZ ini berasal dari port PS3 yang merupakan engine lama. Tidak ada yang luar biasa di sisi grafis.

Berita 30 fps lock cukup membuat banyak orang tidak mau menghabiskan uang untuk beli game ini, apalagi kaum yang merasa game di pc 30 fps = bad port. Untungnya tak lama kemudian muncul ToZ fix yang membuat game ini dapat berjalan smooth pada 60 fps. Saya sendiri hampir selalu memainkan ToZ pada 30 fps & merasa ini bukan masalah.

Satu2nya masalah ada pada kamera & point of view saat battle yang menyebalkan bahkan terkadang susah diatur.

Gameplay (8/10)
Banyak sekali yang bisa kita explore di sisi gameplay.
Dari segi battle, berbeda dengan seri2 sebelumnya, dengan adanya konsep manusia & seraphim, kita bisa melakukan armatize yang merupakan penggabungan (fusion) manusia & seraphim. Stat kedua karakter akan dijumlahkan (HP, BG, Atk dll). Party terdiri atas 2 manusia & 2 seraphim, namun jika Sorey sendirian, maka hanya 1 seraphim yang bisa bertarung bersamanya.

Adanya skill yang dipasangkan pada equipment (senjata, armor, aksesoris dll). Dengan menyusun skill tersebut menjadi G-Union, E-Union & Stack akan memberikan bonus skill yang dapat mengubah karakter dengan stat pas2an menjadi begitu overpowered, sehingga kita bisa menyusun strategi melawan boss tertentu dengan kombinasi skill yang tepat.
