Aiming for a no-KO for this game is something you will work hard on, especially when you are under leveled when dealing with high-tier bosses. High-tier bosses are those bosses that roam around the field with the dark smoke at the center of the enemy. Most high-tier bosses will not offer a retry but it's a gamble. However, I believe that issuing AI presets such as Prioritize Defense, Spread Out and Focus Attacks. For the Prioritize Defense, the AI tends to spam restorative and buffs all the way when they could better guard themselves from the enemy/ies's attacks as well as Spreading Out doesn't do its job either because some AIs tend to attack even though the first player ordered the AIs to Spread Out (Taken the consideration of utilizing the Strategy menu). Focusing attacks to the enemy is a lackluster for me, as it's vague whether a) the AI has to focus on the enemy attack or b) the AI has to focus on what the enemy/ies attack will come to further counter-attack the artes of the enemy/ies casted to a specific character. Don't forget the camera issues as well, it will kill your momentum in battle! Battle actions are also a plus to further customize your needs during a battle. I do recommend that you check your battle actions from time to time as you progress the game. You might discover a new battle action that will benefit you.

Quick saves. They are useful especially in emergency situations where Save Points aren't accessible. This is the feature that I am impressed as how Tales implemented it. However, the issue that I find in this game is that, when the player starts loading from the last save data, and the player started to quick save before the boss battle, it will load to the LAST SAVED DATA (where the player saves in the save point) rather than loading from the quick save. The player has to go to menu and will need to load the quick save by themselves.

Of course, some minor but commendable system that needs to be mentioned is that, the encounters are somewhat realistic, such as this one: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=650984631
But of course, Sorey didn't fall. There was just a major re-positioning of the characters and of the battlefield.

Porting issues. It's somewhat half-baked as well, but tolerable (thanks to the community fix by Kaldaien, I was able to hit 60FPS with this game but it's almost perfect for a port) because Bamco just ported the game in Playstation 3 up to Playstation 4, that can only hit up to 30 FPS. I hope that they will improve on that more in their future games.

Soundtrack. I love the soundtrack of this game. You will love it once you progress through the game.

So far, I recommend this game for those who are planning to buy Tales of Zestiria, however, it's better if it's on sale and includes discounts.

reviewText:
Here is what you need to know:

+ If you never played a Tales game before, you will still feel at home playing this one. Why? Because when you're in the world of Zestiria; the music, the landscape, and the characters remind you of the RPGs you played growing up. It has a 'classic' aura. Best way I can describe it. Now, though it has this feel - you know it's a 'new' game. Little tell-tale signs of such pop up here an there. The detail you'll see up close, the animations, voice acting, etc etc.

+ Optimization. I'll say this, I've had NO significant trouble with this game. I run it all at max and is fine. Only thing I notice now an again is slight clipping. It's rare, it effects the game not at all. So overall, I think they did a wonderful job on this port.

+ Fashion. I like the way they do the outfit system in this game. It's not TOO simple as to say, give you one slot for a head to toe outfit. You can mix things up and give yourself a unique look.

- Combat. It feels tight. Which, most Tales games do to an extent. This moreso. I wish they'd have given more options to adjust your party's AI.

- Skill tree...kinda. Seems like they could have done this easier. I still haven't really understood what it does when it does it. Not completely. I don't mind things being complex, and this certainly isn't the MOST complex system I've seen. It just feels clunky.

Main buying points to keep in mind.

Unless you plan on waiting 5ish years, this game won't drop below 19.99 IF it ever gets THAT low. If you want this game, get it now or maybe wait for a sale to when it's like 10 dollars off.
IF you like JRPGs, get it - plain an simple. You'll get excited to play it. You'll have that thing where, you can't sleep very well, because you just want to get back on an play.

Now if you like RPGs in general, get it. Same as above.

BUT, if you are the type raised on Western RPGs. You might not be as into this. You won't find this poking through political barriers, or showing breasts. You won't have movie quality graphics. This is more anime style, and like I said - a throwback to older games. Where the world's landscape seems like a more detailed world map.

If you've never played an RPG or JRPG before - this is a decent one to give a go.  I'm enjoying the hell out of it. And I haven't really enjoyed a JRPG in what feels like forever.
So, buy it and enjoy it.

reviewText: I am so glad that my friend started talking to me about this game. I had never heard of the 'Tales of' games before and was very curious about it because of how excited he was to play it. After he explained to me what the games were I figured it was worth a try... and I was not disappointed! The game has a very good story and unique, likable characters (two characteristics every RPG should have in my opinion). Also, the battle system is done very well except for the camera angles when fighting in tight spaces. I think the only thing that I wasn't particularly fond of was how the menu was layed out when trying to fuse equipment. Having to switch back and forth between the fusion menu and the skills menu could get annoying when trying to fuse multiple types of equipment for more than one character, but I think that might just be me nitpicking a little bit. Overall this was a great game and I would definitely recommend it to others who want to get into the 'Tales of' games. Now I'm off to play some of the previous games in the series...

reviewText:
*Still in early game as of time of writing*
Tales of Zestiria is thus far proving to be a really good PC JRPG. At the time of launch however it has suffered major bugs but kudos to the Steam forum admin who was taking feedback and giving progress on fixes as well as another user who provided his own fix (the individual even helped me personally which was great) but fortunately now the game is pretty stable. It does only run at 30 fps but I don't mind it and sadly it was developed with 30 in mind so increasing to 60 sounds like it wont happen.

The start of the game isn't very promising, just a warning. It starts out with the same story we have all heard before, hand-holding tutorials, and slow-narrative pacing. Give it time though; the game does improve in all those areas. Combat opens up as you get your party together (most of the games party joins in the first chapter of the game), the narrative and characters become more developed and interesting beyond their trope-like first impressions, and the combat becomes very easy to learn, difficult to master.

As of right now, my biggest complaint has to be equipment and items. They are overly complex to the point where it breaks pacing. Same name items now may have different stats, they can be fused which could make them better or worse, you have a skill sheet too thats tied to equipment that stacks in different ways with each other, etc. I find myself having to stop and take several minutes at a time trying to min-max my equipment trying to figure out what it will mean, what will work, what wont, etc. and it isn't any fun. True, previous games it was boring simple how they were mostly just flat stat upgrades but it was quick and to the point. Here, I'm several hours into the game and I'm still confused how it all works and it's throwing off the pacing where I'm trying to cure a plague from a town only to be stuck wondering why I have a locked skill on my spear because I missed that note on page 13/80 on how equipment works.

So far I would say the game is great dispite the drawbacks. The bugs are mostly squashed with fixes available, and the item system I hate can thankfully be mostly ignored (once I figured that the stats at this point weren't that big a deal it helped my enjoyment immensly) and I'm becoming more invested in the story now. Pretty solid so far, would recommend.

Also on the note of DLC, the game currently has several DLCs in the form of costumes primarily but theres a $19.99 DLC that consists of cheats essentially. Pretty lame but avoidable.

UPDATE: After playing for a while now my opinions haven't changed much but I did start to find myself get into a rhythem and I'm still have fun, so despite the faults it's pretty good overall.

reviewText:
First impression after 9 hours on day 1 (I should reconsider my life):

The port is rather good, it runs flawlessly on my 2 years old laptop on high graphics settings. There are some minor issues like the game not using the dedicated GPU by default and VSync not working unless you enable it in your graphics card's control panel, but I can imagine those being patched in the near future.

The (in-combat) gameplay is fun, somewhat intuitive and depending on the dificulty settings quite challenging (duh). There are some details that I really like, like a have-I-talked-to-you-yet?" icon above NPCs and some about which I wonder why they are even in the game (the so called Treasure Detection triggers at like 3m distance to the chest. reviewText:
This is the first official Tales series on PC, which is good to know more big JRPG names come to PC. Thank you BanCo to release Tales to PC.

Now about this game. Tales Of Zesteria. This is the pros and cons after just played for few hours.

Pros :
+ Good PC port. It support low/med PC or laptop.
It's good no lagging or crashes until now.

+ Keyboard+Mouse support.
Yes you can play with either Mouse+Keyboard or controller.

+ Japanese or English Voice
Well some people is too lazy to read subtitles, so here it is the option you can choose between japanese or english voice

+ Two Player Support
You can play single player or two players, where your friend control one of the AI party in battle.

+ Features
Many features that make this game quite unique such as hidden artes, sephard artes, equipment skill combination,   customes, and many more that I haven't unlocked yet.

+ Grinding
Monsters will respawn again if you go to the other maps. So yes you can hunt the monster as much as you want I think.

Cons :
- Can't really free run in battle unless you press the  button combined with movemont keys.
Not a big deal, but just feel quite uncomfortable. Tales of Abyss has the best movement for me coz it's quite familiar. *Edit : okay so this can be reversed after you got Free & Free battle action. So it's fix the problem. I don't know it's a feature in game lol

reviewText:
**Full Controller Optimization - Would Recommend for Tales players**

Two and a half hours in, and this plays just like every other Tales game I've adored - and then some. The music, as always, is incredible for the mood. The cel-shaded graphics add to the nice anime feel, and the cutscenes are of incredible quality. The voice acting is hit or miss thus far, but is not distracting.

Combat is as you would expect from the free-motion system, and the customization of items and purifying of malevolence will add a new depth rather than just get to new town

reviewText:
Having played two star oceans, and a little bit of tales of xilia and symphonia, I was quite excited for this game. I love the JRPG style of gameplay and finding loot, exploring, etc. It took awhile to get used to the controls on the keyboard/mouse. I had to find the right rythym to get off the specific attacks I wanted. And while the gameplay is fun to me, I find most other components of the game to be lacking. I find the story to be acceptable though some claim it is cliche and lackluster, I find it to be a different take on saving the world.

My biggest complaint, is that the main character is supposed to be BIG into dungeon diving and relics. Yet the only thing you will find in the dungeons of this game, are enemies, treasure chests, and corridors. Here is a small example of how barren the dungeons are. After playing 40 or so hours, walking into a dungeon and seeing a torch made me suspicious. I went over to the torch to see if it was something I needed to activate. If a single light source makes me think something is out of place in a dungeon, then you can imagine how barren it is. Literally rooms and corridors. Maybe a decoration bit here or there, but you will always check them because they all scream out of place. All of these dungeons are like this that ive been in except the very first.

The overworld is beautiful and the skyboxes are quite nice. Yet you will see the same enemies throughout the game just with different color schemes which is a con. So although I dont have much Tales experience to say how good this one is in comparison, for being my real first Tales game, I would say I am mostly satisfied. I just hope in the future they take the time to add more detail to their dungeons as it becomes droll very fast.

reviewText:
Thanks Bandai Namco! You put on Steam, my favorite saga!
Tales Of , with the addition of 4K, new filters and support for cards!
Please bring other titles on the tales of, on Steam platform!
Thank you again!
(Below is the Italian full review)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uXjNmeQArm8

In un mondo dilaniato dalla guerra tra due potenti nazioni rivali, assumi il ruolo del Redentore e opponiti all'oscurità per proteggere il mondo dalla malevolenza e riportare armonia tra umani e serafini.
Insieme a Lailah, la Signora del lago che protegge la lama sacra, e al fidato amico Mikleo, i protagonisti scopriranno che una potente minaccia si agita nell'ombra.


Feature:
- Affronta l'epico viaggio di Sorey in un mondo fantasy medievale reso ancora più affascinante dalle sequenze cinematografiche realizzate dal famoso studio di animazione ufotable.

- Viaggia attraverso scenari unici e immensi con l'aiuto dei serafini.

- Padroneggia un sistema di combattimento avanzato, incentrato sulle fusioni tra Sorey e serafini. Ora le scene di battaglia sono perfettamente integrate con l'esplorazione degli ambienti, senza schermate di caricamento o transizioni.

- Supporto alle carte

- Risoluzione (fino a 4k) e filtri in esclusiva PC

- Video in alta risoluzione

- Doppiaggio Inglese/Giapponese

Parere personale:
Grazie Bandai Namco! Hai messo su Steam, la mia saga preferita!
Ovvero Tales Of, con l'aggiunta del 4K, nuovi filtri e supporto alle Carte!
Per piacere portate altri titoli Tales sulla piattaforma Steam!
Vi ringrazio nuovamente!

Il gioco è semplicemente un Tales Of migliorato, sia il gameplay che risulta più veloce senza caricamenti, che tecnicamente!
Il tutto inizia con una Leggenda Narrata... che toccherà a noi viverla!
Tales Of Zestiria è il JRPG per eccezione! Si, io sono un po di parte perché amo la saga, è finalmente posso giocarla senza possedere una console Sony.
Se amate il genere JRPG o la saga, compratelo ad occhi chiusi, che a detta di Bandai Namco ne arriveranno altri!

reviewText: I've been waiting for this game even before the NA release of Xillia 2. What I can say so far is that the game is far more detailed than past Tales games and by far the most innovative entry since Xillia. It has a great setting and recurring story elements here and there that are borrowed from past tales games. The battle system on the other hand is still linear motion although a bit almost like an over the perspective is used for the camera as opposed to how usually you would be able to see all of your characters at once on screen. It'll take a few minutes or so to get used to but it progressively gets more fun. There is a bit of screen tearing which is completely noticable so if this is an issue turn on the in game v-sync and/or v-sync in your gpu control panel. One final thing which may dissapoint some is that there isn't a whole lot of grinding invloved this time around which is usually apperant in past entries although this does keep the story moving rather than slowing down and speeding up in unexpected intervals. I'm a huge tales fan and I've even sold my soul away to Bandai Namco to consistently keep me satisfied with this series so 10/10.

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria has it's fair share of problems and the game is slow to pick up the pace in the story, but is overall a good game.

While the game is visually appealing, especially for those who like anime art styles, the environments can feel bland and closed off. Especially so for the indoor dungeons. If you've played past tales games such as Tales of Symphonia, Tales of Vesperia, Tales of Xillia, and/or Tales of Graces, you'll find the game is more similar to the latter two in terms of combat and design choices.

The audio in the game is also pretty good. The English voice cast did a great job, and you might hear some familiar VAs as some of the main characters (such as Caitlin Glass [Winry Rockbell in Fullmetal Alchemist and Cammy White in Street Fighter 4 and 5] and Carrie Keranen [Satsuki Kiryuin in Kill la Kill]).

Matoi Sakuraba's soundtrack is as you'd expect for a Tales game (he composed most of the prior games in the series). Go Shiina also composed for Tales of Zestiria (he previously composed Tales of Legendia's OST), and there is a start contrast in the music. You'll know when it's a track by Shiina. And that's a very good thing in my opinion.

The battles are fun overall, though I prefer the mechanics in other games in the series more (Tales of Symphonia, Vesperia, Xillia, etc.). One thing that knocks the battle system is the camera. There's no good way to control where it is outside of sidestepping around your target. In indoor areas the camera can be a real issue as it will make contact with the wall and zoom in extremely close to the character you control.

And there are some difficulty spikes later in the game. Be prepared to grind some levels or lower the difficulty if you find yourself struggling to kill regular monsters. Learning the battle system is key in this game. You can't mash out regular attacks into an arte in this game, the properties of each skill greatly affect the flow of battle (certain types of artes will make enemies cast magic faster instead of interrupting the cast, elemental resistances heavily hinder your damage output, etc.) and avoiding as much damage as possible will help a great deal (i.e. learn to time your side steps/back steps).

The story is alright by Tales game standards, even if the pacing is not great and one section of the game makes you explore to find certain items if you haven't already (forces some side quests). However, it's nothing to really write home about when comparing it to other games in the series (which is saying something considering the series isn't known for amazing stories and writing). The characters can be likeable as well, but they each fill a stereotypical role in a very anime" fashion (innocent main character who grows into a hero
hoursPlayed: the "cold

votesHelpful: yet has a soft side" person

etc.).

The puns make up for it though. Puns are the highest form of humor and the game loves to throw out puns. The localization team did a great job on that.

The crafting/fusion system is really tedious

reviewText: One of the weaker mothership Tales of games in the series, right next to Tales of Symphonia 2. Continuing the tradition of introducing something really cool in its previous mothership title (in this case, Xillia/Xillia 2's dual raid battle system), but choosing to not take any of its successful elements and incorporate new experimental elements that is rather shakey in its introduction. It did take Graces F's/Destiny's unique style shift battle system, but severely limiting its options through poor choices, one of which was initially not displaying a numerical value of SC required to attack with a specific move while in battle. This makes judging the cost of which combos you want to pull off to a rather vague sense of estimation, though this can be helped by just keeping your SC high (admittedly not a good design choice though).\n\nThe premise so far for the initial story is interesting, but only for the first 2 hours of the game. You play as Sorey (or later Rose), the main character and the chosen Shepard who pulls out the sacred sword (AKA Excalibur) and is given the task of purifying the world of yomas and unify the human and seraphim race into cohabitation. There's a few parts of the story here and there that try to emulate a moral choice, something Xillia 2 did well, but only because it had a silent main character. Zestiria's main character has a clear personaility and when picking a choice, it didn't seem to have much impact as the character simply brushes it off with an ugly EH" kind of feeling. Gee
recommended: you're kinda hard to like. The moral choices presented are also pretty weird

reviewText:
For those knowing the series, Graces is what this title is the closest to, with a very similar fighting system, based on action points that regenerate when not attacking, and a big emphasis on dodges for those wanting to play on higher difficulties.


For those that don't know the series at all, it's a somewhat forgettable story, with most of the meat of the game being the fights.

The fights themselves pit you and your team against groups of monsters, in a closed arena.
You fight using a combination of your attacks and special moves in a real time battle.
It places quite a big emphasis on the player's skill, choosing the right target, using moves that give you an edge, defending and dodging on time to greatly reduce the damage.

I'm not the best at explaining the game, and you might want to check a few videos of the fighting system, to be sure that it's your thing.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a big fan of the Tales of... series, my excitement for this game maintained its high ranking throughout the year. Finding out it was going to be on Steam definitely interested me, and I have to say that the inclusion of more platforms proved to be a good decision.

In general, Tales of Zestiria returns to older Tales of... formulas and improves upon the newer battle systems introduced in Tales of Graces, Tales of Xillia, and Tales of Xillia 2. I would honestly say this game contains a good mix of new and old Tales of... games. Tales of Zestiria contains a much more open world than Tales of.. games of late, which was nice to see after the linear world of Graces, Xillia, and Xillia 2. I actually felt like I was exploring vast areas in Zestiria, which really added to the experience. Unfortunately, the world in Tales of Zestiria still feels smaller compared to older Tales of... games, as I don't feel as I'm venturing throughout the world, moreso venturing through a continent. However, this drawback stems from the style the developers are going for, so it's necessarily a system needed to be perfected, rather than a flaw in this particular game.

The battle system in Tales of Zestiria certainly expands on Tales of Graces rather than Tales of Xillia, as evidenced by the lack of TP or another MP-based battle system. In addition, A-Artes and B-Artes return as Martial Artes and Hidden Artes for humans, and Hidden Artes and Seraphic Artes for Seraphim. This makes the battle system seem awfully familiar to Tales of Graces, and really, it's a fun system. In addition, the game allows Seraphim and Humans to combine, creating a stronger playable entity which will completely destroy certain enemies. This game isn't easy unless you master this battle system, so the overpowered entity really assists the difficulty curve. Unfortunately, the camera definitely does not agree with many battles, and while the seamless transition from field to battle is nice, I don't believe the game was ready for that transition until the camera issue was solved.

The overall gameplay system also really expands upon itself, mainly stemming from the fusion system. The fusion system in this game, which allows one to work with different skills, really expands upon the battle system. The goal to becoming stronger in this game lies more in what skills one has, rather than how much attack or defense a certain piece of equipment holds. Until one learns this system, the game can be penalizing on harder difficulties.

There's so much more I could talk about, but really, it all comes down to personal preference. Tales of Zestiria really boils down to whether one wants to have a fun time playing an RPG with a fun action battle system, or not. While I found the story to be entertaining, I can see why many don't care for it, as it's a commonplace Tales of.. game story. However, the characters are enjoyable to watch, the story was fun to watch unfold, and the gameplay was phenomenal. I definitely recommend this game if you enjoyed any other Tales of... game, or if you enjoy real-time battle systems.

reviewText:
First of: Yes I recommend this game, but only if you're a Tales of Fan.

I'll keep it short, and warn of Spoilers my review could contain. Please beware!

Starting with the cons:
- 30 FPS, for some it is, for some it isn't a con, decide for yourself.
- Bad combat camera.
- Overall unintuitive combat and skill system.
- Some characters are just bald and unmemorable, sadly.
----SPOILER-----
- No real plot twist i came to expect from tales games? If you're just paying a little attention you'll know whats going on, no big shocker.
---- END SPOILER -----

Pros
- Tales of Game on PC, want to see more hopefully better
- Soundtrack and Cutscenes are well done.
- The memorable and likable characters make up for the opposing ones.
- Skits are good but their placement is... not so good.

All in all, even if this review seems rather negative, i REALLY enjoied the game. Of course it isn't the best Tales of Game there is, but it is solid, with a few flaws.

I also have to say I had no techincal difficulties besides sometimes a bit of screentearing.

I'll give it a solid 6.5-7/10, there are better games, but there are far more bad games!

Hope my review helped you!

reviewText:
I can recomend this game, but it does have a few issues.  Most of the other reviews explain what is great about this game very well.    So in this review I'm going to summerize the major issues.   I feel these issues hurt the game-feel and break immersion.  Hopefully this could help people determine wheather this game is still worth it to them.  My biggest gripes with this game are down to the  environments, animations, gameworld interactivity.

The environments are terribly bland in most areas.  The ground and wall textures are very low resolution most of the time apart from the stone floors of ruins, which have designs and patterns on them.  The character models look great it's just a shame the rest of the world doesn't.  The lack of any foliage and loosely scattered trees was very unexpected coming from a ps4 game.  It would have made the world feel a lot more vibrant even with some more general foliage.

The animations of monsters outside and (sometimes) inside of battle a very abrupt.  Landing a preemtive strike was nearly impossible for me the first 20 hours of the game until I got used to the jerky animations.  If your playing ToZ vanilla at 30 fps, it can be pretty hard to predict enemy movements in battle.  This is an essencial part of the gameplay mechanics since dodging and blocking at the right moment gives you huge benifits in battle.  Plus playing at 30 fps can be really diffcult since you have even less time to react to the very fast enemy attacks.

I enjoyed interacting with the various party members and listening to their mediocre (but punny dialogue).  On the other hand the gameworld itself has very few ways you can interact with it.  Most of the interactable objects throughout the world will be question marks, (???) these are 4 abilities you gain later in the game that help you progress past whatever obstacle was in your way.  Besides talking to people this is your only way to interact with the world.  This system reminds me of a metroidvania style game but very, VERY, poorly done.   Press a direction on the d-pad, and you've solved the puzzle.

Sorry for the little rant, just though it would be important for people to understand some of the issues with this game, although I would recommend it for its combat.

reviewText:
OVERALL VERDICT

despite camera bugginess and terribad ai programming, tales of zestiria is an enjoyable jrpg experience for casual players and boasts an amazing soundtrack.

PROS
skippable cutscenes

orchestrated music

zaveid's theme

atmosphere and character art design

all swords and umbrellas have their own model assets, so you can watch the cutscenes to see them all



CONS

game has a butt backwards sense of progression: never in this game did i feel like i was getting stronger, rather i felt like the enemies were getting stronger and i had to grind, get better gear, or use cheese stunlock strats to keep up with the increasingly HP spongey enemies.

story is a real hit or miss

equipment fusions and bonus skills are too grindy

some side-quests are actually required for the main quest

objective markers are missing half of the time

battle camera glitches out when battle starts near collision models (walls)

friendly ai does not block, sidestep, nor use freerun to evade

friendly ai does not sidestep to reduce casting time for spells

friendly ai often gets you killed, ie: enemy is casting a spell and the friendly ai runs in and attacks with a hidden arte

weakness and resistance system is gimmicky form of strategy"
date:
as long as you can chain together multiple hits while the enemy is in hitstun/stunlock the game will give a weakened bonus

text tutorials. ffs this doesnt help explain anything while in real time combat.

combat and ai are framerate dependent. the game breaks if you try to unlimit the fps.

FINAL THOUGHTS

if a modding community comes back to adjust some of the combat and equipment mechanics
recommended: this game's lifespan and replayability will definitely increase."

reviewText:
This is by far the best game of 2015 I have played so far. Stellar story, deep characters, and a feel that you are playing an anime all in one. The art style is quite nice in my opinion, all the while the combat is deep, and engrossing. Live action combat tied with a combo system like no other. The equipment system is also really well done. Only problem is sometimes in environments the camera can lag a little behind. Last but not least I would play this with a controller. I am using a DS4 which has a slight issue with this game. Sometimes while still connected to the program I use to use it, it will just stop working in game until I plug it in. 3rd party problem most likely the cause. (I believe that even though this is the only game I have had it happen in.)

All in all, I think this game should be a must play for anyone who enjoys RPGs.

P.S. All your Edna belongs to me!

Pros -
Characters
Story
Gameplay
Difficulty (Can go from Hello Kitty Adventure Island to Dark Souls NG+)
Soundtrack
Really I find almost no flaws maybe a few slight bugs here or there but it's far from an Electronic Artholes launch.

Cons -
Camera can sometimes get stuck in goofy positions when in corridors.

Will update upon finish but as it sits this is turning into a classic status for me much like Symphonia did.

reviewText: One of the weaker mothership Tales of games in the series, right next to Tales of Symphonia 2. Continuing the tradition of introducing something really cool in its previous mothership title (in this case, Xillia/Xillia 2's dual raid battle system), but choosing to not take any of its successful elements and incorporate new experimental elements that is rather shakey in its introduction. It did take Graces F's/Destiny's unique style shift battle system, but severely limiting its options through poor choices, one of which was initially not displaying a numerical value of SC required to attack with a specific move while in battle. This makes judging the cost of which combos you want to pull off to a rather vague sense of estimation, though this can be helped by just keeping your SC high (admittedly not a good design choice though).\n\nThe premise so far for the initial story is interesting, but only for the first 2 hours of the game. You play as Sorey (or later Rose), the main character and the chosen Shepard who pulls out the sacred sword (AKA Excalibur) and is given the task of purifying the world of yomas and unify the human and seraphim race into cohabitation. There's a few parts of the story here and there that try to emulate a moral choice, something Xillia 2 did well, but only because it had a silent main character. Zestiria's main character has a clear personaility and when picking a choice, it didn't seem to have much impact as the character simply brushes it off with an ugly EH" kind of feeling. Gee
recommended: you're kinda hard to like. The moral choices presented are also pretty weird

reviewText:
Having played most of the Tales series over the years and going as far as ordering the japanese versions overseas, I must say that Tales of Zestiria is one of my favorite installments out of the entire series.
Great character design, amazing cutscenes, beautiful environments and a fluid combat system make this a very enjoyable game to play.
The story itself is may be a bit too touchy-feely at times, but boy does it offer immersion and takes you in its grasp, refusing to let you go for hours.
The PC Port is excellent, offering many in-game options for graphical settings, so no additional launcher pops up when you launch the game. The keybinds are also pre-set very well, but can be customized to your wishes (or just use a controller if you feel like it).

This game is a straight 10/10 to me, though the story takes a while to get started.
This game will definitely impress you if you give it the chance.

reviewText:
A story about a sheep herder by the name of Sorey. A boy with deep interest in exploration... And as well as have multiple personality disorder and an addiction to hallucinogens. This is his story about how he deals with it and the only other person that supports him through his difficult times.


Jokes aside, this is a pretty solid game, but don't expect a grand story. Combat is a mash-up of Tales of Graces F and Tales of Xillia in a way. All action-based. So if you like action RPGs, this might suit you. There is a 30 FPS lock, only due to limitations because it was programmed in a way. If you don't mind the lock, it's a really good and competent port to the PC world. You know. Besides. Being tied to 30 FPS. I say this multiple times because I know there are some people who get REALLY anal about FPS locks in the 30 FPS zone.

If none of that bothers you and you want to play this game, go grab it!

The game itself is great although i am a long time tales of fan so my impression of the game might be biased.

the game has awesome additions to the already very nice battle system they have for tales. one thing that would bother most people is probably the camera during battle. their new take on open world"(ish) gives the game camera issues when fighting enemies within dungeons or narrow corridors. the exploration of dungeons can also be very boring at times but the combat keeps you playing for hours. there is a customization system with equipment that really allows the player to build their characters for unique roles and styles of play. though to get the best gear for a certain build it requires endless hours of grinding/farming.

reviewText:
Thought not perfect, Zestiria makes several steps in the right direction This review assumes you have some familiarity with the Tales of series.

I have mixed feeling about Tales of Zestiria. Did I enjoy it? I'd say yes but no Tales game has such a disparate list what it did well and what it did poorly.

CombatZestiria's combat is similar to most 3D Tales games. You move either closer to or further from your enemy as you attack them with a diverse range of attacks and spells. Like Tales of Graces, it allows for sidestepping and does away with TP. Instead, all attacks are flashy artes that deplete a stamina meter.

Combat itself is deep and thoughtful. There are several enemy archtypes and each requires a different approach. Each individual playable character controls differently and you can switch between them in combat to adapt a fighting style.

Zestiria features a pair up mechanic similar to Xillia but vastly improved. Rather than one character just following the other's lead, they act independently. Instead, they can fuse through a mechanic called Armatization. It opens a lot of interesting combat options up. Whether it be fusing to exploit a weakness, consolidate into a stronger enemy target, reviving a partner through a fusion, or splitting apart to dodge an attack, it all feels great.

Still, there are a few flaws. New attacks are unlocked and it really makes the variety feel lacking in the early game. Additionally, magic seems more overpowered than in previous iterations. Sometimes an attack will interupt magic, other times it will only speed up the cast.

Most importantly, the friendly AI is probably the worst I've seen it. Your teammates have no sense of spacing despite strategies. They rarely show an inclination to block and get themselves killed frequently. That they can fuse and cause 2 deaths for the price of one makes it all the worse. It can get incredibly frustrating to watch and I ultimately found myself setting them to not blow their combat resources and healing them frequently. It makes me think this game would be far more fun as a co-op game.

GameplayZestiria uses an open world approach that feels amazing. Traversing the world feels good and cutscenes require no transitions. Rather, the camera elegantly shifts and lets the action unfurl from where your characters stand. Entering combat similarly happens by touching an enemy and hopping back into a combat stance. It ends up feeling beautifully cohesive and is something I hope future games keep.

Characters develop in the classic RPG fashion. You gain XP/Levels through fights and equip better equipment as you go. As you level you unlock more moves, making combat more interesting and varied. The big gripe here is the skill system. It's convoluted, grindy, and not the easiest to manipulate. Each piece of equipment comes with skills attached. As you stack skills of the same name, type, or element you gain either bonus stats or a bonus skill. Manipulating these to get what you want requires grinding, use of a item fusion mechanic that doesn't seem to obviate how skills transfer, and finding one time use NPCs that can confer a specific skill on a piece of equipment. It's excessively complex and is probably the worst element of the game.

Dungeons are for the most part right angled ruins. There's occasionally a clever puzzle here and there but there's generally not much to write home about here. Gameplay wise I don't feel like they subtract much save the water dungeon. It's a dungeon built with motion detectors that warp you back to the beginning of the dungeon. The quick save mechanic reduces the pain, but it's still horrendous design.

A fast travel mechanic helps drop the trek time which is appreciated. It's occasionally unavailable, but that's always due to needing to encounter a cutscene on the way to your goal.

Sidequests are easily accessible by simply talking to your party members. You also get the flavor of the world and where other sidequests might be from banter you hear in town as you walk around.

PlotThe setting of the plot is probably one of the most novel in a Tales game. The world is comprised of ordinary humans and spirit like creatures known as seraphim that most humans are oblvious to. Sorey, the MC, is a human raised in a village of seraphim and is the rare human who can perceive seraphim. This ultimately leads to him becoming the Shepard. A figure of legend who mediates between the two races and purges the world of malevolance caused by fallen humans and seraphim alike. It's a different player perspective than any other Tales game has provided and it feels fresh.

The character unfortunately mostly underwhelm. Sorey is a competent and sometimes surprisingly mature main but there isn't much of a character arc nor is he terribly interesting. In being the Shephard, his design is that he's a near uncorruptable, pure, and just character. He has some personality which helps, but he's basically shackled from any meaningful change. Other human members are better as while similarly uncorruptable, have interesting spins on why. They're also pretty charismatic.

The seraphim party members on the other hand are all pretty bland. They all experience next to know character development so what you see is what you get. They mostly devolve into trope-like caricatures which hurts. A lot of them had setup or back story to be genuinely interesting but ultimately none of it was capitalized on.

The story itself is about average. It does a good job of taking you through a variety of locales and rationalizes near everything that happens with the plot extremely well. It also presents a lot of epic scenarios that were a joy to play. Still, due to the lack of development in the characters there's no real feeling of gravity for the player behind the events.

Again, it's a competent but not great story. I didn't feel it hurt the game but I also don't think it added much.

SoundThe sound direction for this game is outstanding and easily the best in the entire Tales of series. It's strong praise but it's deserving. The orchestration is beautiful and small decisions like not switching to a different combat theme in dungeons goes a long, long way. Several of the dungeons were legitimately more enjoyable due to atmosphere and tension and music underscores them with.

The fire dungeon's energetic theme meshes with the lava filled environment. The water dungoen's piano heavy orchestra fits with the more intellectually based challenge posed in the plot to Sorey. The final dungeon theme leaves the area dripping with a sense of ominous tension.

Conclusion
Zestiria isn't perfect. It has a lot of flaws and some of them are major. The skill system feels bad, friendly AI performs poorly, and plot isn't the best offering of the series. Still for all those things it does so very much right. The open world is beautiful and cohesive. The combat is one of the most varied and legitimately fun entries in recent memory. Not to mention, the soundtrack is the best of the series hands down.

For all the things I disliked, I loved the things it did well enough to brush those issues aside. It honestly gives me a lot of hope for the future of the franchise. If you enjoy the Tales series or are just itching for a JRPG, it's worth playing.

reviewText:
PROS:

1. No angsty teenage drama. Yes, the story is not particulary captivating but at least it gives you an adult vibe. There are no characters whose only role is to repeat last said words with a puzzled look on their faces when everything is decided by others. Nothing is done blindly because someone said to do it, everything is evaluated and actions taken with consequences in mind.

2. Battle system might seem overcomplicated, especially in the beginning but later you start to appreciate its flexibility. A lot of different monsters require different tactics so there is a necessity to adapt. There is also an easy mode if you only want the story.

3. All girls are best girls.


CONS:

1. Graphics are bad, like very bad. The game looks worse than FF XII, yes, twelve. Giant bland levels which you have to travel across over and over.

2. Speaking of traveling. The game forces upon you an insane amount of backtracking. I lost count how many times I visited more populated central regions. It's common to travel for 15 minutes to see 30 seconds cutscene and then go back the same way. It wouldn't be so bad if the game looked decent but... see 1.

3. Overlocalization and mistranslation. A lot of lines are mistranslated for no apparent reason. The message is delivered but overlocalized. Just a couple of lines from memory: two guards say to each other: Let's go drink" - "Ah
date: with pleasure" but it's translated as "Let's go drink" - "Anything to get off this armor". Why? No reason at all. Lailah often compassionly repeats the protagonist name but it always translated differently
hoursPlayed: don't you" etc. The game is full of humour but it's not delivered due to horrible translation job. Puns fall flat because lines make no sense or just simply not funny. Also it's the game in medieval settings
voteText:
why put so many modern idioms? It breaks the immersion.


Overall I give it 6/10. After all I've said I still like the game

reviewText:
It's a damn good JRPG. The second best after Trails in the Sky if u ask me so far on steam.

Pros:

- best combat system in a tales of game
- it has one of the best soundtracks in a JRPG ever (check out Rising Up on Youtube, it's even a battle theme)
- it's not as linear as most JRPGs
- it offers huge customization to suit unique playstyles via item abilities
- grinding is no a must, skill and understanding of the combat system matters

Cons:
- sometimes the camera angle prevents you from seeing whats going on in a fight, but this happens very rarely and was no problem at all
- generic story

Storywise Abyss, Vesperia, Symphonia and Phantasia were better, but the battle system and the soundtrack compensate  for that easily.

reviewText: For fans of the Tales of Series, I have to leave this footnote to begin with. Zestiria plays dramatically different than what you are use to. Although the changes at face value don't seem that different, it certainly will be a culture shock to say the least. I enjoyed Zestiria all the way through, it was well written and a welcome return to the series. If I could point out one flaw I would say that it feels like it's lacking something. Compared to the previous Tales of Titles there is quite a bit less game to play. The major cities are smaller, some minor characters had more buildup than party members, and some party members disappear due to plot reasons and never reappear again. Previous Tales of Titles have done the disappearing party member sure, but they always returned in time for the end of the plot. Unfortunately Zestiria doesn't do this, and at least to me, it kinda feels like I was cheated just a bit. Now don't get me wrong, Zestiria is a fantastic game, I enjoyed every moment of it. However it falls flat when compared to its predecessors. I’m glad to see the Tales of Series get a reboot, and I'm excited to see more. But we should demand more. Buy this game, play it and enjoy. But make sure you remind the Development team what you want. Remind them of the standard they have set in the past, so with the money they get from Zestiria, they can get this reboot back to the quality it should be.

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria is an enjoyable Action JRPG with a few issues...
+ Gameplay is fun for the most part
+ Graphics are fairly good
+ Soundtrack is great, as usual for a Tales game
+ Character interaction is often humorous
+ The English Dub is good
+ Plenty of Content (Took about 40 hours to beat the game and I skipped many side missions)
o The story is hit and miss, not bad but not that good either
- The camera in combat can be absolutely awful sometimes
- A good number of dungeons are dull and boring to go through

Overall, I think this game is worth 50 bucks despite its flaws. Hope to see more Tales games on PC.

reviewText:
I've been playing Tales of Zestiria a lot lately (I just got done with all the elemental trials and am doing a lot of side or extra quest before continuing with the main story). So far the game is really good. The music is really good, I've found some tracks I like a lot. But...I can't say this is my favorite Tales Of game, and from what I know, I don't think it will become it either. The battle system isn't as good as Hearts R or Graces F (Those are my two favorites of the series. Still really want to play Vesperia but haven't had the chance) and I'm not a fan of the human/seraphim difference.....but the biggest problem lies in how Alisha leaves the party (And early on to boot). This leaves the game giving you only 2 humans. That's not even enough to switch to someone else. Not to mention I don't really like Rose much.

The story is great but the gameplay seems kind of bland compared to others Tales games. In others, you must switch party members and do without people for a while....here....well you don't really have that except for the crucible locations. Also, for some reason, I just don't feel a desire to try playing the other characters in this game. Xillia 2 had Gaia that was fun to play as, and Xillia 1 and 2 both had Elise which could be fun if you get good at toggling Teepo. (I had an interest in Muzet but forgot why. I think it was a good balance and good aero combat character). Hearts R and Graces F both had a bunch of fun characters. But Zestiria, they don't really work so different from each other (At least as far as I know).

Hopefully the next 2 Tales Of games in development will turn out better. Please don't make this mistake again. I'm ok with a party member leaving, but give us enough different people to replace them with. Two humans just doesn't cut it.  Still a great game but there are better Tales Of games out there for people getting into the series.

*Edit*
I have now beat the game.  I'd say it's the best game for 2015.  But still not as good as Graces F or Hearts R but still great.  Now I'm trying to find things to do post game outside of the DLC (I do have it though).

reviewText:
I can recomend this game, but it does have a few issues.  Most of the other reviews explain what is great about this game very well.    So in this review I'm going to summerize the major issues.   I feel these issues hurt the game-feel and break immersion.  Hopefully this could help people determine wheather this game is still worth it to them.  My biggest gripes with this game are down to the  environments, animations, gameworld interactivity.

The environments are terribly bland in most areas.  The ground and wall textures are very low resolution most of the time apart from the stone floors of ruins, which have designs and patterns on them.  The character models look great it's just a shame the rest of the world doesn't.  The lack of any foliage and loosely scattered trees was very unexpected coming from a ps4 game.  It would have made the world feel a lot more vibrant even with some more general foliage.

The animations of monsters outside and (sometimes) inside of battle a very abrupt.  Landing a preemtive strike was nearly impossible for me the first 20 hours of the game until I got used to the jerky animations.  If your playing ToZ vanilla at 30 fps, it can be pretty hard to predict enemy movements in battle.  This is an essencial part of the gameplay mechanics since dodging and blocking at the right moment gives you huge benifits in battle.  Plus playing at 30 fps can be really diffcult since you have even less time to react to the very fast enemy attacks.

I enjoyed interacting with the various party members and listening to their mediocre (but punny dialogue).  On the other hand the gameworld itself has very few ways you can interact with it.  Most of the interactable objects throughout the world will be question marks, (???) these are 4 abilities you gain later in the game that help you progress past whatever obstacle was in your way.  Besides talking to people this is your only way to interact with the world.  This system reminds me of a metroidvania style game but very, VERY, poorly done.   Press a direction on the d-pad, and you've solved the puzzle.

Sorry for the little rant, just though it would be important for people to understand some of the issues with this game, although I would recommend it for its combat.

reviewText:
Having played most of the Tales series over the years and going as far as ordering the japanese versions overseas, I must say that Tales of Zestiria is one of my favorite installments out of the entire series.
Great character design, amazing cutscenes, beautiful environments and a fluid combat system make this a very enjoyable game to play.
The story itself is may be a bit too touchy-feely at times, but boy does it offer immersion and takes you in its grasp, refusing to let you go for hours.
The PC Port is excellent, offering many in-game options for graphical settings, so no additional launcher pops up when you launch the game. The keybinds are also pre-set very well, but can be customized to your wishes (or just use a controller if you feel like it).

This game is a straight 10/10 to me, though the story takes a while to get started.
This game will definitely impress you if you give it the chance.

reviewText: You know I'm a hardcore tales of series fan and when I first set my eyes on Zestiria I thought the combat and camera angles were a bit wonky and the protagnist was a bit of a lame basket case. When I wasn't playing second player off of my friend's ps4 and played single player on PC I quickly realized this game is much better solo as it realies on the armatization and seraphim for the majority of the games combat and that the main character Sorey ultimately becomes more likable after the first anime cutscene. I can think back to my favorite tales of game in the series; Symphonia and the main character Lloyd Irving. Now Lloyd wasn't the brightest guy and hell he couldn't even make a sandwhich, but what he lacked in sharp smarts he made up with his undying morally strong ideals. He believed in a world in which everyone could live happy and that no one was born for the sole purpose of dying. I have to say a little bit of Lloyd I can see in Sorey even if he isn't my favorite character in the game (Edna). So the point is if you like RPGs and you never played or know of the tales of series, definately give this one a try.

reviewText:
This game may not ever be in running for best RPG of the decade, but it's fun! I enjoyed it a lot! The plot is (kind of) standard RPG fare but (like a lot of Tales of games) its characters are basically what keep you playing. It's what kept me playing at least! The battle system is like a lot of Tales games - it can be really repetitive and you could button mash half the time and still do okay... but you know, it's addicting in its own way if you're into grinding and all that.

The only con I'd have for this game is the AI - it's super terrible. It's made even worse by the fact that you're rewarded Grade based on how you did in a fight and... you (or your Ai-controlled buddies) getting KO'd takes a good chunk out of that Grade.

Oh and OST is great....

reviewText:
OVERALL VERDICT

despite camera bugginess and terribad ai programming, tales of zestiria is an enjoyable jrpg experience for casual players and boasts an amazing soundtrack.

PROS
skippable cutscenes

orchestrated music

zaveid's theme

atmosphere and character art design

all swords and umbrellas have their own model assets, so you can watch the cutscenes to see them all



CONS

game has a butt backwards sense of progression: never in this game did i feel like i was getting stronger, rather i felt like the enemies were getting stronger and i had to grind, get better gear, or use cheese stunlock strats to keep up with the increasingly HP spongey enemies.

story is a real hit or miss

equipment fusions and bonus skills are too grindy

some side-quests are actually required for the main quest

objective markers are missing half of the time

battle camera glitches out when battle starts near collision models (walls)

friendly ai does not block, sidestep, nor use freerun to evade

friendly ai does not sidestep to reduce casting time for spells

friendly ai often gets you killed, ie: enemy is casting a spell and the friendly ai runs in and attacks with a hidden arte

weakness and resistance system is gimmicky form of strategy"
date:
as long as you can chain together multiple hits while the enemy is in hitstun/stunlock the game will give a weakened bonus

text tutorials. ffs this doesnt help explain anything while in real time combat.

combat and ai are framerate dependent. the game breaks if you try to unlimit the fps.

FINAL THOUGHTS

if a modding community comes back to adjust some of the combat and equipment mechanics
recommended: this game's lifespan and replayability will definitely increase."

reviewText:
I dug my way into ruins that had been undisturbed for centuries and found a chest that contained a slice of cake that I promptly ate.   10/10

This game suffers from a few design issues. Much of this game consists of overly large areas with high ceilings, but said spaces feel empty when there's little but one or two enemies to occupy them. The cities look all too uniform, with no real distinguishing features to set them apart from one another, and this only gets worse inside building-dungeons, where the color schemes of the walls/floors/ceilings are so similar that you feel like falling asleep just looking at them.

The game is locked at 30FPS, and this doesn't have much effect on the game. However, there are times when it's quite noticable, like in the animations of distant enemies, as well as a close up few enemies with particularly fast animations (bats for instance). Minor graphical glitches are evident, but not more than you'd expect from a new release. Aside from that, it performs well. As an added bonus, the game supports resolution scaling tools like NVidia's DSR flawlessly.

That said, this game is a worthy successor to the Tales of..." series (as well as a solid JRPG

reviewText:
A fun JRPG to add to the selection on steam. I just finished my first playthrough and am happy to have purchased it.

PROS: -Tradiational JRPG story, Good vs Evil.
-Amazing music! You have the ability to change battle music by equiping different outfits as well.
-Anime styled cutsenes.
-Outfit customization is varied, lots of outfits you can unlock and accessories before DLC.
-A solid amount of sidequests.
-Character interactions, SO MANY PUNS!
-Replayability, you unlock a New Game+ upon first completion.

CONS: -Short for a JRPG (I put in 46 hrs for my first playthough)
-Equipment upgrading can be confusing.
-Too much DLC.

I really enjoyed this game, will probably do a second playthough in a few days. I recommend it to anyone who likes the Tales Series.

reviewText:
First off, I want to warn you the game may not run on your system if you are on Windows 10. The only way I could get this game to run is with a 3rd party community patch. A game IMHO should never be released in any such form! You have been warned. Go to the discussion board and get the community patch first.

I have trouble reviewing this game because it divides me so much.

I'll start with the positives by saying the game has a fantastic story and set of characters. All characters (annoying or not) are voiced well and likeable. The story is complex and so are the characters and there is a lot to love when the two coming together. This game does a great job of telling a story, as I think an RPG should.

The game has lots of great cut scenes, or mini cut scenes called skits. They do a great job of giving characters thoughts, ideas, and expressions in a fun anime like way. It's kind of a unique system that I've never seen and it just adds a lot I think.

They also have an Anime based on the game in the works, would totally watch.

As great as the story and character are, which really hold the game together, the game has issues.

Even with the community patch, the game does have some graphical issues during combat. Certain effects cause massive graphical slowdown on a GTX 970, which shouldn't happen. Then again the game wouldn't even run for me without a community patch.

The camera in the game does not work exactly as you would expect. It turns super slow. You will adapt mostly, but it's just something that is so weird it's worth mentioning because you will battle it all game.

One thing that was kind of good / bad is you lose a major character like 1/3 of the way through the game. It's not that it really changes anything it's just a really bizarre thing like they started making the game and decided they didn't really want this character to be in the game and then hastily wrote them out. Although the game's director downplays this, it seems almost evident.

The combat system is overly complex, but here is an “easy mode” if you wish to take some of the complexity out of the game. It gets easier the more you play it but sill takes a bit of time before you can really confidently fight “epic” type monsters and survive. The few strong enemies will clean your clock though, and it drives down the fun value.

There are a few times where you will not have clear goals and need to basically wander around until you discover where you are suppose to go. Some better hints would be nice rather than wasting literally hours of my time trying to figure out where to go. Wasting players time should not be considered good. It is a tactic used by bad games to extend their play time. It really kills the pacing of the game.


TLDR;
Overall the game is above average in terms of story, and the characters are great. It's a shame however that the game suffers from poor pacing and other problems that really just make it a mediocre game. The game tries to do too much and stretches out too long for the content included.

I'd say play it with tempered expectations going in, it's an interesting game but it's not going to probably make your “greatest RPGs ever” list.

reviewText:
SPOILERS INBOUND!!!

TL;DR:

Story: 5/10 (Average)
Characters: 7/10 (Above Average)
Lore: 7/10 (Above Average)
Overworld: 7/10 (Above Average)
Combat: 6/10 (Above Average) - 7/10 (If you want me to factor in controller schemes)
Performance: 7/10 (Above Average)
Music: 8/10 (Good Stuff)

Overall: 7/10 (Above Average)

This game is exceedingly above average. It isn't my first pick for a game to play, but I'd play it for days when I do. If you don't like some monotony/grinding,  then why are you playing RPGs?  this game is not for you.

In comparison to other Tales games, this is missing somethings and has some issues. However, it does have a place, and it will comfortable sit in my Tales collection, racking up hours like nobody's business, just like every other Tales game.

I'm happy with my purchase, but I'm on the fence with recommending this. Like I said, it can get grindy, which puts people off. But there is plenty of content in-game and post-game. I'm going to say yes, I recommend this, but be prepared. I would actually say that you wait for a sale before you decide to pick this up.
_________________________________________________________



Story:

Journey through the continent of Glenwood, purging evil in the land! You play as Sorey, a bright-eyed, ruin-loving youth, his adoptive brother, Mikleo, and others who dare to purify evil with them.

This is a fairly basic story. They set out to cleanse evil, and they do so. What more could you want?

...Well, actually plenty. But it's a servicable story, and there is nothing wrong with it. I just wished it had some more to it.

5/10 (Average)



Characters:

In a humorous statement:
We've got a ruin maniac, an invisible ruin maniac with control over water, Princess Not-Mary-Sue, a plucky assassin, a rocking sarcastic loli, Pun-Mistress Turbo (She's on Fire), Professor Wind, and that funny guy that's simultaneously awesome.


But yeah. These characters, while summed up rather crudely, are quite memorable for their interactions, as are most  Tales of  games. I've thoroughly enjoyed my time with these characters, and I'll probably remember them more than others in other games/VNs I've done so far. I just wished that they would have fleshed them out some more.

7/10 (Pretty good stuff)


Lore:

We've got the paragon of good, and the epitome of evil; the Shepard and the Wolves that threaten it. Well its actually not wolves but that's the idea.


LORE DUMP INBOUND!!!


There are three beings that exist on the continent of Glenwood:
Humans (SURPRISE!! :D)
Seraphim
Hellions



Humans are what you expect. You know, because we are human.

Seraphim are beings who are similar to humans, possessing great powers and significantly longer lifespans but only perceivable by a select few who are capable.

Hellions are either Humans or Seraphim that have become corrupted by evil; malevolence. They can be purified of their evil by a certain group of humans and seraphim.

These humans who can purify are referred to as Shepards. The Shepards use the power of the Seraphim to purify malevolence. There are two categories of Seraphim in reference to the Shepard: the Prime Lord and the Sub-Lord. The Prime Lord is the one who enables the Shepard to purify, and Sub-Lords are those who have bound themselves to subservience to the Prime Lord, allow the Shepard to wield their power and giving those Seraphim the ability to purify as well. Other humans can gain the power to purify in addition to the Shepards. They are known as Squires - they only make pacts to become bound the Shepard.

It is the duty of the Shepards to quell Hellions by quelling the source: the Lord of Calamity - your wolf to your Shepard.


I think it's fairly solid lore. Wish they would expand it some more, but this is plenty enough for decent lore.

Lore: 7/10


Overworld:
Holy crap this is an actual overworld! Everything is scaled up to match the player models on screen. It can feel lifeless at times with the lack to fauna skittering around, but that's where the Hellions come into play - they appear on the world as the fauna, and can be engage in combat.

Last two times I saw an expansive satisfactory overworld was in Skyrim and Middle-Earth: SoM

Overworld: 7/10


Combat
I'm not going to get detailed here.

It's servicable and I had fun with it, and what crazy combos you can pull off. Try it for yourself. If you are a returning Tales fan, it closely resembles Graces/f

Thing to note though:

It's a triangle advantage/disadvantage system for the artes.

Martial > Seraphic > Hidden > Martial ...


If you were wondering about the keyboard controls vs. controller feel, it works. The controls in-game can be rebinded to different keys/buttons. Its actually surprisingly intuitive.

Combat: 6/10 (Above Average)


Performance
This old beast of mine runs smoothly without the uncapped FPS mod at 30 FPS. I'm satisfied. It does occasionally dip below when there is too much happening.

Performance 7/10


Soundtrack
Sakuraba Motoi's usual fair - some of it is actually uninspired compared to some of his other stuff, like in Eternal Sonata. But Go Shiina picks up the slack with some exceptional pieces.

However, I'm easy to please in terms of music.

Music : 8/10

reviewText:
A nice and fun JRPG.

Pros:

+has some epic/emotional moments

+great soundtrack

+good character development

Cons:

reviewText:
Overall decent game and very glad that this series has been brought to PC. I hope that in the future they bring online co-op to the Tales games.

The characters and their characterization are great but the story, or rather lack of it, is dissapointing. It feels that you're just stumbling from one area to the next with no purpose. The voice acting is also great and am glad that pretty much everything is voiced acted unlike past Tales games. The graphics are good but pretty much on same level since Vesperia, just that now with full 3D enviroments.

The battle mechanics are great, especially the SC system instead of previous TP system, making using skills more frequently not risky. The equipment system is not, or at least not for a first playthrough. It has a good concept but to fully take advantage of it requires unnecessary grinding (which if done then your characters become too powerful that the advantages of the better equipment aren't really worth it anymore) for multiple copies of the same equipment or for buying and selling weak stuff over and over so that shops sell better equipment. This also makes looting dissapointing,as when you see that new shiny chst hoping to have that great loot it's just a crappy old weak equipment meant to be fused.

The battle camera is atrocious, especially when playing co-op, as it only focuses on the enemy the first player is targetting and if there's walls around it gets all confused and zooms in too much.

reviewText:
Preordered due to the inclusion of Tales of Symphonia on Steam.
Oops.

At least this game works flawlessly and can be easily modded to look and play far better than it does by default. An incredibly weak and cliched story, dialogue, characters (the wind seraphs, in particular), etc hold the game back - generally anything involving the writers' ability isn't up to snuff. Expect a stereotypical anime that lasts for roughly 45 hours and further weakens what it has to offer with more than the usual amount of obligatory, crippling cheesiness.

That said, the music is better than usual for this series, and the battle system is great at 60FPS, so much so that I'd recommend the game overall. Steam could use more JRPGs, but all I can recommend this one for is its battle system.

reviewText:
Despite it's overwhelming changes compared to more classical titles (such as Symphonia and Abyss), Tales of Zestiria keeps it true to be a Tales of Game.

I don't have enough hours on the game to give it a deep analysis on all the factors, so I'll update this review as I play...

So far, what has exceeded my expectations.

*Graphical design (Which steps over Vesperia by a good margin)
*Better and friendlier menus
*New management of Artes
*More tactical sense to battles

The things that have deeply hurt me are...

*Poor Control supports.
*Tons of bugs (this was expected though)
*Combat feels way more simplified.


Overall, you will receive the idea, that you are entering an adventure, a new road, which will be YOURS, and that my friends, is the purest essence of a Tales Game, a TALE, a story that engages it's player through, a phantasy that builds up is climax with masterpieces of musical talent and engaging combats...

I am really excited to see what this game has in store for me as the huge tales fan I am...

For those interested, to understand my opinion is not biased...

I have cleared Symphonia, Abyss, Vesperia and Phantasia.

Overall, this game deserves a good 7.5/10 for it's first impression and immersion that it has given me, hopefully, once all the bugs are solved, and it becomes better for PC, I can rate it accordingly to what it actually is.

reviewText: This game just reminds me of kingdom hearts with anime characters instead of disney characters. Its writing isn't very adult orientated but satisfying in the same tone that a pixar movie can be. It's definitly on my to do list of games to finish as what I have played so far is incredibly entertaining. The game does kind of hold your hand, but its because this game knows its audience. The audience is looking for a challanging witcher 3 esque rpg play. It's looking for a story. A story that not only brings about a sense of child-like wonder, but a story that entralls the user to feel emotion.  I have to recommend this game simply for its reminding of great rpg's i played as a kid, as well as the great non-adult anime's i enjoyed as a child. Its just a refreshing throwback game, that makes any oldschool rpg player happy to play it.

reviewText:
Brought the game yesterday and have played 7 hours of it. I'll give you all the pros and cons based on ratings out of 10 Note: I'm writing on my mobile.

- Art: the art style on the characters are on point. I believe that some textures on walls could be updated though. 6/10
- Combat: this is a hard one, the combat is extremely confusing as there's so many different buttons to press. It's also good that you have to learn combos as most of the time button mashing deals little to no damage. The main problems is the awful camera controls. You have to keep pressing the RB (if using 360 controller) to lock onto the nearest target otherwise it looks a mess. 6/10

Cosmetics: they're pretty funny. You're allowed a suit and a hat as your main outfit then you can have accessories to go on top of the outfit such as wings etc. There's a lot of cosmetics from DLCs and by looting from chests. 8/10

Armour: this is probably the most disappointing part, the armour doesn't display on your character. Bummer. All armour is basically the same name with a different prefix. 'Old' to 'Amber' etc. The armour at beginning game doesn't do a lot, I haven't progressed far enough to see if it's better at late game. 4/10

World: The world is extremely large but this games world reminds me of a game called last revenant where it's all instanced, the instances are very large though. The world's can be very bland with a few scattered chests and trees but sometimes they can be very beautiful with castles etc. The dungeons are all different but are still all extremely empty. 6/10

Enemies: There's a massive variety of enemies, from large bosses to small animals. All have their own attack patterns, weaknesses, strengths. 8.5/10

Cutscenes: there's two different types of cutscenes, one of them is from in-game and the other is the classic anime style. I can tell you now there's LOADS of cutscenes, almost around every corner, they are all skip panel though. They don't bother me too much as its a story game. The cutscenes art is glorious, sometimes the in-game cutscenes can be buggy. 6/10

FPS: it's at 30, a very noticeable 30, there's already a fix for this. -/10

Professions: there's not really any professions in the game, you can choose a small selection of what you can do but it does everything automatically. 2/10

Exploration: Not a whole lot of exploring, the lands are very similar. 4/10

Replay value: this depends, if you enjoy these games it can have an extremely high replay value. I can't see myself making more than one character. 7/10

Saving: strange, there's saving points scattered on the map yet you can go in the menu and select quick save. The save is also not done by characters but by overall, so if you made s new game it would overwrite the previous save. 5/10

Story: It's very generic and here's the rundown 'guy takes sword from the stone, finds then kills a guy'. There's a lot of background story and lots of elements so I make sure I watch every cutscenes. It might be generic but it's very manipulative. 6/10.

Upgrading: to upgrade you have to either play with your equipment and it upgrades overtime or you can take it to a blacksmith and combine it with the same type of clothing. No weapon customisation. 4/10.

I made it a thumbs up as for a JRPG it's the best non turned based you're going to get. Is it a dissapointment? Yes but no. I expected the game to look better and more current gen, it reminds me of an old xbox360 game called 'last revenant'. Is it worth £40? No way but it's 100% worth £20. This JRPG could have been made way better.
