reviewText:
Summary:
It's a fun game. However, I wouldn't say there's anything special about it. As a Tales game, it's probably one of the weaker ones. What I liked was that it was surprisingly dark. Children die, often the only redemption possible for people is through death, light doesn't triumph over dark, and humanity is generally awful. It makes for a really nice change. So, if you like JRPGs and the Tales series you will probably like this. It also has puns. The sheer amount they manage to fit in should be commended.

Detailed:

The overarching plot is very simple, a village boy leaves home for the first time and is later tasked with defeating the Big Bad, which is done through trials to get the power necessary. Where this game shines is in its characters. Maybe due to the game's battle mechanics, but every character feels necessary. They also have unique personalities and their personal stories are explored throughout the game. The voice acting is decent and you really learn to love the characters. However if you play with English audio you'll frequently notice the character will stop talking but their sprite's mouth keeps moving for a good five seconds, which can be annoying.

The battle system can be pretty complicated at first, but it's very smooth once you get used to it. The new enemies are called 'hellions' and your job is to purify them (which gameplay-wise is just defeat them). There's the usual fire, water, earth, wind strong/weak system, but the hellions also have their own categories to consider. For example, a hellion might be a beast type, and you can get equipment which is more effective against beasts. The unique battle system here is 'Armatisation', where you combine with another person to get more HP and special powers. Combat can be challenging as often you can't just hack and slash your way through battles. but the amazing invention of the quick step (back step, front step and side step) make them feel fun.

The worst part of combat is the camera. Sometimes, it's a real ♥♥♥♥♥.

If you're not smart, like me, the equipment system is very complicated. The basics are given to you, but its only through skits a lot of the information explained. To put it simply, one piece of equipment can have a maximum of 4 skills on it. You fuse equipment together to make it stronger and get better/different skills. By doing so, you can comfortably take on enemies which are 5-10 levels higher than you. There's also another dynamic, all about bonus skills which comes from E-Unions and links and other nonsense, but you don't need to know it well to play the game. Just randomly fusing everything together works well enough.

If you like skits, this game does have them, but they're only viewable in certain places and it's quite easy to miss some. My advice is to frequently stay at inns.

Regarding the New Game+, the best thing to do to is to make sure your Lords of the Lands are at the highest level you can be bothered to get them to. Their level affects how many points you get at the end of the game, which affects what bonus things you get in New Game+. However, there is a lot of replayability in this game, like all Tales, as you get bonus dungeons and bosses.

As this game isn't as popular as the others, if you encounter any problems you will often struggle to find a solution and wind up having to work it out yourself. For example, I accidentally activated local co-op (which is only in battle) but I had no idea how I'd done it and there was no support anywhere which told me how to turn it on, let alone turn it off (FYI, you have to change whether their moves are auto, semi-auto or manual in the artes menu).

Otherwise, it's okay.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I bought this game quite some time ago and didn't have many chances to actually finish it up until now. Having 9 to 5 jobs, a kid who needs attention and household chores tend to do that to you, heh.

Anyway, this would be my fifth Tales of - games since I entirely skipped PS3 Tales games library. I do tend to have Vesperia and Abyss standard concerning this franchise, and it ends up undermining (imho) other Tales games since Vesperia did almost everything so well with its stories, characters, and overall gameplay.

Now, Tales of Zestiria is not bad, per se. But it somehow lacks in some areas. Don't get me wrong, the combat is great, that has been the highlights of Tales series RPGs, and it is, in my opinion, the best aspect of the game. I like the Normin system, weapon crafting (or fusion), how the world is presented in the game, and the graphics is quite good. The game runs flawlessly on my GTX 950M, where I played it mostly (my GTX 970 rig is not actually portable). The main flaw of this game, maybe the for most of the Tales of - games is the story and how it is told. Zestiria somehow has this problem. The characters are quite likable, but I can't help feeling that there should be more character development. And some EXPLICIT romance would be nice. But that's just me.

I have to mention that the music in this game is superb. Especially on the Trial shrines and opening Japanese movie. There are numerous tracks, and battle musics somehow just pump up the already hectic battle system. Some would argue that it's all about button mashing, but without proper strategy and just pushing buttons haphazardly one would not get the best out of its intricate battles system. Oh, and be careful when fighting in tight spaces. The camera angle just goes bonkers in those cases.

Lastly, I cannot overlook how the game initially delivered. I'm talking about stuttering, choppy frame rate and audio problems. I have no problem with 30 fps, really, although I do prefer it to be in the sixties. It has all been fixed as of this review, but the bulk of the fix comes in the form of a third party patch. I REALLY think Bandai Namco can do better. I hope Berseria will not have these problems.

All in all, a good game, but I would say that it comes up short in some of the key aspects. I do recommend this for all Tales fans and Action JRPG fans. For newcomers to the series this would not be a bad start, but I do think they should start with the other games in the series.

Final score: 7.5/10

reviewText: This is the third day this game has been out and i already have 19 hours, and I am not afraid to pour in more time into this awesome game! I play the japanese dub because i find the english dubs actors voices to be a little bit obnoxious. Anyways, there is a bit of a grind, I am currently lv 31 and I am fighting monsters that are level 46, and leveling up is quite a pain. There is a $20 dlc which gives you double exp and gald and stuff but you can earn that in game the right way. I play with a controller so i have no idea how the pc controls work but the controller settings are wonderful. (Though the battle camera gets stuck on walls sometimes) The decisions you make are actually quite interesting, SPOILERS: In the beginning of the game a merchant asks you if you want to sell a royal knife for 1000 gald, DO NOT SELL IT!!!! Trust me it saves you the hassle, with the knife you're able to bypass the guards blocking you're way into the church, AND the knife was used as a key to a dungeon. I can not imagine what my game would be like right now if i sold that knife, 1000 gald isnt even that much! Anyways I highly recommend this game. Now if you'll excuse me, I got a game to play!

reviewText:
So, Tales of Zestiria. First of all, I'll inform you that I'm a bit of a “Tales of” fan, but with them being scattered across various consoles, I've played only 3 of them before Zestiria: Symphonia, Abyss and Vesperia. Given the background, I'll make some comparisons, but I'll try to stick to the game to itself.

I'll start right away with my overall impression, then if you'll like you can read the details behind my opinion. Tales of Zestiria it's an okay game: it's fun, it has interesting characters, the music is awesome, the battle system is quick paced. However, it's a bit of roller-coaster, with highs and lows, hits and misses; some aspects of the game are too simple, while other are too complicate. I'll stick on a 7,5/10 as a numeric value. If you're a “Tales of” fan, prepare for many changes; if you never played a “Tales of” game, this is a really nice JRPG, that needs some work on some things. In both cases, it will be a good experience!

So, why 7,5? Let's find out

Zestiria is a JRPG, so it's the usual mix of exploration, puzzles and battles, which are in real time: you command directly one of the characters in the party, while the others are guided by the CPU, that follows a series of guidelines customizable by the player. It's basically an action game, quick paced, fast, fun and enjoyable. However, you can still coordinate the attacks of the whole party, giving specific commands if you want to take on the battles with a more strategic approach.

Now, the system has really changed from the previous “Tales of” games: you don't have a mana bar, but rather an action bar, that depletes when you attack or when you dodge, but it refills automatically if you defend or simply stand still. You don't have 'basic attacks' as in the other “Tales of” games, but rather different techniques (Artes) that you can use. Point is, the close combat Artes common to all the characters (the Martial Artes) are 'linear': you can do four attack in a combo before being forced to reset it, but the possibilities are very limited. At the first attack, you'll have to pick one of two specific Martial Artes, at the second one one of four specific Martial Artes and so on; at the second attack you can't pick a Martial Arte that triggers only at the fourth move. And it's a bit of a pain, since every enemy has weakness related to specific attacks. There are ways to break their resistance of course, you are playing with four characters after all so one of them will be able to strike hard the enemy when you can't. But aside from that, the combos you'll be able to create are impersonal and limited: back in Vesperia, it was GORGEUS to see the characters fighting... I made a 300+ hit combo in there! That was SO fun! Zestiria, however, becomes too repetitive too quickly. Of course, you have other types of melee attacks (the Occult Artes) and the classic long range magic attacks (the Seraphic Artes), so there are still possibilities, but still... This battle system feels like a bit of step backwards in order to make new things. They also added lots of battle rules and specific actions that are simply too many: it's nice to improve a fighting system by making it deeper, but I think they got too far. They also added a range of 50 skills bound to your equipments: from them, it comes most of the fighting power your characters will be able to acquire; you'll also be able to fuse equipments to either power up existing skills or making new ones. But even here, it's a bit too much: as I said, 50 skills. You really need a guide to understand how to get the desired result.

In short, they took many risks, some paid off, some didn't. It's still enjoyable, but it feels like they added too much to renovate the system.

The characters are enjoyable; we've seen better in the “Tales of” history, but we've seen worse. Overall, I liked them, some more than the others (Edna, Dezel, Zaveid), but I didn't actually dislike any of them. They're good, they work well. The plot is a bit traditional (chosen hero needs to defeat the big evil guy), but the characters interactions and developments make the story interesting and enjoyable. The game world feels a bit small, compared to other “Tales of”, and it needs more sidequests... But, credit where it's due, they gave you a hint system to tell you where you need to go to trigger the sidequest... In the past, you needed to be at the right place at the right time and they rarely gave you a hint about it.

The music is AWESOME, I really loved it, it pumps you up during the fights and it makes you feel the emotions of the characters.

reviewText:
I have been a Tales fan since pre-Symphonia times and was very excited when I heard that the newest entry in the Tales series, Zestiria, was going to go back to its classic medieval style. During the first few hours of the game I was absolutely captivated. The world of Zestiria had the classic Tales flair with many Arthurian style elements, but that enthrallment slowly faded away due to the lack of character development and the story plot.
Graphically the game is very beautiful despite being outdated PS3 graphics, and the world and character design are all magnificently executed. I really liked the characters in the beginning but as the game progressed I felt that the personalities they had become static. The story went from being interesting, to painfully predictable. The only thing that really kept me going was the battle system, which had some new wonderful implements, and my love of the Tales series.
My absolute biggest complaint was that I felt that the game was extremely linear due to the lack of side quests compared to that found in other Tales games. The side quests present in the game always felt like they were oddly timed between the few important story quests, and always revolved around optional dungeons. I did enjoy how optional dungeons were peppered into the newly improved world map system, but any quests that involved them were merely “go and fight X here.”
Despite these complaints I would still recommend this game to any Tales fan. It won’t be your favorite Tales game ever, but it’s a solid entry in the series.

reviewText:
Pros:

- Amazing Story
- Memorable Cast, Edna was my favorite
- Skit System
- Battle system
- Loved the soundtrack

Cons:

- Sometimes I was unsure where the game wanted me to go (though sometimes this felt like the point)
- When fighting in a corner the camera would place itself at a bad angle

While playing Tales of Zestiria it felt like Namco was trying a few new things such as the changes to the battle system and  how the main cast interacted with the party (I'm being very vague to avoid spoilers). With the execption of some hiccups with the camera, I loved them all. The game was shorter than I expected, however, I did not want to list this as a con because I would rather not have a story drawn out longer than it needed to be. If you enjoyed other Tales games this is a game for you.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game far, far more than I expected I would  - I thought I would skip this entry as I thought the trailer betrayed lower production values than tales of Xillia, and I wasnt sold on the character designs. Regarding the latter, I still dislike Mikleo's clothes and Soreys stupid ear feathers, but after our 70 hours together I love them far too much to care. I loved them enough after 2.

However, The game does seem have Lower Production values than Xillia. The Field environments are far better spatially designs than the blobs of land seen in Xillia, but in parts are very, for want of a better word, polygony. The town and dungeon areas dont seem as well designed as Xillia but they arent quite so polygony. Possibly because most of the dungeons are ruins which could be made from repeatable rectilinear assets which would reduce the work needed.

The battle system is a bit of a departure from previous games. The battle system has been gradually become more are more 3 dimensional in each installment, and using the battle ability 'Free and Free' completly removes the 2d axis you traditionally fight on. I didnt. The ability to fuse with the different seraphim characters in your Party is good to really mix up the playstyle, whether it's for defensive reasons, in order the withstand a bosses blows, or just for when you get surrounded by enemies weak to water and want to maelstrom them into oblivion. The camera is not great. It is what it is.

One thing that has come under fire is the abilities on a grid system. It is quite complicated. There are 50 abilities which all occupy a grid. Line up 2 or more horizontally you will get different elemental bonuses, or of you get all 5 in a collumn vertically you get a stat boost. For example for the first collumn grants you 10% boost on all stats. However I was fearful of losing this bonus after I had gotten it and as as a result by characters were wearing 1st and 2nd tier equipment far too late in the game for them to be doing so. I later opted for equiping all the strongest equipments for their various strengths and making small consessions for certain abilities to make up for a characters weaknesses or provide abilities beneficial for certain bosses. For example I equipped Sorey with 3 peices of equipment with the Lindwer ability, providing 45% more damage against dragons (15 each), and the bonus for stacking 3 was adding an extra unit to my blast gauge (blast gauge being expended for fusing and special attacks).

The Strong point in this game in the characters. They are so likeable. I didnt think anyone would replace Jude Mathis of Tales of Xillia at the top of my list of most likeble Tales Protagonists but Sorey may have done just that. Theres lots of skits that expand on the characters, and even the enemy information is full little tidbits of Lailahs puns, Edna's snark and insults directed at Mikleo, and Sorey being so enamored with the little gun carts the goblins ride that he wished to be the first Goblin Shepherd (all the while being lightly chastised by Mikleo). Theres something quite refreshing about opening the enemy info mid boss and have rose making a Joke. Theres also a fair amount of fun in the item descriptions as well (Soreys not allowed to touch Mikleos hair, not since the incident) and its these little touches that really make Tales of Zestiria.

Theres also a good soundtrack, a few pieces being outstanding, an overall improvement on previous games in the series.

If the question comes down to whether its better than Tales of Xillia then the answer is no, but that comparing an excellent JRPG with a very good one. If you have a PS3 play Xillia first. If you dont this is still worth your time and money.

I only meant to write a short few words to show support. Whoops.
And Meebo is my Precious Angel.

Hmmmm I have seen this game get a lot of hate from various sources but honestly i do not understand why. Many reviewers say that this game does not do much to inovate, but I have to disagree. All in all, i thought this was a great addition to the series and I would reccomend it strongly.

reviewText:
Never owned a 'Tales of....' game before but I have to say I feel as though my purchase was justified. I felt as though my library was in need of more JRPG's and I made a bold choice purchasing ToZ without any idea of what the game was about or any insight of what to expect it was a pure jump in the deep end which luckily paid off.
I won't lie, the game is not perfect, I felt the story wasn't as rich as it could have been but the gameplay was flawless, the character interaction as good and I really enjoyed the battle system even though at first it felt a bit overwhelming you quickly pick things up as you go along.

Story
The story is about a teenage human boy named Sorey who has lived amongst seraphim (beings with power unseen by natural humans) since he was a baby, events transpire that takes him on a quest in search for an unknown force that is causing great malevolence (a darkness that is created by the evil within humans and seraphim), taking on the role as the Shepard (ancient heroes that can take on the power of seraphim and purify the world of malevolence) he crosses the world with his companions bringing peace and light to all.

I felt the story as a whole was written well, it was straight forward and left no questions unanswered.
7/10

Characters
Without giving too much away of possible playable characters I won't name them all but in total you get a party of 6 players which of only 3 or 4 may battle.

Character development is my biggest problem regarding to the characters, I just didn't really feel emotionally attached to any of them as much as I should do when playing an JRPG (That FF7 moment with Aeris still haunts me to this day), not to say the characters are boring or flat in fact the characters Edna and Zaveid will probably go down as some of my favourite, again that is all I can say about that without ruining a part of the game.

The quirky interactions they have during battle or when resting in inns is brilliant and does bring some light hearted comedy into the equation which makes sleeping at the inn worthwhile!
I enjoyed the characters and found some parts amusing however I do feel as though the characters could have been developed a bit better to give the players more of an emotional attachment.
6/10

Gameplay
The game handles well, probably what you'd expect from a JRPG, open world exploration countless battles, be prepared for ultimate grinding I was taken into a false sense of security in thinking levelling up was easy until I hit break point and spent ages farming exp (and gald, plenty of gald).

The weapon system is easy enough to understand and with fusion if you start to horde weapon equipment (as long as they are the same item) you can fuse them together (for a price of course) making the weapons stronger and transferring any abilities they may have.

The use of Artes is easy, again once you get the knack it's a case of carefully coordinating your attacks leading to some killer combos!

One thing which is also helpful are across the world are these things called stone monolith's which when interacted with just give basic tips on the game itself, if like me and you're not a fan of this then you really don't need to read them but you do collect AP points which become helpful as you use these to spend on battle actions.

Battle Actions are a series of automated instructions you can give to the main protagonist Sorey, things like Auto backstep which (obviously) automatically backstep evades attacks at the cost of some SP points, which I think stands for Stamina points?

The battle camera is probably THE worse aspect of the game, it can become annoying when pinned into a corner and the camera zooms right into the battle and then to make matters worse a tree branch gets into your line of sight, it's very frustrating and has killed me a few times, I'd like to say you get used to it but you don't you just learn not to get pinned into a corner. Even when it's not zooming in its spinning out of control, it sometimes feels someone is recording the battle on a mobile phone or video camera and can't keep still, I'd like to point out it's not always like that though, but when it does you will rage.

The gameplay is great and my favourite thing about the game but it loses points on the battle camera part which is a shame.
9/10


I feel as though I've covered most things vital, Tales of Zestiria is a must have for any JRPG lover, I've played under 64 hours completed it and now I've started my second play through on Chaos mode (they have a New Game+ feature).


Overall score
7.5/10

reviewText:
Only 3 hours in and I am hooked already. If you've never played a Tales game before and are an RPG fan, you owe it to yourself to pickup one of the best RPG series you've probably never heard of. The Tales Of games are a series similar to Final Fantasy but have never reached the same level of acclaim due to many of the games not being localized in English or only being released for specific consoles. Despite that, the Tales Of series has been going strong since the SNES days and is one of the greatest RPG series of all time. Combine the action-oriented combat with deep character customization, great narrative and plot, and for the first time ever, branching storylines with choices that impact the game as you play along.

If you are a Tales fan, you are about to experience one of the best games in the series. I have not beaten the game, and as I said am only 3 hours in, but I will update this review as I progress. But I can already tell this is THE defining game in the series. Want the best of Tales of Graces without the quirky combat, the cool and memorable deep characters from Xillia, the unique story of Phantasia, the epic feeling of Symphonia, and the awesome graphics of Vespiria all in one game? That's what I'm getting from Tales of Zesteria, and at only 3 hours in. There is so much depth to the battle mechanics, titles, equipment, collectibles, skits and more.

You need to play this game. Technical issues will be ironed out, this is the first PC Tales game... EVER. So they are surely developing on a new platform they haven't worked with before. Please support the game and encourage this great series to cater to PC gamers in the future.

I ALMOST REFUND THE GAME

My initial problem that the game has some sound issues which can be easily be fix. Then there's the graphics. I recommend to manually configure the graphics option in your NVIDIA control panel. The game isn't running 60fps (yet) but if configure it properly it runs very smoothly which for me whose sensitive in graphics slowness and lag. This game is very good once the small changes has been made. It's very easy just read the guide for additional help because at first it runs horribly and I know that the developer could have made a better setting than that but don't let those negative reviews fool you. It's a damn good game-- so far.

reviewText:
So I have been playing this now for probably 3 hours and I am having a blast I love Tales of Games and have played almost every single one to date minus a few that i couldn't get.

I just want to address something that i saw this was getting flack for.  When you switch the game to surround sound it's actually creating seperate channels for each audio type and a lot of people are saying they lose the voice sounds.  I plugged in my Logitech Z506 5.1 Surrond Speaker system to my computer it had been sitting stagnant for awhile as soon as i plugged it in and turned them on my voice sounds were coming crystal clear through the center channel with no problems what so ever.  If you're using one of those gaming headset that says Dolby 7.1 surround they only actually have 2 speakers with drivers making them sound like 7.1 so you're not going to get all the sound channels in them stick to stereo for the game.

To get back on topic.  It's a great game even with the 30 FPS lock combat is just like other tales of games and you will enjoy this game if you purchase it and like JRPG styled games.

Pros:

Cons:

If you enjoyed other Tales games this is a game for you.

reviewText:
I enjoyed this game far, far more than I expected I would  - I thought I would skip this entry as I thought the trailer betrayed lower production values than tales of Xillia, and I wasnt sold on the character designs. Regarding the latter, I still dislike Mikleo's clothes and Soreys stupid ear feathers, but after our 70 hours together I love them far too much to care. I loved them enough after 2.

However, The game does seem have Lower Production values than Xillia. The Field environments are far better spatially designs than the blobs of land seen in Xillia, but in parts are very, for want of a better word, polygony. The town and dungeon areas dont seem as well designed as Xillia but they arent quite so polygony. Possibly because most of the dungeons are ruins which could be made from repeatable rectilinear assets which would reduce the work needed.

The battle system is a bit of a departure from previous games. The battle system has been gradually become more are more 3 dimensional in each installment, and using the battle ability 'Free and Free' completly removes the 2d axis you traditionally fight on. I didnt. The ability to fuse with the different seraphim characters in your Party is good to really mix up the playstyle, whether it's for defensive reasons, in order the withstand a bosses blows, or just for when you get surrounded by enemies weak to water and want to maelstrom them into oblivion. The camera is not great. It is what it is.

One thing that has come under fire is the abilities on a grid system. It is quite complicated. There are 50 abilities which all occupy a grid. Line up 2 or more horizontally you will get different elemental bonuses, or of you get all 5 in a collumn vertically you get a stat boost. For example for the first collumn grants you 10% boost on all stats. However I was fearful of losing this bonus after I had gotten it and as as a result by characters were wearing 1st and 2nd tier equipment far too late in the game for them to be doing so. I later opted for equiping all the strongest equipments for their various strengths and making small consessions for certain abilities to make up for a characters weaknesses or provide abilities beneficial for certain bosses. For example I equipped Sorey with 3 peices of equipment with the Lindwer ability, providing 45% more damage against dragons (15 each), and the bonus for stacking 3 was adding an extra unit to my blast gauge (blast gauge being expended for fusing and special attacks).

The Strong point in this game in the characters. They are so likeable. I didnt think anyone would replace Jude Mathis of Tales of Xillia at the top of my list of most likeble Tales Protagonists but Sorey may have done just that. Theres lots of skits that expand on the characters, and even the enemy information is full little tidbits of Lailahs puns, Edna's snark and insults directed at Mikleo, and Sorey being so enamored with the little gun carts the goblins ride that he wished to be the first Goblin Shepherd (all the while being lightly chastised by Mikleo). Theres something quite refreshing about opening the enemy info mid boss and have rose making a Joke. Theres also a fair amount of fun in the item descriptions as well (Soreys not allowed to touch Mikleos hair, not since the incident) and its these little touches that really make Tales of Zestiria.

Theres also a good soundtrack, a few pieces being outstanding, an overall improvement on previous games in the series.

If the question comes down to whether its better than Tales of Xillia then the answer is no, but that comparing an excellent JRPG with a very good one. If you have a PS3 play Xillia first. If you dont this is still worth your time and money.

I only meant to write a short few words to show support. Whoops.
And Meebo is my Precious Angel.

reviewText:
So, Tales of Zestiria. First of all, I'll inform you that I'm a bit of a “Tales of” fan, but with them being scattered across various consoles, I've played only 3 of them before Zestiria: Symphonia, Abyss and Vesperia. Given the background, I'll make some comparisons, but I'll try to stick to the game to itself.

I'll start right away with my overall impression, then if you'll like you can read the details behind my opinion. Tales of Zestiria it's an okay game: it's fun, it has interesting characters, the music is awesome, the battle system is quick paced. However, it's a bit of roller-coaster, with highs and lows, hits and misses; some aspects of the game are too simple, while other are too complicate. I'll stick on a 7,5/10 as a numeric value. If you're a “Tales of” fan, prepare for many changes; if you never played a “Tales of” game, this is a really nice JRPG, that needs some work on some things. In both cases, it will be a good experience!

So, why 7,5? Let's find out

Zestiria is a JRPG, so it's the usual mix of exploration, puzzles and battles, which are in real time: you command directly one of the characters in the party, while the others are guided by the CPU, that follows a series of guidelines customizable by the player. It's basically an action game, quick paced, fast, fun and enjoyable. However, you can still coordinate the attacks of the whole party, giving specific commands if you want to take on the battles with a more strategic approach.

Now, the system has really changed from the previous “Tales of” games: you don't have a mana bar, but rather an action bar, that depletes when you attack or when you dodge, but it refills automatically if you defend or simply stand still. You don't have 'basic attacks' as in the other “Tales of” games, but rather different techniques (Artes) that you can use. Point is, the close combat Artes common to all the characters (the Martial Artes) are 'linear': you can do four attack in a combo before being forced to reset it, but the possibilities are very limited. At the first attack, you'll have to pick one of two specific Martial Artes, at the second one one of four specific Martial Artes and so on; at the second attack you can't pick a Martial Arte that triggers only at the fourth move. And it's a bit of a pain, since every enemy has weakness related to specific attacks. There are ways to break their resistance of course, you are playing with four characters after all so one of them will be able to strike hard the enemy when you can't. But aside from that, the combos you'll be able to create are impersonal and limited: back in Vesperia, it was GORGEUS to see the characters fighting... I made a 300+ hit combo in there! That was SO fun! Zestiria, however, becomes too repetitive too quickly. Of course, you have other types of melee attacks (the Occult Artes) and the classic long range magic attacks (the Seraphic Artes), so there are still possibilities, but still... This battle system feels like a bit of step backwards in order to make new things. They also added lots of battle rules and specific actions that are simply too many: it's nice to improve a fighting system by making it deeper, but I think they got too far. They also added a range of 50 skills bound to your equipments: from them, it comes most of the fighting power your characters will be able to acquire; you'll also be able to fuse equipments to either power up existing skills or making new ones. But even here, it's a bit too much: as I said, 50 skills. You really need a guide to understand how to get the desired result.

In short, they took many risks, some paid off, some didn't. It's still enjoyable, but it feels like they added too much to renovate the system.

The characters are enjoyable; we've seen better in the “Tales of” history, but we've seen worse. Overall, I liked them, some more than the others (Edna, Dezel, Zaveid), but I didn't actually dislike any of them. They're good, they work well. The plot is a bit traditional (chosen hero needs to defeat the big evil guy), but the characters interactions and developments make the story interesting and enjoyable. The game world feels a bit small, compared to other “Tales of”, and it needs more sidequests... But, credit where it's due, they gave you a hint system to tell you where you need to go to trigger the sidequest... In the past, you needed to be at the right place at the right time and they rarely gave you a hint about it.

The music is AWESOME, I really loved it, it pumps you up during the fights and it makes you feel the emotions of the characters.

reviewText:
I have been a Tales fan since pre-Symphonia times and was very excited when I heard that the newest entry in the Tales series, Zestiria, was going to go back to its classic medieval style. During the first few hours of the game I was absolutely captivated. The world of Zestiria had the classic Tales flair with many Arthurian style elements, but that enthrallment slowly faded away due to the lack of character development and the story plot.
Graphically the game is very beautiful despite being outdated PS3 graphics, and the world and character design are all magnificently executed. I really liked the characters in the beginning but as the game progressed I felt that the personalities they had become static. The story went from being interesting, to painfully predictable. The only thing that really kept me going was the battle system, which had some new wonderful implements, and my love of the Tales series.
My absolute biggest complaint was that I felt that the game was extremely linear due to the lack of side quests compared to that found in other Tales games. The side quests present in the game always felt like they were oddly timed between the few important story quests, and always revolved around optional dungeons. I did enjoy how optional dungeons were peppered into the newly improved world map system, but any quests that involved them were merely “go and fight X here.”
Despite these complaints I would still recommend this game to any Tales fan. It won’t be your favorite Tales game ever, but it’s a solid entry in the series.

reviewText:
Never owned a 'Tales of....' game before but I have to say I feel as though my purchase was justified. I felt as though my library was in need of more JRPG's and I made a bold choice purchasing ToZ without any idea of what the game was about or any insight of what to expect it was a pure jump in the deep end which luckily paid off.
I won't lie, the game is not perfect, I felt the story wasn't as rich as it could have been but the gameplay was flawless, the character interaction as good and I really enjoyed the battle system even though at first it felt a bit overwhelming you quickly pick things up as you go along.

Story
The story is about a teenage human boy named Sorey who has lived amongst seraphim (beings with power unseen by natural humans) since he was a baby, events transpire that takes him on a quest in search for an unknown force that is causing great malevolence (a darkness that is created by the evil within humans and seraphim), taking on the role as the Shepard (ancient heroes that can take on the power of seraphim and purify the world of malevolence) he crosses the world with his companions bringing peace and light to all.

I felt the story as a whole was written well, it was straight forward and left no questions unanswered.
7/10

Characters
Without giving too much away of possible playable characters I won't name them all but in total you get a party of 6 players which of only 3 or 4 may battle.

Character development is my biggest problem regarding to the characters, I just didn't really feel emotionally attached to any of them as much as I should do when playing an JRPG (That FF7 moment with Aeris still haunts me to this day), not to say the characters are boring or flat in fact the characters Edna and Zaveid will probably go down as some of my favourite, again that is all I can say about that without ruining a part of the game.

The quirky interactions they have during battle or when resting in inns is brilliant and does bring some light hearted comedy into the equation which makes sleeping at the inn worthwhile!
I enjoyed the characters and found some parts amusing however I do feel as though the characters could have been developed a bit better to give the players more of an emotional attachment.
6/10

Gameplay
The game handles well, probably what you'd expect from a JRPG, open world exploration countless battles, be prepared for ultimate grinding I was taken into a false sense of security in thinking levelling up was easy until I hit break point and spent ages farming exp (and gald, plenty of gald).

The weapon system is easy enough to understand and with fusion if you start to horde weapon equipment (as long as they are the same item) you can fuse them together (for a price of course) making the weapons stronger and transferring any abilities they may have.

The use of Artes is easy, again once you get the knack it's a case of carefully coordinating your attacks leading to some killer combos!

One thing which is also helpful are across the world are these things called stone monolith's which when interacted with just give basic tips on the game itself, if like me and you're not a fan of this then you really don't need to read them but you do collect AP points which become helpful as you use these to spend on battle actions.

Battle Actions are a series of automated instructions you can give to the main protagonist Sorey, things like Auto backstep which (obviously) automatically backstep evades attacks at the cost of some SP points, which I think stands for Stamina points?

The battle camera is probably THE worse aspect of the game, it can become annoying when pinned into a corner and the camera zooms right into the battle and then to make matters worse a tree branch gets into your line of sight, it's very frustrating and has killed me a few times, I'd like to say you get used to it but you don't you just learn not to get pinned into a corner. Even when it's not zooming in its spinning out of control, it sometimes feels someone is recording the battle on a mobile phone or video camera and can't keep still, I'd like to point out it's not always like that though, but when it does you will rage.

The gameplay is great and my favourite thing about the game but it loses points on the battle camera part which is a shame.
9/10


I feel as though I've covered most things vital, Tales of Zestiria is a must have for any JRPG lover, I've played under 64 hours completed it and now I've started my second play through on Chaos mode (they have a New Game+ feature).


Overall score
7.5/10

Hmmmm I have seen this game get a lot of hate from various sources but honestly i do not understand why. Many reviewers say that this game does not do much to inovate, but I have to disagree. They completely revamped the open world design. Made the entire game more seamless in design. Towns are bigger and the combat is my favorite so far in series. On the subjective side of things I personally enjoyed the characters in the story just fine. The only real con I can think of is the battle camera. The camera does have some problems, but it is not that bad. The camera occasionally gets caught on terrain, but this does not happen frequently.

All in all, i thought this was a great addition to the series and I would reccomend it strongly.

Only about 20 hours into the game at the writing of this review, so keep in mind this isn't a 100% review.

I feel I have enough time in game to decide if I like the game or not. And well, I ♥♥♥♥♥ do! The game is amazing. It holds true to the JRPG/Adventure genre. It can easily be compared to a lot of games, but a lot of those are also Tales games. If you can afford it, BUY IT.

Innovative weapon system
Very easy to configure your characters for battle
Excellent combo control in battle

Cons -
You may get tired of the puns
Up yours if you don't like it.





Seriously though. The game is great.

The game is also very much familiar gameplay elements Kindom Hearts game, that game myself the most brings to mind, which is pleasing to myself.

The game has plenty to do even for the discerning rpg gamers.

Definitely worth the money and the purchase of a game that percentage. In the best JRPG game for myself 2015/2016

Forced to own, which is not every day offer. My best spended 50 euros + add-ons for one jrpg game ever.

High testimonials for the game.

IGN 10/10


FIN:

Aivan häikäisevän käsittämättömän kaunis ja yksinkertaisettu JRPG peli, joka on koskaan tehty.
Paras JRPG peli tähän asti, jota olen koskaan pelannut tietokoneella, ei epäilystäkään.

Jos olet juuri nyt etsimässä hyvää ja tuoretta JRPG peliä niin, tässä se on!

Olen pelannut useita rpg pelejä mutta, pidän eniten tästä pelistä, jotenka kirjoitankin tämän arvostelun enemmän minun omasta kokemuksesta kuin yleisesti ja antaa tällä kertaa tuote esittelyn ja muiden kirjoittaa sisältökohtaisemmin esittelynsä sekä arvostelunsa ja minä kirjoitan omani.

Harvoin kirjoitan positiivisia arvosteluja rpg peleistä, sillä en itse pelaa niitä juurikaan mutta, tämä peli teki itselleni heti vaikutuksen heti ensi lähdöstä lähtien & minä todella rehellisesti nautin siitä tällä kertaa.

Kerrankin rehellisesti voin sanoa että, nyt on kysessä varmasti paljon parempi kuin Final Fantasy sarja takuulla.

Arvostan pelissä todella paljon pelin helppoa vaikeustasoa, tarinan kerronnan seuraamista sekä yksinkertaistettua pelimaailmaa, johon ei voi eksyä. Todella hieno peli musiikki ja kiinostavilla hahmoilla, joita voi muokata upeilla elokuvamaisilla animaatioilla tekevät tästä todella hienon pelin pelata.

Pelissä on myös hyvin paljon tuttuja pelillisiä elementtejä Kindom Hearts pelistä, jota peli itselleni eniten tuo mieleen, joka on itselleni mieluisaa.

Pelissä on yllinkyllin tekemistä jopa vaativille rpg pelaajille. Ehdottomasti ostamisen ja rahan arvoinen peli, joka sentti.

Vuoden paras JRPG peli itelleni 2015/2016

Pakko omistaa, jota ei ole joka päivä tarjolla. Elämäni paras sijoittamani 50 euroa + lisäosat yhdestä jrpg pelistä ikinä.

Korkeat suosittelut pelille.

IGN 10/10

reviewText:
Great game,
For a tales of game

The characters as usual lack emotion and gesturing in their character models, but the english dub cast i do not mind at all, and its on par with Vesperia and Symphonia in my opinion.


On PC (THANKS TO FANS OF THE GAME) it can be played 60FPS+ no problem (WITH THE MOD, less screen tearing and frame issues)

IF you have played previous Games in the franchise, this game plays just like them, More or less like Vesperia, Less like Symphonia EXCEPT that you dont have a world map, you walk everywhere like in  a Legend of Zelda game. Which i feel is a Good thing so far.
Every change was made for the better of the franchise. but the only downside is that MOST of the dungeons are SHORT AS HELL and could be longer like in Vesperia.

reviewText: Tales of Zestiria is a fun button-mashing RPG. The combat elements are fairly simple yet enjoyable. The only downside to Zestiria is the fact that the story is incredibly mediocre. After 30+ hours of gameplay I can hardly stand to finish the game even though I am close to the end. If you require an enjoyable story to muddle your way through a game then I do not recommend this game. However, if all you want is button mashing combat with a few Artes thrown in to take advantage of a weakness then you should enjoy this one.

reviewText:
(Final (first playthrough) review coming)

Firstly, the optimization is incredible. I was accidentally running it on my Intel i5 processor instead of my Nvidia and it STILL ran great on around medium graphics!

But aside from that, Tales of Zestiria is really shaping up to be a top-notch JRPG and a good entry into the Tales series. The environments are beautiful, the story so far is pretty intriguing, and the characters are diverse! The battle system is your typical Tales Of fare, with the Armatization mechanic to mix it up. Yes, the camera is problematic, but it's an easily avoided one in most cases.

I've listened to some of the soundtrack before release, and the Zestiria soundtrack is probably one of my top soundtracks to date. Each song has richness and depth that you rarely see with atmosphere soundtracks these days, and the special tracks by Go Shiina are just incredible.

I'll update this review as I play, but I don't forsee my current strong recommendation changing throughout!

reviewText:
LORE
Ok, so there's a race of invisible people who live all around humans, angels basically, known as seraphim in the game. They're literally everywhere and according to the game they even eat food, yet somehow most people don't acknowledge or believe in them despite what I assume has to be a extremely high number of floating and disappearing food reports. The whole thing is a completely unnecessay plot device in my opinion.

The other part of the lore is that whenever a human, seraphim and even animals gets mad or hateful enough they become powerful monsters, who then apparently live forever unless the chosen one kills them, which turns them back, unless they're still angry or get angry again in which case they'll apparenly turn back into a monster. So instead of being a badass warrior of justice the game makes you feel more like an anger management counselor.

PLOT
Everything is pointless. There's several times where you will get to choose one of two seemingly important options in dialogue, but you get the same result no matter what you pick. The only difference is that you occasionally get a slightly different cutscene on some of them. And speaking of dialogue, the word malevolence" literally shows up in almost every sentence from every character.

Another example is a character doing something in a cutscene just to show how cool you're supposed to think they are
date: such as one character trying to fight an enemy on their own because they're immune to it's special ability
recommended: only for you to have to fight the boss with the rest of the party like normal anyway with absolutely no changes to the fighting mechanics. So the entire cutscene was basically just that one character saying "Look how cool I am.".\n\nThere's also several times in the story where the party does something completely pointless and unsatisfying
hoursPlayed: such as confronting a major and extremely dangerous villain who intends to kill a lot of people
voteText: and then letting them calmly walk away as if they were just players on different football teams or something. Literally every time that there's a confrontation
helpfulPercent: the solution that's forced onto you is to go somewhere and do something to get stronger first regardless of what might happen in the meantime.\n\nDespite the MC supposedly being the "chosen one"
votesHelpful: there's multiple other people that can do everything he does
votesTotal: only with less whining. Also
votesFunny: near the start of the game he pulls a legendary sword from a stone (super original) to become the chosen one
commentsCount:
though immediately after the sword isn't shown anywhere and is inexplicably never mentioned again. Yet another completely unnecessay plot device.

CHARACTERS
Completely uninteresting and generic anime archtypal characters. There's no character developement or flaws to speak of
column16: the MC is your standard naive good guy type who generally has about as much to add to the situation as a Buzz Lightyear pull string doll. And the bad guys are equally one dimensional
column17: they're all just flatly evil and want to do evil things because they're evil for no reason other than because they're evil. And just in case them being evil is too much for you to keep track of they all have dark colors
column18: clothes
column19:
and auras to make things simple for you.

GRAPHICS
Standard anime style characters and medieval fantasy style world
column20: the lack of imagination isn't that big of a deal on it's own
column21: however the graphics are late Xbox or early 360 quality at best. Before I played this I recently played Tales of the Abyss on PS2 and the change is pretty minimal
column22: which is inexcusable considering they're a decade apart. Aside from the quality the lack of originality and overuse of immersion breaking anime cutscenes make looking at the screen more of a chore than it needs to be. The game sports a little bit of character customization
column23: though extremely limited
column24:
however they're all shown as their default setups in any of the numerous anime cutscenes. So it's pretty bad for the immersion.

COMBAT
The combat is bad
column25: it's extremely awkward
column26: boring
column27: and one-sided. There is zero strategy involved
column28: you can't assign any roles to your party members such as healing or tanking
column29: and they have no problem repeatedly walking into a lingering attack that is killing them. You'd think that would make it more of a hack and slash style game
column30: however any time you get a few good hits in on an enemy they inexplicably become invincible for a random amount of time. Which is especially annoying when you finally get one of the super moves to work
column31: only to have it completely wasted on a basic monster who decided to turn on god mode. The whole thing could be compared to playing rock
column32: paper
column33: scissors but everytime you throw the right one your opponent ignores it and says that they win anyway.\n\nSo combat generally consists of you running around in circles

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria is a decent port marred by frame limiting issues that they refuse to fix
I will admit, I came into this with low expectations after they announced it'd be 30FPS only.
Initially I was impressed with this port as it does a lot of things right that others fail to do. But it has a lot of issues that they just are completely ignoring. They are willing to fix some issues carrying things to the side DLC, but dont' give a ♥♥♥♥ about anything else. At least not yet, and not that they have communicated. Which is irritating as all hell. It doesn't inspire faith for Symphonia on PC.

The only reason this is getting a Yes" and upvote is because of TZFix picking up the slack and fixing a lot of problems.

Look at the Alisha DLC issues
date:
they swooped in and fixed those STAT. The rest of the problems? AT LEAST the damn frame rate limiter causing constant stuttering? NOPE. That's a non-problem.




Pros Arbitrary Resolution Support
Decent amount of Graphics Options (Including Texture Filtering
recommended:
even if it is completely useless on some textures.)
DX9 meaning we can force better Anti Aliasing! I made a guide here ! https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=539008816 (Might still be waiting to be approved)
Retains Local-CoOp
Local-CoOp supports two controllers or KB&M+Controller
Buttons are fully remappable
Separate Sound Sliders
Well optimized (I can run 5464x3072 on a 980 and only be hitting just over half GPU usage)
KB*M and Controller prompts (Though it does not auto detect between the two. You have to set it in the main menu first)
Surround Sound
English and Japanese voice overs______________________________________________________________________

Cons  Does not natively support any resolution other than 16:9.
Fixed with TZFix
https://steamcommunity.com/app/351970/discussions/0/490123938441506815

Vsync is partially broken. It will only apply when you turn it on in the Main Menu and then quit the game using the "Quit" Button. And then restart the game. (If you Alt-F4 it will not work)
Forcing Vsync is not an option
hoursPlayed: at least in my testing. Any forced Vsync from the Drivers (including 1/2 refresh Vsync on 60hz which is 30hz sync) will result in constant microstuttering and judder every so many rendered frames.\nAnd as it turns out
voteText:
the in game Vsync has Microstuttering as well!
TZFix can fix this in a few different ways.
https://steamcommunity.com/app/351970/discussions/0/490123938441506815

There are currently issues with different Sound Sample Rates than 48.0Khz or even 44.1khz
helpfulPercent: from crashing to crackling audio. You will need to set your output device's SR in shared mode to at least 44.1khz.  A fix is included in this larger utility/fix https://steamcommunity.com/app/351970/discussions/0/490123938441506815/\n\nIt uses Bink video for the Anime FMVs *Uck* it's 2015 people get a damn clue and quit using this low quality crap. The PS3 version used BDMV for Blu-Ray quality video
votesHelpful:
IIRC it was like an additional 16GB just for video. Which is nice.
Final Fantasy Type-0 uses x264 videos. Something MORE games should start doing if you are going to include FMVs.


30FPS cap. This is not a port of an old game
votesTotal: something that can be excused for games like Grandia 2 or Type-0. Not for a new game. Though Honestly i'd be just fine if they fixed the damn stuttering and reduced latency more.\nTZFix has 60FPS WIP
votesFunny:
it's not perfect mind you. We'll see how it turns out.
https://steamcommunity.com/app/351970/discussions/0/490123938441506815

The configured analog stick dead-zones are kind of on the poor side. Using a wierd OEM 360 controller here.
No Playstation Icons for DualShock4 users

Input latency feels a bit on the sluggish side. You can improve this a little by forcing 1 Maximum Pre-rendered frames in the driver.

Originally included the Japanese OP song with vocals by mistake. They rushed to patch this literally day 1. So I don't think you can get it now unless someone is redistributing that file. (Which may be illegal as silly as it is. The Japanese are weird when it comes to licensing man) But seem to be taking their time with other things that are painfully obvious to everyone that should've been patched already. (Vsync for example)

As an optimization left over from the PS3 version
commentsCount:
distant animated characters/models have their framerate reduced to 20 or 15FPS (I can't remember). The same happens when there are a large amount of characters on screen at once in battle IIRC. This looks really jarring and I don't see why it wasn't removed. As this is an optimization thing where they just reduce the Refresh beyond a certain threshold. I don't see why they can't just add that as an option in the menu to disable it completely.

Some Z-Precision issues. If you see bits of textures or geometry sort of flickering back and forth between two totally different textures. It's Z-Fighting.  It doesn't even have to be very far away. Character's Hair or Eyes at a short distance can have Z-Fighting

There is secondary bloom PP that is run at a fixed scale of 512x256 or so that looks beyond ugly at high resolutions. On character models it's like a secondary drop shadow that flickers and crawls constantly. On the envronment this causes flickering.
TZFix's PP Ratio can fix it. https://steamcommunity.com/app/351970/discussions/0/490123938441506815

The Shadows setting only affects Environmental Shadows. They are 2048x2048 at max and highest LOD. But you wouldn't be able to tell that by looking because the LOD and Draw distances are super short. And the filtering is some of the worst i've seen in a modern title. The filtering solution is extremely poor. Adding to the joy of this is that Character Shadows have really good filtering. But they are insanely low resolution. Sorey gets like 128x128 and everyone else gets 64x64 IIRC.
TZFix can increase character shadow and environment shadow resolution
column16: but it can't fix the filtering of environment shadows
column17:
or the distances.
https://steamcommunity.com/app/351970/discussions/0/490123938441506815

Some textures (especially distant grass textures) seem to either have no MIP MAPs or are forced on with point filtering no matter what. This looks beyond awful
column18:
those areas just become a noisy mess of flickering 100% sharp pixels. TZFix's option to force load all MIPs doesn't solve this.
And not even brute force 16xSSAA can fix the flickering completely. (Though some SSAA+SGSSAA can).

The easiest way to see it is in the intro of the game at the top of the Ruins.
There are some bugs with Alisha's DLC. They have acknowledged these but have ignored all others.
The LOD setting seems to do absolutely nothing that anyone can see.

As for the game itself
column19: it's Tales man. I don't think i've ever NOT enjoyed a Tales game. At least not a Mothership title. Not even the original Destiny or Phantasia
column20: which are almost a bit painfully sluggish to play these days. Even if they have issues or a rough spot
column21: they are always worth playing for console RPG fans.\n\nI tend to mainly comment about technical things when it comes to ports
column22: rather than the games themselves. As I find this is a more important matter. It is 2015
column23: and there are basic standards that need to be met."

reviewText:
Long review, so skip to the bottom, for the TL:DR



First off the PC port of this is amazing, while yes it only runs at 30 fps, it has all the other settings required of a PC port.

Now, for a year I completely remained ignorant to any of the story from the japanese release, as such, going in, I knew nothing, except for the alisha scandal. I can safely say, that Zesteria is a good game. Not a great game, not a bad one.

The Xillia games were a mess of incoherent ideas with no clear focus. Decent characters, but the motivations, story turns, and overall plot were far underwhelming and dissappointing for long time Tales of players, like me. But it had wonderful set pieces.

Zesteria on the other hand, is much the same. Except with a lack of memorable set pieces. So why do I consider it better? Zesteria is a sort of first for the Tales of series, an experiment to see if certain things work, and while some do, others don't.

In order to get the full experience out of the battle system, you are forced to play one of two characters, the rest of the playable cast will be used merely for buffs. So unlike previous titles, you can't really specialize with one character that aren't the two humans. Not to mention the party formation is NEVER saved. So you cosntantly have to switch to your prefered parties after every cutscene.

The characters, while enjoyable, are lacking in growth. It feels like the game is only 2/3rds of what it should be. The villains and heroes don't get the development needed to have a concrete emotional connection on why they do what they do.

It took me 29 hours to beat the main campaign, the first time. A decent length, but many of those hours were hollow, running around, trying to find where to go next. Searching every crevice just trying to know where to do. And there's two of these sections in the story. They give you a goal, you can do them in any order, go do it.

Vesperia is my favourite in the series, followed by Graces F and Symphonia. And I am one of the few that enjoyed Symphonia 2. All four of these games set up their characters and play out their stories in a natural and understanding way.

Even Xillia 1 did this, and for the most part it worked, until they introduced a character that made no sense within the context of the world. Xillia 2, well, It had a character so good, so well thought out, that it was amazing. Then they throguh it away.

Zesteria is lacking as a Tales of Game. Just as the Xillias were. And the only reason I consider it worse then Xillia 1, is because Xillia 2 is technically the second half of that story. Xillia 1 is better then Zesteria, but only because the plot is a tiny bit more coherent then this one.

The base characters, are good. They interact with each other well, and their skits and dialogue are spot on, but the lack of growth and compentant story, feels like they're jsut going through the motions.

And that's what this comes down it. Zesteria is bandai namco, going through the motions. It's a technical marvel at the technology for creating a battlefield from the terrain, but that's where it seems most of their efforts were laid.

There is a god awful lack of extra content. There is no hot springs side quest, no cooking challenge.

And what I cannot forgive, is that some side quests are locked off if you proceed with the story too much. Making them increable hard to complete without prior knowledge of when they're safe to complete.

Now. I've complained for a few paragraphs of why this game is lackluster, but it despite all this, Zesteria is a good game. My eyes as a Tales of fan, may be blind to the needs of a new player, and it's a solid game. I whole heartedly recommend it.

But there are better Tales of Games. Symphonia comes out next year, and it's a much better, more solid experience of a game.



TL:DR

A technical marvel as an experiment on Tales of technology. The story and charcters are lacking in  meaningful development, with a plot that contradicts itself.

The combat is fun, and later on deep with layers.

Recommended for the combat, but not the story.


Edit: With a few months of reflection on my feelings for this game, I don't recommend it. Not going to do into detail about it.

reviewText:
Update after beating game:

Great Tales game. Characters development was ok, although I think they could have expended more like the other Tales game do. The plot is straight forward. Chosen inocent boy grows strong to save the world... No plot twist no nothing. You meet the main antagonist early on and you try to get stronger to defeat him. The main story isnt that bad but it falls a little flat.There are a lot of side quests and are fun but the loot isnt that mehh.

Leveling up is kind of weird. It is either grind millions of boring minions or fight mini-bosses who can 1hit or combo you down instantly (Although most of them have obvious attack animation). Equipments menu is weird and have confusing bonuses but you dont need to figure it out how it works. I beat the game with picking random equipments.

Voice dubs is great and it has an option of japanese voice which duhh is always great. Dialogs are well written with a lot of jokes between the characters. Graphics are good and the game barely has any lag. Dont let the 30fps scare you.

I still have the ex- dungeon and the Alishia dlc to finish

reviewText:
This review is for those of you who are either already a Tales of" fan or a jrpg fan

For Jrpg fans:
The "Tales of" series is comprised of isolated mothership titles like Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest (eg. Final Fantasy VII has nothing to do with Final Fantasy XIII but XIII-2 is related to XIII) so you can easily get into this game without playing previous entries. The "Tales of" series isn't well known for their stories in fact I find them all to be pretty weak but one of the strong points is the characters in each story and how they interact with on another
date: what they do on their adventure
recommended:
and their overall chemistry is entertaining. The anime cliches can be a turn off for some and unbearable for others but if you can look past that the "Tales of" series offers fun gameplay and is the major reason I became a fan. All the games aren't your traditional turn based rpg game but rather real time "fighter" in which you control a character and attack doing normal attacks and specials to create combos.
This time around in Tales of Zestiria you find yourself fighting on a 3d plane similar to recent entries in the series however to cut down on load times instead of encountering a monster and getting put onto a battle area you instead fight on the overworld map itself fighting from wide open planes to narrow corridors with obstacles here and there every now and then. Overall I think Tales of Zestiria is an ok entry into the series and is a nice little title to get a taste of what "Tales of" has to offer but there are older titles I would highly recommend in its place.

For "Tales of" fans:
Its not PS3 Vesperia or DC Destiny"

reviewText:
Starting out it's reminding me of a mix between Tales of Graces / Tales of Abyss nostalgia with the combat artes and titles.  If you're a fan of the tales series it seems to be more of the same.  I expect the same tropes and new twists on some things.

The skits are a return to Tales of Graces with full character models instead of the usual boxed heads.  The combat is focused more on the main protganist with the other characters able to enhance him better (without spoiling too much of the plot).  It is an interesting mechanic.  Xillia 2 locked Luger in place for the entire game (allowing you to play anyone but he had to stay in the party of four).  In Zestiria while you can control any character you choose (just like most other tales series) it's in your best interest to stick with the main protagnist as you add more members to your crew.  Additionally you have to have a human in control and there are other limiting factors to potential party make-up.  I'm taking a wait-and-see" on how much this ends up bothering me.

I haven't had any issues with the PC port and have been using my PS3 controller with no issues.  I also switched to the keyboard/mouse controls for a little bit and those worked fine as well.  English voice acting is also well done.

The equipment/crafting portion of the game seems to be a bit more convoluted then it needs to be
date:
but I think as time wanes on I'll figure out my way around it.  Also the addition of being able to slot things into the zone (eventually this happens to avoid spoilers) that level up the monsters might give the player control to keep any zone relevant to your level.

I will say that the motley crew didn't start to round out really well (even skit wise) until Edna came along for me.  So if you're finding the crew to be a bit dull or not your cup of tea... tough it out until her.

I look forward to losing more time to this game!"

reviewText:
Just a quick note on port as I play. So far seems decent, better than most of the ports of recent times.

That said there are some issues I find annoying, some will be fixed, some won't.

Thankfully keyboard/mouse work, and they actually play overall smoothly and well. Although I have a controller, I am thinking of not bothering with this title, as I do like the feel of K/M in it. That said there are some issues.

Most problematic is that instead of actually taking a good look at the UI and figuring out a decent control scheme, they just went for the brute force approach. Notably it does have reasonable mouse driven functions. However when using the keyboard every option is mapped to varying keys, in no logical way. Plenty of options could have been reduced to a single common set of keys, but aren't. In this sense keyboard layout for game menus is horrendous. It does thankfully display the keys to use at all times, but it is still annoying given it uses the full spread of the keyboard, when it is not a keyboard only game.

Apart from that I would recommend to save often. There are currently some game breaking bugs with no way out, so if you get trapped in one without a recent save, arrrrrrrrggggghhh... One I just experienced was where on opening the merchant sell screen some key bindings failed. So that although I could sell stuff, I couldn't exit the screen and get back to the game. Who would have known a merchant was the final invulnerable boss.

On the graphics side I have had no particular problems apart from reasonably bad screen-tearing which is fixable. The game has otherwise run fine and smooth at maximum on my 750ti.

reviewText:
if you like J-RPG's then this is a must buy. i have not put much time into it yet but i know, like with many of the other Tales of games, before im done, i will have more then 100 hours in.
now then, what makes this good?

for one, this is a really solid PC port. you can alter the resolution, alter the grapics a little by changing things like draw distance and some other stuff(didn't really look at them too long). you can play with a contoller(360 and even PS3 if you have motion joy) and customise the buttons.

the game its self is quite different from the other Tales of games, for one, there is no transition screen when you enter battles; once you touch an enemy, the battle will start(after the characters move into place and the extra mobs spawn in), and the combat system is similar to Tales of Graces in your basic attacks(known as Martial artes in game) work like a combo system; holding a direction while pressing the button will do a different attack depending on what direction you are holding(but you have to unlock them), and instead of the combo points that Graces and Xilla had, you have a meter that is similar but if it runs out, you will be unable to attack for a short time. it fills up if you idle or block attacks.

the story... well, not very far in but it seems like its nothing really special, but when it comes to Tales of games, its the characters that make it great, and i have seen a few of the party members so far and i find them enjoyable.

the world itself is quite nice looking as well. on top of battles not having loading transitions, several cutscenes dont have pesky transions between them, so you can get into action quite swiftly.

the Voice acting is good in my opinion, some of the VA's are people i have heard before and i enjoyed them. some people may be quick to say they suck, but i have heard terrible VA before(ever play Samurai Legend Musashi on the PS2 before? and who doesn't remember Resident Evil on the Playstation?), so to me, this is good.

Overall, if you are a fan of the Tales of games or J-RPG's in general, this is a must buy. the story is not going to be mind blowing but the gameplay is where the game shines bightest. the Tales of games never really had great storys to them, but with each new Tales of title, they take the battle systems and tweek them to make each game feel different, and try to have a good cast of characters to make the game stand out from the other games.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Tremendously well optimised JRPG game from a long running series. Runs great on my shitbox laptop. Visuals are crisp, Japanese voice acting is solid, and although I am only 4-5 hours in, the stage is set and the story is beginning to build nicely.

Add to that a battle and ability system that has the potential for a large ammount of versatility and, thus far, this becomes a game that would belong in any collection, and an absolute staple of a JRPG one.

9/10 so far, with a point docked for some truly ridiculous skits in the DLC. Damned Weeaboos.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A Truly excellent JRPG!

Crisp visuals, soaring music score, engaging battle-system, intricate menues and plenty of open spaces to explore and discover secrets and Skits (small lore expositions or character conversations).

Running flawlessly here, even though some have reported crashes and/or control issues. Setting Vsynch in Nvidia/Amd control panels works perfectly. Xbox One controller works without issues. I did start it up and then quit and restart just to ensure it would run fine.

There is plenty of difficulty settings (Tried Moderate but it was a bit tough and went back to Normal) and alot of other nice options like subtitles on/off, long or normal time-windows for performing combos, satisfactory Graphics options and more.

It runs at a constant 30 FPS without stuttering or framerate-drops I've found and the steam overlay works fine with it. There is a quick-save feature so it's not a drudge trying to find a save location when you need to leave the game in a hurry.

The level of depth and care put into this game is a breath of fresh air compared to some other games out recently.

10/10!!

If you're a fan of The series, you'll love it.

10/23/2015 ------- Verdict: Recommended
Second Review:
After putting 10+ hours into the game i have a better understanding of the game. a few things have bugged me like when i save the game the game not saving correctly requiring me to go back to previous save data and making me redo some of the game. after i exit a menu the camera slingshots to where your mouse was, which can be annoying. Also when you open a point of detection you have to hit enter intead of just clicking a mouse button, which would be so much easier.
The story is also very good, but lacking in certain areas. What i think is the main villian has a weird setup, and has basically no interaction with Sorey and Co.
Overall, i would give this game an 8.5 out of 10 because the graphics and art style are amazing, the battle is awesome, and the overall gameplay is pretty good.

Will uodate again when i beat the story.

reviewText:
Well I will say for start almost 11hrs stright in the game an had zero problems with the game.

I for one am really enjoying the story an game play of the game, unlike most games to play these days that lack that joy of what rpgs use to have, this has a rich world to explore with a good story an characters.

The game play is great, its action base meaning your actions in battle can cost you if you do use the wrong moves that will leave you open for stats effects such as stuns an so on, also there is blocking, dodging back foward side to side, doing the wrong thing will hurt.

Also the item/skill custom set up is really well done.

Its not offtend I these days write about a great game cause theres not that many, but if your in need of a great rpg with lots of hours of play an story then this is a game for you.
You will also get a laugh out of it ever now an then with the show they put on here an there with there wise cracks.

reviewText:
As I'm only 30 minutes in, this review will be a basic impression of the port itself.

Overall, it's relatively solid for a Japanese dev. It's got a good range of resolution options, even going up to 1440p for my monitor. Preset graphics selections, FXAA support, draw distance, and a few other things to modify for graphics on top of that. It runs smoothly without any signs of stutters or crashing.

The biggest caveat for some would be the ugly textures in places and 30 FPS lock. However, I'm able to forgive them as it's a port of a PS3 game.  Allowing higher than 30 FPS would have broken the combat system, according to the developers.

Still, hopefully with this game successful, they'll see PC as not a place to port, but as a primary release for future Tales games. And maybe those games will be designed around 60 FPS from the get go.

For the game itself, I can't judge. Only 30 minutes in. But so far, it seems to bring the standard Tales flavour, with its own unique charm.  If you love Tales games, you'll love this game.

EDIT: After 3 hours of playing today, I've experienced a few graphical issues. Screen tearing and flickering happens extremely rarely, but it's noticeable when it does. However, this happaned maybe once an hour.

The battle camera can also be an issue: But only in the specific instance of battle starting while you're in a cramped area (like a doorway).

Still, these two problems are not nearly enough for me to not recommend it. In those 3 hours, most of my experience was good. The battle system is deep, and a good flow of tutorials and new mechanics means that it won't get stale for awhile - even once they stop I'll still have a lot to learn.

reviewText: After about an hour of gameplay, I can say that this is a great port. While the framerate is locked at 30fps, it's really not a major issue yet. I have not experienced any dips in framerate or performance issues aside from camera issues when you get into an awkward spot in a battle. There was also a little screentearing, which for me was fixed by turning Vsync on. The soundtrack is some of the best I've heard from a tales game and the graphics are gorgeous. I was wandering around in the beginning area when I saw a huge mountaious ruin in the distance above the clouds. Absolutely beautiful. It's nice to return to a medeival style setting after Xillia 1 and 2.  Characters seem intriguing so far as does the story. If you love Tales games, by all means pick this up!

reviewText:
This is a Tales Game. You know what that means. You're in it for the characters and skits and the awesome combat, not necessarily the super fantastic plot - it's JRPG cliche, that's just part of the fun.

But, I'm shocked, shocked, that on launch I was able to run it with 4K resolution, Japanese Audio, XB1 controller, set up a bunch of custom stuff, and it just actually WORKS. That is completely unheard of for a PC port on Steam.

Oh yes, and you absolutely must have a gamepad for these games. Don't bother otherwise.

It's working great at launch, so thumbs up for this high quality port!
