I for one am really enjoying the story an game play of the game, unlike most games to play these days that lack that joy of what rpgs use to have, this has a rich world to explore with a good story an characters.

The game play is great, its action base meaning your actions in battle can cost you if you do use the wrong moves that will leave you open for stats effects such as stuns an so on, also there is blocking, dodging back foward side to side, doing the wrong thing will hurt.

Also the item/skill custom set up is really well done.

Its not offtend I these days write about a great game cause theres not that many, but if your in need of a great rpg with lots of hours of play an story then this is a game for you.
You will also get a laugh out of it ever now an then with the show they put on here an there with there wise cracks.

reviewText:
So far so good... I loved the old Tales francise and this game doesn't disapoint the kid inside me... movement around the map is smooth controls handle properly( Xbox controller). Voice overs are excellently done, kinda cheesy but welcomed. I am sure this is a ps3 port and I saw this on steam and could care less I was more excited the tales games are coming to PC.

If you like JRPG's  and looking for a game to sink 30+ hours into this would be the way to go. My only problem is the battle system starting off it's just mashing the B button and hope for the best... The old style tales games had more flow to them... I am only a couple hours in and I haven't done much yet so I can't comment on the FULL combat system.

Overall 8\10 so far.

reviewText:
As a fan of the series I'll try to keep my analysis so far as critical as possible.

Pros:
Combat is exceptionally good, best in the series and one of the funnest jrpg combat systems to experience.
The open freedom of the game is really nice, and the way they keep plot based area's out of your way is really smart.
Customisation of the world through lord of the land is REALLY cool, essentially modifying how areas work.
Characters are well planned and interesting.
Story is amazing and awesome.
Ufotable anime cutscenes are awesome
Brilliant Dialouge
Story is really good! :3

Cons
30fps limit, in future games Bamco please deal with this <3

Funny Story:
On final boss, don't accidently enable the skill that halves all your damage and then spend a week ♥♥♥♥♥ing why you can't beat the final boss, only to find out the mistake you've made... you looks silly.

reviewText:
Dear Bandai Namco Entertainment of Americaz,

This iz my sincere review of Talez of Zestiria for both PlayStation 4 and the Personal Computer. The first thing I would like to congratulate the developer teamz on, iz being able to deliverz a solid PC port of a Talez game. It haz great controlz, and graphical settingz (though it would've been nice if it had Fullscreen Borderless.) However, there are some thingz I would like to point outz that have given me some annoyance or troublez. The first of which being that the game has no minigamez, at allz. When I camez to Katz Korner, I was expecting at least one minigame or something, but I waz saddened to find nothingz. Gone are the dayz of being able to play Talez of DB on Talez of the Abyss, and limited to only listening to an epic cat songz, re-watching Skitz, Re-watching anime cutscenz and beating up a Toitlez for the good of making a point. This isn't the only issue I have thoughz, I'd like to point out that the game'z new equipment direction iz a bit strange, giving only HP on orbz obtainment, or via Sage, is a bit annoying, and making levelz practically meaningless iz even more so for casual playerz of the franchize.

Furthermorez, the game'z story is a bit lack-lusterz in comparison to prior talez gamez, and seemz to be slightly rushed. The game also copiez a lot of the story designz from a game known as Legend of Legaia, and I'll admit, I preferred that game more than this one. Even after all that, I did get a healthyz 45+ Hourz out of it on PS4 before pushing the game to itz limitz by forcing everyone'z statz to maximum on PC, this caused the game to be shortened to about 20 hourz or less, far less if you just skipz all the cutscenez. While I admitz, Talez of the Abyss is the longest Talez game title in the seriez, it would be nice if we got something on that scale again in the futurez. I really liked how Talez of the Abyss was able to make uz think there waz a final boss coming upz, but then it waz like Nopez
recommended: this iz only aboutz 1/3 the gamez." I hopez you will readz these wordz with utmost seriousness. While It lookz likez this iz a silly response
hoursPlayed: this iz a serious review of the gamez.\n\nSincerelyz
voteText: \nIan Carlsonz\nMadisonz Wizconsinz
helpfulPercent: USA\n\nP.S: Toitlez
votesHelpful: Katz and Cowz for life. Alsoz
votesTotal: do considerz a more darkz talez in the futurez
votesFunny: one wherez the worldz is destroyedz like Final Fantasyz Six (Threez in Japanz.) Or Likez Wildz ARMz.\n\nOh alsoz
commentsCount: I only reccommendz this game if youz want to supportz the developmentz of more Talez gamez for PC. Otherwisez
column16: get it on PlayStation 4."

reviewText:
Tales of zestiria is about a sexy tall anime dude named Sorey, that have becomed the Sheperd and will destroy the lord of Calamity. Now the pros and cons!

Pros:
Combat is tactical, fun and intense.
The characters have great personalities.
The story is really good!
The art style is beautiful
Actually good English dub!
A lot of things to explore.
A lot of side things to do. Like bonus bosses and dungeons.

Cons:
Camera angles in combat is not the best and can get frustrating at times.
Too many enemies! When you are just doing a dungeon, there are legit enemies 2 seconds away from each other in each room.
Too many un answered questions.
The last 10 hours was rushed! I experienced lag spikes, animation glitches and issues.

Conclusion!!
The game is lots of fun from start to end. The story is really enjoyable, so is the gameplay and it is really pretty to look at!

reviewText: I love this game. I've played a lot of tales games and this game plays a bit differently. The combat and battle encounters feel nice and a bit more simplified than other tales combat systems, which isn't to say it's bad. The combat encounters have no load times, attacks are done in a flow chart for comboing and there are different elements. Your stats and passive abilities come from your equiptment which you can combine to make better equiptment etc. Your artes are unlocked from your titles and leveling up. Dungeons can get boring. The story is what kept me playing, I really enjoyed it. On the surface it seems like a happy and fun game but then the story's tone dramatically changes dark unexpectedly/randomly, which I didn't mind too much. The tone varies a lot at times. It didn't exactly feel too forced and they were able to tie in the dramatic dark tone changes in the story. The unexpected reveals are what kept me thinking about the game long after I beat it, especially the entire ending/aftercredits. Even the little things in the game's story like the subtle characters interactions with one another kept me thinking about it. I figured the english voice actors would be mediocre  and sound annoying so I switched to japanese. The game was overall a lot of fun and the characters were great. I feel like a few things might have been/were lost in translation but I'm okay with that because I enjoyed the game and got what I wanted out of it. 8/10

reviewText:
Update after beating game:

Great Tales game. Characters development was ok, although I think they could have expended more like the other Tales game do. The plot is straight forward. Chosen inocent boy grows strong to save the world... No plot twist no nothing. You meet the main antagonist early on and you try to get stronger to defeat him. The main story isnt that bad but it falls a little flat.There are a lot of side quests and are fun but the loot isnt that mehh.

Leveling up is kind of weird. It is either grind millions of boring minions or fight mini-bosses who can 1hit or combo you down instantly (Although most of them have obvious attack animation). Equipments menu is weird and have confusing bonuses but you dont need to figure it out how it works. I beat the game with picking random equipments.

Voice dubs is great and it has an option of japanese voice which duhh is always great. Dialogs are well written with a lot of jokes between the characters. Graphics are good and the game barely has any lag. Dont let the 30fps scare you.

I still have the ex- dungeon and the Alishia dlc to finish

reviewText:
Overall one of the best JRPG I have ever played. This is my first tittle in the series so I do not carry the fan-bias of the series. In clarity the last time I enjoyed a JRPG this much was when I played Legend of the Dragoon back on PS1 funny cause in both the  wind element dude dies. =)


The story was a lot of fun and the NPC's have a lot of character and interaction with one another and there are a few plot twists which help keep you pumped for what is coming up next. I even really enjoyed some of the commedy after each fight as your comrads talk to eachother.

Unlike Most JRPG the game features an action oriented combat system, it starts off very slow in the begining of the game however it builds up in complexity quickly after you begin to pick up skills and battle techniques. To the extent where you may spend some time trying to figure out the deep mechanics in this game as they start to get thrown at you very quickly at an overwealming rate especially if you are new to the series.

There are a few porting technical issues the game has common issue with Bandai however a great modding community has a easy to install fix that makes it run well.

This is one of the few JRPG I have ever put this much time into and would recommend anyone interested in a fun story, challenging combat system and enjoys high replayability to try out.

reviewText: Played over six Tales games, so I felt like I knew what I was getting into, really excited to play co-op with my girlfriend, as neither of us much liked Dawn of the New World. We quit pretty friggin soon, because the first 4 battles made it clear, the camera will center on your enemy target and swivel so you can't see yourself or your enemy. Fighting with your camera stick is as unintuitive as it could possibly be, because I literally cannot make it include both of our characters at the same time. Really hard to enjoy an action rpg when you cannot view your character during the fight, let alone figure out how to walk into where the camera is looking.\n\nI very well might continue the game one day, but honestly I don't have a work-around for such a basic function in a game, and it made it so innane, I just can't imagine forcing myself to deal with it.

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria is the first attempt at a full 3D combat system by the Tales series and it largely falls flat. The story is what you expect in a typical series, but there's numerous problems with the game and you'd think that a company that has been making these types of RPGs for nearly 20 years would be learning from their mistakes. First and foremost are the controls. They haven't been adopted to fit the 3D style. Holding down now often means holding back, and your character runs backwards when you try to use down + attack or down + arte. Another problem with the game is that you only have 2 human characters to use at a time. One human character can only be partnered up with one of the Seraphs, spirit like beings that only some people can see. The result is that even though you have four characters in your party, you can only use two. I also hope you don't get too attached to the heroine of the game because she gets replaced halfway through.

A serious issue I had with the game is the fact that Lailah is somehow bound to not speak about the past. The emphasis of learning your own answer through a journey is important, but the fact that she withholds crucial information throughout the game makes me feel like everyone is an idiot.

Another problem with the game is that the enemies have huge amounts of super armor and invincibility frames. Super armor is when the enemy breaks your combo and become immune to stun and knockbacks for a period of time. Invincibility is when they are immune to all damage while they are performing their attack. This occurs far too frequently in the game and many enemies activate it after a fixed number of hits, automatically ending your combo, even if they are airborne at the moment. Ironically, many of your character's powered up transformations hit very rapidly and very quickly, allowing you to make high hit combos. The problem is that this automatically triggers the enemy's auto response that makes them invincibile, largely making this feature useless.

There are some massive changes in this game compared to the other ones. Levels mean nothing in this game as it only gives you additional HP and the ability to equip more Skills (you can get more of those points from finding stupid monuments in the game than leveling up though). Stats are acquired from new equipment and killing bosses, not from leveling up. They also changed Grades and Skills to be unlocked by acquiring achievements. There are hints as to what you need to do to unlock them, but it quickly becomes something tedious. For the first time there is also no dedicated healer. Instead, everyone has a bunch of small heals, nothing that is meant for the entire party. Compared to the previous installments of Tales of Xillia and Tales of Xillia 2, this game has a worse story and worse gameplay.

The only good thing about buying this game was that I received Tales of Symphonia for free because I pre-ordered a terrible game. Hopefully Tales of Bestiria will improve on the combat and the story.

reviewText:
I've just recently finished the game, and as a fan of the Tales series, I'm sad to say I cannot reccomend Zestiria.

For reference, previous Tales games I've played are Phantasia, Symphonia, Symphonia 2: Gotta Catch'em All, Vesperia, and Abyss.

The dungeons are bland and samey, the side-quests are lackluster, there's very little in the way of end-game content and a notable absence of super bosses, and my major gripe with the whole experience? The combat system is awful from a Tales standpoint.

Coming from other Tales games, I recall the combat being fluid, and all about stringing together long combos. It was simplistic, but exciting. While playing Vesperia, I found myself performing long 100+ hit combos from somewhere near the midpoint in the game, and capping the whole thing off with a Mystic Art. The battle system was simple enough to pick up and learn that you could start exploring the kinds of Arte combos available to you quickly.

Zestiria's combat is anything but simple. Attacks have been split into three categories. Martial Artes (your basic attacks), Hidden Artes (Your Sonic Thrusts and your Demon Fangs), and Seraphic Artes (Spells.) These have been given a rock, paper, scissors style interaction. Martial Artes interrupt spells, Spells cast faster when struck by Hidden Artes, and Hidden Artes cannot be interrupted by Martial Artes. This isn't so bad, except for one glaring fact. This interaction is rarely relevant.

There are five elements in the game. Physical, Fire, Wind, Water, and Earth. The vast majority of enemies are resistant to most of these. If it's resistant, it takes very little damage and doesn't stagger regardless of what Arte you use. To make this worse, most of your attacks are now imbued with elements from the start, so you have to pick your combos based on what will deal damage, rather than what you think will be fun.

This cuts out some of the freedom to build your own fighting style that was present in past Tales games. But this is just the beginning of Tales of No Fun Allowed."

You can only have 4 party members at a time. Two of them are permanently set. Sorey
date: and his human partner. Despite being perfectly capable of doing things normally
recommended: your other 4 party members require a 1/1 human/seraph ratio to participate in fights. So gone is the ability to choose 2 half of your party based on personal preference and combat style.\n\nBut wait
hoursPlayed: there's more! The four other party members each correspond with one of the four non-physical elements! I remind you
voteText: most enemies resist all but one or two elements
helpfulPercent: so you'll be forced to pick and choose which of those members to include in the party based of their element. Again
votesHelpful: removing yet another element of choice from you.\n\nSo the game already goes out of its way to force your hand in choosing specific parties of characters throughout the game
votesTotal: but what else is wrong with the battle system? Surely it's still a classic example of Tales gameplay
votesFunny: right? Nope.\n\nEnjoy your Over The Shoulder camera angle and full 3D combat arenas. In older Tales games
commentsCount: battles were mostly fought on a linear plane. You frequently had the option to move yourself around the battlefield
column16: but the actual combat tended to take place in a straight line. Left to right. With the changes
column17:
I find a lot of my attacks just straight up missing. Sword cuts flying off into the ether and accomplishing nothing.

And I've saved the worst for last: The SC system.

In previous Tales games
column18: mashing the attack button was a free action. It cost nothing. In Zestiria
column19: that attack costs SC. SC replaces mana in this game
column20: but where your mana pool could be increased in past games
column21: your SC bar is permanently set at 100. And some of your Artes cost 25+ SC to use. You see where I'm going with this?\n\nOne SC intensive combo can drain your bar entirely. Hell
column22:
there are some combos you can't even perform because it will empty your bar before it's finished. So how do you refill your bar?

You WAIT.

SC refills very quickly
column23: but the short 2 seconds where you're told "stop" by the game
column24: over and over again
column25: is infuriating. Past Tales games

column27: but this was only an issue if the fight dragged on. SC becomes a constant problem every few seconds during fights with boss enemies.\n\nYou can refill SC alternatively by blocking or dodging attacks
column28: but both of these abilities are slow to respond
column29: \n\nIn addition
column30: even if you're managing your SC well

column32: thus making them immune to a second combo even if they're in the middle of an Arte yours SHOULD in theory interrupt.\n\nThe game is
column33: in essence

the game was a slog. At every turn it felt like the game was actively preventing me from enjoying myself.

TL;DR:

The Good

reviewText:
First and foremost: if you were hoping for another Tales of Vesperia you should look elsewhere. Even without unfair comparison, Zestiria is not a great game. Thankfully the port runs smoothly and looks great (a promising sign for the future) but almost every facet of the game is disappointing.

Going for the low hanging fruit, the plot and characters are hideous anime cliches through and through. The protagonist is wide-eyed and bushy-tailed but naive and idealistic, one of the female protagonist is kind of the same but calm and royalty while the other one is kind of wild and energetic. All the seraphs are just different shades of anime: mother figure, cynical one, older realistic brother figure, dark mysterious dude. Really tiring and boring garbage.

Combat is frankly a pain in the ♥♥♥. Without barfing a dissertation onto you, there are three different types of attacks that break each other in a rock-scissor-paper fashion which is often obnoxious to put to any use. Combat often felt like a cluster♥♥♥♥ of getting the right combo off at the right time and praying the enemy didn't start channelling an attack that opposed yours. Bosses require that you armatise with their elemental weakness in mind otherwise you will straight up get stomped every time.

Equipment sucks as well. No learning neat abilities or artes, they just have various stat boosts and other assorted passives. You can only fuse the same pieces of equipment to produce higher leveled versions of that (e.g. vest + vest = vest +2!) and the boosts, of which there can only be a max of four, interact to make new stat boosts. This interaction further depends on whether the equipment is mastered or not either. Mastering equipment does nothing outside of fusion. It's pretty tedious and extremely bad.

So yeah, there is little to really like about Tales of Zestiria. I very stupidly tried to push myself through this game and at 35 hours I realised I still couldn't see the end in sight and was completely sick of every single aspect.

TL;DR? This isn't Tales of Vesperia.

reviewText:
Tales on Steam! What a day to be alive.

As a longtime Tales fan, I'm glad to see Tales of Zestiria on this platform. It has many features that fans of the series like me can appreciate, such as dual audio support (Japanese voices!), and full controller support (how would playing this on keyboard and mouse even work?). Don't forget steam trading cards, who can forget those valuable gems?

There are some potential drawbacks though. The dreaded 30fps cap exists here, and I can safely say it has had no negative impact on my experience so far. Could my computer run a PS3 port at 60fps? Probably. Will someone remove that cap eventually? Most likely. Is it a big deal? Not at all. This game also has no online co-op or anything. I personally figured that was given and didn't expect it, but I saw a negative review mention it so I figured I'd throw it in here.

The game itself plays like any tales fan would expect it to, combat is action based and you bump into (or smack) enemies on the overworld to start battles. A new feature is that the battles actually take place on the overworld, which means no loading times and immediate action. That's pretty swell. Skits make their return, and goofy character interaction between the more serious plot elements is abundant.

Tales of Zestiria has met all of my expectations so far, and I look forward to delving deeper into it. I hope any tales fan reading this does too! This game looks to be a good entry point for anyone wanting to try out the series as well, so give it a shot everyone and anyone!

reviewText:
(My review so far on the game)
I still can't believe another great JRPG arrived on PC. I can't believe it! I played another 2 hours or so (with breaks to play Cities skyline and Battlefield Hardline on my Xbox) and it's working perfectly fine with a few ploblems in game. Other than that, I'm loving it!

The character developments (Sorey's development especially), The fighting scenes especially that Fox guy, the scenery, EVERYTHING! The opening in the eng version was great too (Pumped up!!). There are plenty of things to do (I haven't reach that part yet) Which doesn't make you feel bored

However, there are some downsides with the game at the moment as many of you know.
I've noticed in some scenes that whenever a character speaks, they take a little longer to speak like in other games i play. This also goes for movement as well. It's just.....weird. It just feels....sluggish and they may need to improve on that
The camera. Yep. I have to complain about this. Especially in battle. Switching camera types doesn't help at all (I use Xbox one Controller but the game reads it as Xbox 360).
I just can't trust the quick save at all. Sometimes it works somethings it doesn't.
It can get boring really quickly if you are someone like me who prefers exciting things. (I get bored real easily. Just look at my list.
FPS locked at 30fps isn't my problem. But apart from that, it looks amazing anyway.
I know at the moment there are issues since it just released but i recommend you get the game now as they go over these issues. I Will update as i play on for you guys.

reviewText:
Like every Tales game it's pretty much the closes thing you can get to a playable I'm the hero anime. But this time it's on PC! Who would of guessed we would see the day?

It's not a perfect port but by no means is it a bad one. Just make sure you go to your Nvidia control panel and turn on Vsync (or however you do it with AMD) because the in game option doesn't seem to do anything. Also unfortunantly the game is capped at 30fps, I'm assuming it's mostly because the game was about 95% developped as a PS3 exclusive before they randomly decided to put it on PS4 and PC (not that I'm complaining), so most of the mechanics and animation are designed around a 30fps lock so unless they pretty much rebuild the game from the ground up any higher that 30 will just break the game. Good job Jap devs..

But if you can look past that and you love to play as a hero that has a sword and powers and stuff and has a very JRPG/Anime way of doing things you'll probably enjoy the game. Also Troppy Animoo stuff.


[EDIT] Also it's the first time I booted a game up and it's like: Wow senpai, your PC is pretty good why are you only playing in 1080p? I'll just downsample from a higher rez without you having to do anything, I know you'll enjoy it. I was pleasantly surprized, especially because it's a Bandai Namco port.

reviewText: I've been a true blue Tales fan since I popped a Symphonia disc into my Gamecube and encountered what may just be my favorite RPG of all time. None of the Tales games that cane afterwards however, regardless of how good they were themeselves (yes Xillia, I'm lookinh at  you), have given off the same charm that symphonia did. Symphonia made me tear up. Symphonia made me feel very attatched to my companians. Symphonia did what so many other RPG's have attempted to do, flawlessly.\nBut this isn't a review about Symphonia. This is a review on what seems to be the closest thing to reliving that experience I did so long ago. I have been waiting for this game to release for so long now. The protagonis is nongeneric. The story is so into depth you can tell how much time and effort was put into it in the very few minutes you play it. The environment is rich and filled with detail. Even the enemies are fun to fight because they look so darn nice! Having said that, I must admit a few minutes into gameplay before my first encounter I  thought, Wow spider webs. Spiders are so original"
date: but then later encountering the spider my jaw dropped. they managed to actually put some originality behind such a cliche enemy.\nThe one thing that doesn't compare to Symphonia is the coive acting. Not to say Symphonia had the greatest voice acting ever
recommended: but if you decide to buy this game about 2 minutes into gameplay I'm sure you'll realize exactly why I had a good laugh at it. Sometimes the voices are emotionless leaving a bland feeling of discomfort and confusion as to how exactly the character is feeling. Think of the notorious film "The Room" to get an idea of what I mean.\nAll in all? This is bound to be one of the best

reviewText: Personally, I believe this game exceeded my expatations. The graphics are Extordinary, the 30 fps lock isn't that bad. (As a shrine maiden, I can't even tell the difference between 60 and 30. Looks the same.) Otherwise, the gameplay and the story so far are all interesting. In my opinion its one of the better Tales i've played besides Symphonia. (<3). The story overall is interesting and the scenary and details are amazing as well especially for being the first tales game on steam and pc. I love all the tales game, and its just that passion that I cannot see any dislikes about it so far. But even if there was one, I would probably ignore it and only see the pros. Otherwise, its like all the other tales games in terms of fighting and exploring area's. Overall it is a great game, and I reccomended those who love the tales series, or Jrpg's games to give it a try! You won't be dissapointed (After you get past the many bugs that is..;;)

reviewText:
Outside some minor screen tearing on my (got a Nvidia 770M GTX) I have been really enjoying the game.  So far only put about 5 hours into the game. It plays very smooth and has been a great game.  Only thing outside of the screen tearing that I have had has been a bug during combat were I have gotten stuf not doing damage nor recieving damage from enemies, but it isn't really a bug so much as user error on my part for not realizing I am stuck in certain tutorials long after being well into the game.

The game is huge, 5 hours in and I am still getting tutorials and still often haven't a clue what I am doing and I love that about the game.  I can see that 50 hours into the game I will still be learning and most likely 100 hours into it I will just be getting the hang of the gameplay.  This isn't a 10 hour game and that makes me very happy.

The plot is normal for a JRPG.  But the Anime cut-scenes are great and the over all quality is awesome.   I am super digging the game.  So far is is more than worth the money spent for sure.

reviewText:
So it has a 30 fps lock- Does that really make a difference? Frankly I don't care and its been stated enough at this point.

if this is your first tales game please don't even think for a moment that the story is going to be good. In fact they introduce possibly the most important mechanic in the game in a mundane battle with no build up and try to make it out as an emotional battle scene- and fail miserably.

This isn't to say the story is complete rubbish- its a JRPG for heavens sake it can use almost as many cliches as it wants, though i must say they didn't resort to 'chosen one' here, rather 'one who chose' if that makes any sense.

The battle- Its a tales game! of course its good!

the controls- By far the weakest point of the game is using a generic controller. if you have a PC compatible xbox controller it will make your life a whole lot easier. if not, your going to have to set up each individual button to make sure you don't get lost.

another thing about generic controllers and this game is that some buttons think they are the same, thus meaning you have one less button.

Despite all this you will eventually configure everything to your liking and figure out how character changing works (You need to go into the in battle item/arts menu and press the button you assigned. Don't see why to bother outside of battle.)

Overall i'd say its not got the best story, even for a tales game, but the things that make tales games good- their selling points: Skits and awesome combat are still strong... If you can get the skits button to work.

If you don't have an Xbox controller I'd say use the keyboard, in fact the keyboard might even be BETTER.

reviewText:
I notice people usually copy paste reviews from the PS3 title in Japan in order to make their reviews seem a whole lot faster. As if, only 3 hours into the game, it seems like they are already halfway through it. I am not going to write a review on this game since so many are already out. However, I will say this about the PC port.

I have not played the PS3 version of this game, but I assume it to be mostly the same. The developers never promised 60 fps in this game, but even at 30 it still looks amazing. There are some bugs of course, but they are easily solvable. Even on my craptop, this game runs at 30 FPS the entire time, even while the game still looks good!

I commend the developers and whoever made this port possible, please do this more, so far this is an amzing game and I hope to play more 'Tales' titles on PC in the future!

reviewText:
I have been a fan of the series since Tales of Symphonia and this one is far form a let down. I am really enjoying the newly seamless transitions from cutscene/combat to overworld. I was on the other hand dissapointed by the intro. The music was god awful and repetitive, and there was NO SINGING Q.Q

Aside from that, it's been an enjoyable experience. I like that the game doesnt use TP, and really love that there is Japanese/English options for VA. (I prefer Japanese). So far I'm not too impressed with the storyline, but I have plenty more to go before I can be settled on that.

I'm also super hyped for the Tales of Symphonia PC port next year.

Kudos to you all at Bandai/Namco!

reviewText:
Tales of Zestiria sits on my mind oddly. First and foremost before you read this reveiw I am going to openly admit that I have never played a Tales game before and that this was basically the best title to start the series with since I only have a 360 and my PC. So longtime fans of this series that for whatever reason are reading this reveiw keep in mind that i'm completely new to this series.

TL;DR VERSION AT THE BOTTOM.

I'll go into gameplay and mechanics first and this might be lengthy so prepare:
The gameplay is honestly really fun and exciting. Not only do battles start without any loading and takes place right where you encountered the enemy (giving it really good immersion) but they also have this really hectic and fast pace feeling to them. Firstly the battle zone is surprisingly big (unless you get caught in a corner, narrow corridor or god forbid doorway) so you have a lot of room to move around to cast spells or to heal party members or to simply recouperate your SC. Now what is SC? Well it's basically the limiting factor put onto you to keep you from just steamrolling everything. You see, instead of giving you a mana bar to limit your spell casts and giving your basic attacks infinite uses they give you SC which is drained with every action you do besides blocking and running. While this might sound very annoying at first I actually think it's a brilliant system since now I can freely cast spells and combine them with my basic attacks to have insane combos. Also since even your basic attacks drain the SC they don't need to make your martial artes (basic attacks) weak or underwhelming compared to your hidden artes (basically the spells.) In fact with some characters it's actually more pleasing and satisfying using martial artes instead of hidden artes (Sorrey and Dezel). This is even more apparent when you use the armatus which is basically a superform in this game and apparently a new feature in the Tales games. When you use the Armatus two of your characters that are linked together will combine and make a stronger form that has it's own moves but has the combined stats of both previous characters. However as I said everything you do drains SC and because of this you must control how much you do in a short amount of time otherwise you'll find yourself in the middle of a group of enemies without anything to do and just take a bunch of hits.

I would go into the other mechanics but I'll sum up the gameplay and battle system as interesting and strategic since there is a lot of things you can do in a single battle to rack up some massive damage and combos. However it should be noted that there's no way to control the camera and there can be times where it seriously ♥♥♥♥s up.

The atmosphere in this game is quite lively and colorful. It has clear contrast so that's its really colorful without being too bright and annoying and this really fleshes out a lot of the areas since almost everything sticks out by itself while also blending in with the background. The towns could use a bit more work on them but ultimately still feel like they're actual towns and cities. Open feilds (my favorite areas honestly) are suprisingly big and gives you a sense of vastness and that you're actually traveling across the continent. This is enhanced even further with the draw range of the game. They really seemed to take the time to make sure that everything physical in these areas would look good both near and far which again makes it hard to tell where the wall of the area is without looking at the map which I believe is good. Dungeons however are painfully straight forward and small. You'll find yourself kinda bored and unexcited about what you have to do there when you're not fighting the mobs.

Now the chracters and story is what kind of makes this and oddball for me. On a personal level I like a few of the character Edna being my favorite closely followed by Alisha. However there are a lot of archetype characters that are pretty unamusing sadly with a few of them painfully stereotypical (I'm looking at you Dezel). While on the other hand you have characters that simply don't act accordingly to what they do (specifically Rose) and then you have Laliah who is just queer, sometimes I really like her and other times I find her annoying or stupid. This gives the party a schizophrenic feeling and gives the player obvious favortism. I always try to use Edna and Laliah as much as I can while keeping Mikleo and Dezel on standby unless I need them or they simply make the battle easier.

[SPOILERS IN THIS SECTION!!!]
As far as the story goes it's...well...it could be better honestly...a lot better actually. It's pretty stereotypical and can be summarized as a more cliche version of Ocarina of Time without the time travel and more characters which I can deal with and even enjoy since a lot the of character interactions can be funny. However one character in the game pretty much ruined the entire story for me and that's Rose. You see before you meet Rose it's implied and almost blatantly explained that only the Sheperd can use the armatus however within literally 10 minutes of interactions with Rose it's established that she can use the armatus too which really breaks the whole story. You see apparently Dezel was messing with her mind and body since she was little so that he could use her as a vessel for the armatus however this made her very easily controllable when using it and also gave her the ability to see and speak to seraphim as well. Now the biggest problem I have with this is that it makes no freaking sense on how or even why she uses the armatus. Okay maybe she does have a lot of resonance but the reason why the Sheperd can use it is because his power is linked and intertwined with another Seraphim. Not only that it's up to the human to use it in the first place so how is it possible for a seraphim to force her to use the armatus and is the reason why she can use it at all when it requires the human to say their name and to give them access to it. The explanation for her power was really weak and story breaking but going even further beyond that is that she joins the party for literally no reason whatsoever other than sure
date:
why not." and everyone just goes with it from there on.

Well that was pretty lenghty.
Ultimately I would recommend this game. I find the combat fun and exciting and it makes it a blast to grind through. The enviorment and atmosphere can be beautiful and colorful and the interactions between characters is quite charming.

TL;DR VERSION
Fun gameplay. Good graphics. Good atmosphere. Some characters are good others are bad. Story is cliche and not really good but neither is it really bad. Dungeons are too linear but feilds are great. Camera can be really stupid sometimes. I'll give this game a 7-8/10.  It could definitely use some work in a few places but the gameplay is the best part and it's really fun."

reviewText: Note: I've never played any Tales of" game before. With that said
date: I find Zestiria's action RPG approach to combat refreshing and entertaining
recommended: the storyline is straightforward and there is a lot of replay value with new game+

2 things I hate and Bamco could have patched but didn't:

1) Horrible teammate AI. I end up investing heavily in stats I would otherwise ignore in order to keep them alive. At times I might even command them to just stay to the corners of the battlefield and try to stay alive because telling them to attack is risky.

2) Horrible camera when your back is against the wall

reviewText:
Yes, it was a good game - but ONLY with the 60FPS mod that you can find in the forums (tzfix).
Do NOT play the game without it.

The story isn't that great compared to the great JRPG's of the 90', the graphics aren't that great compared to modern PS3 games, and the battle mechanics are so complicated that even after finishing the game and the DLC I couldn't understand and use all of them.

The game stuffs so many cluttered and useless information at you from the first moment you start playing, about strategies and customizing and so many other things, that I almost stopped playing. The characters aren't that interesting compared to other Tales of... games (except Edna, she's great), the expansions cost so freaking much that it's a joke, and the music isn't that good. Basically, it's just an average game.

I drop games a LOT. I get bored really easily, and when I look back at it, I didn't enjoy this game even half of what I enjoyed Tales of Symphonia on the Game Cube, or even Tales of Phantasia on the SNES, both games that I cannot play today because of how aged they are. But for some reason I just couldn't stop playing.

Maybe it was a dry time, maybe I did enjoy. The thing is, I wanted to play, and it didn't feel bad. Really, I can't explain why. Maybe this is one of those rough diamonds that are covered with dirt, but deep inside, who knows, it might be pretty good (except for the Alisha Story DLC, that is really bad and you should just watch it on Youtube).

If you like JRPG's, try it when it's on discount.

reviewText:
Edited on 10/5/2016.

I would not recommend this game. Especially as a veteran [Tales of] fan. TL;DR at the bottom.

(Fans of this game on STEAM are probably going to vote me down. Ok look. This might be the only Tales of game aside from Symphonia you've played. I understand. But I've played more than 10 titles in the franchise so I'm just speaking from that perspective. You can love the game, I just can't despite how much I want to.)

Tales of Zestiria is an alright game. It's worth about 45 hours of content on one playthrough. The game pans out like an action RPG, the plot is alright (some girls might like it a lot though), the graphics are pretty, and the gameplay is...

Well, that's what I really don't like. About 10 hours in I was only onboard for the story and acheivements. There is nothing else I think is worthwhile about this game past that. I'm sure this is highly rated on Steam, but I found the gameplay to be terrible. The story is pretty entertaining, but a couple horus of cutscenes cannot hold up the entire game for me.

The writing ToZ is just not quite up there either. It's fujoshi bait. I'm a fujoshi. But I'd rather watch someone else play this game, really.

The game tells you about this amazing world, and how there's such a rich history behind it, but we don't ever get much of a glimpse at it past the main plot. There are monuments in ancient writing scattered throughout the world, and they use it for tutorial, not world building. For 30 hours.

There are stretches of dungeons that is too big, too empty, and brain dead. The Great Camelot Bridge takes you a full 3 minutes to go through, and that's a straight line.  Tutorials are constantly telling you how to play the game even 30 hours in.

The dungeon design in this game is absolutely asinine. Since the battle system takes place EXACTLY where you run into the monsters and the battlefield is huge, the map in turn has to be obscenely huge. All you get is huge rooms and boring corridors just because they wanted to shoehorn that poorly thought out feature in. This is even worse in the Alisha DLC. $15 and two hours worse. You run through a dungeon for TWO DAMN HOURS. (Look up youtube.)

The battle itself is aggravating as well. But some people like it. I found myself fighting against the camera most of the time. The battlefield is usually so huge that you can't see enemies to your left or right. Which is trouble since the battle plays out like a game of rocket tag. If you don't defend on the higher levels, you will die. You want a messy challenge where your party members get KO'd 26 times in a single boss fight because of that? Try this, then. Of course, there's AI stupidity at play too.

The balancing here has some pretty strong MMO grinding feel to it. The padding I felt from this game is incredibly bad.

Once again, I found this to be an ok game. Playing through this made me so angry and disappointed I wish I was playing Tales of Vesperia on the console which is exponentially better than this garbage of a Tales game.

TL;DR: I consider this to be the worst Tales of title aside from Tempest due to all the poor design that went into this, and I think people should give the other Tales of a try to see what I really mean.

reviewText:
I love JRPG's and have played Tales of Symphonia and Tales of Destiny.

I struggled to find any immersion in this game's world. There were far too many pop-up tutorial/information screens (even for the most basic of mechanics like what HP is). I don't like this approach as I would much rather explore menus and discover things for myself instead of constantly feeling as though the devs thought very little of the player's intelligence.
There were some seemingly complex features and a lot of it I found unintuitive... I get the game has to teach them to the player but surely there are better ways than this immersion-breaking method.

In the short time I played I also found the dungeons and locations very static and uninteractive (and sometimes needlessly big and open). Walking through empty uninteractive room to empty uninteractive room with little to no interesting sights became quickly grinding on my experience.

On a plus side, great animated cut scenes and decent character graphics. But unfortunately I could not get into this one.

reviewText: The storyline is very cliche and stock about a chosen hero who befriends a princess, but in a twist that's not really been surprising to anyone since Ocarina Of Time she's also a badass knight who can fight with a spear. I don't really think people play JRPGs for the story as they're usually pretty stock and this one is no expection. It plays more like an action game like Kingdom Hearts, rather than turn based like Hyperdimension Neptunia.

reviewText: So far this is the best Tales game since Vesperia in my opinion. English voice actors do a good job, great music, and decent story. Is it the best port ever? No. Is is a BAD port? I wouldn't say so. The 30 fps lock may bother some, I hardly notice it. The only con for me so far is the screen tearing, which apparently is an easy fix if you force v sync, and I'm sure the little bugs will be patched soon. Japanese studios are notorious for thier really bad PC ports, and this is good in comparison to many. No, it's not perfect, but hopefully this game paves the way for more Japanese devs to bring thier games over to PC. If you are a fan of JRPGs and want to help support more of them coming to PC, I would recommend purchasing this game. It is definitely worth the money. It's a great game with some minor annoyances on PC, all in all I would heavily recommend the game for fans of the genre.

reviewText:
My review started off with a recommendation but because of the constant cheating of enemies in battle, I can't recommend it anymore. It gets worse and worse as the story progresses so my impression changed a lot over time.

The story:
Is nothing that will set your world on fire, BUT (Spoiler - kind of - incoming and I only played ~40 hours, so there's the chance I'm wrong) it has a different story than most of the other Tales games (like Symphonia, Abyss, Graces, Zillia, Hearts etc.): there are NOT two worlds competing in some way or the other with another and you are not on a journey to somehow get those worlds to coexist.
I know... that's really a change up!

The characters:
I never really liked the lead in Tales games, they are mostly boring and pretty uninteresting, sometimes even unlikeable (I'm looking at you Luke) - Lloyd being the exception - but I don't mind Sorey to be honest. So that's something! The rest of the cast is interesting and the interaction is again really funny.

Graphic and sound stuff:
Graphics are fine, but you can see, that this game was developed for the PS3, the music is in parts really damn good and never bad.

Gameplay:
The gameplay/battles feel definetely a bit dumbed down from previous entries. It incorporates the weakness/power hit system from Zillia 2 and tries to bring a bit more depth into the game by introducing the armatizing feature (combining with a seraph character of the different elements), but it removes the freedom of binding martial artes to any button and the attacks have a specific spot in the combo. Like certain attacks are always the third in a combo and so on.
I certainly miss the option to bind my 16 (or 20? has been a while) different attacks to every button I choose to and execute them whenever I want to, like in Zillia.
Only hidden artes are bindable and very limited (5 can be bound at any given time), so overall not a lot of freedom there.
Of course there's no cooking and no wonder chef... you have to buy food when you sleep in an inn.

The bad stuff:
- Little variety in your party setup: it's always 2 humans and two seraphs, but as far as I've gotten now, you only have two humans at any given time, so you can only experiment with different seraphs in your setup (4 so far)
- The camera... god damn this camera... especially in narrow hallways or near walls...
- Countless tutorials but some stuff is still confusing. Like leveling your weapons, I've still don't really get it, mainly because I can't memorize the 50 different boni and there place" in the matrix... To really make a good item you need a tutorial or a reference sheet I guess
- The game cheats... a lot. A lot of the time enemies are able to become invulnerable and stay invulnerable for easily half a minute or even more. While you are not able to stagger
date: damage or incapacitate they'll pound you down and this way you'll lose several battles or at least party member
recommended: which will instantly destroy your grade rank for the battle. It gets worse and worse as the story progresses.\nThere were several battles against bosses where I was able to keep the whole party alive up until the boss decided to stay invulnerable for half a minute and kill my party... with maybe 1000 points of health left. There is NOTHING you can do ... just die and reload.\n-the party ai: they are stupid and will die a lot
hoursPlayed:
which will cost you a lot of grades... a LOT.

Technical stuff:
The game runs great
voteText: the 60 fps patch/mod really makes battle feel smoother and the game overall is really stable. I didn't have a single crash
helpfulPercent: so that's nice."

reviewText:
Pretty embarassing entry into the Tales series. I can see why this is considered one of the worst games in the series, and I don't even give a ♥♥♥♥ about the whole Alisha/Rose fiasco (both of them are one-dimensional overused archtypes anyway). Starting with the abysmal camera that can't help but get stuck riding up a mob's ♥♥♥ during a fight so you can't see anything, this game's combat system is also complete trash.

The equipment fusion is an exercise in spreadshit simulation if you want anything decent out of it; every single dungeon in the game is big square rooms connected by big square corridors; the monster designs are embarassing (a ♥♥♥♥ing squid and a skunk, really? Almost everything is recoloured mobs not even halfway into the game?)

I'm kind of surprised I even got past the unstandable early stages of the game; just insanely slow and boring.

Huge gaping plotholes (this guy who was killing seraph villagers and shown eating people works for an assassin's guild. Well guess what? Leader of said assassin's guild joins your party later and yet the protagonist doesn't say a ♥♥♥♥ing word about him or ask her why she let something like that in her guild in the first place).

This is such a step back for the series; such a dissapointment. Its nice that its on steam but we really need the good entries in the series (Abyss and Vesperia for example).

It is a jRPG , it is a Tales game.

Speaking as someone who had played almost every single Tales game out there from Phantasia ,Abyss, Rebirth , Destiny , Destiny 2 , Destiny remake ,Symphonia , Graces F , Legendia ...etc ( beside the Tales of dungeons and spin-offs ) ,it is hard for me to recommend this game to anyone , even to diehard Tales fans.

Zestiria does has a likable Artstyle and game graphics, dated but likable .especially if you are the sort who enjoy watching Anime and playing RPG ,which is why you are checking this game out .
The character dubs are decent and since the game came with dual languages on Steam, for those who like watching their Jap-dubbed anime with English subs , this should be familiar.

Comparing to the Playstation 3 version , the graphics in the game have also received a slight upgrades and the characters looks a lot sharper , the game environment and background is cleaner " . It is however

reviewText:
I have been playing this game since 2 days ago on my PS4, and so far the story and gameplay is great. just finish downloading it on my PC and here is my 2 cent about this game.

Pro:
-Interesting story and character ( as expected from a Tales game )
-Simple but deep combat system. Suitable for all type of gamer
-Interesting game mechanic that improve the strategy element of the game (bonus skill, elemental skill, boons, etc)
-choices in game that may or may not change the story (still not that far in so can't confirm)
-Dragons!!!

Con:
-30 FPS (doesn't really impact the gameplay at all)
-no SLI support (but the game is very light so no problem there)
-Voice acting sometimes doesn't match character body language (to be expected since it's base on the Japanese VO)
-the walking animation is kinda funny (yeah I know I'm nit picking here)

I highly recommend you guys try this game out. If it's not for my real life (which i need to keep buying games), I would attach an IV into my wrist so I can keep playing this game none stop. So far it have been a blast for me.

P/S: For those who are wondering where is the DLC that is suppose to come with the Pre-Order, It is in the in-game menu. Go to Item, then in the top right u will see something like a horizontal wifi sign, that is the Downloadable content tab. Also if you go to Namco Bandai website you download another  DLC called Alisha's Story (Free until 19th November 2015). If you can't find where it is, just google Namco Bandai DLC.

Hope you guys find this useful. If not I apologize since this is my first review (unless i'm starting to get alzheimer)

reviewText:
I don' really know ever where to begin with this. I'm writting this review to serve as a warning, Zestiria is a masterpiec that has suffered a terrible accident, it recovered enough to limp back to life but is forever crippled for it. That's the best way to describe the travesty of this game.

*As a notice the following may contain spoilers*

Zestiria is a tales game, a member of one of the few JRPG linages to survive to the modern age. It was hyped as most of it's kind is of being the greatest new thing. Beautiful open and traversable areas, HD graphics [ though since I played it on a modest laptop most of that was turned down to avoid inducing a computer anyersum],  and flawless control - there were problems with the PS3 release, the system was just not powerful enough and the game was poorly optimized for it, but that's a a different can of worms. For the most part it delivers, accompanied by the as usual amazing Tales Soundtracks.

The Characters are a blast and have that classic interaction and quirky fun that one expects from Namco, and the expected interactions are all there.

BUT... that's pretty much all of the good parts.

While it is a vast, and beautifuly expansive world, it is rather empty. There are a grand total of 7 towns in the entire game   in addition to 4 destoryed villages (that are simply desolate areas related to simple side quests ) and the final dungeon which is a town in a similar state as the other four - destoryed houses little to explore and no soul living or dead inhabiting it.

Much of the game consists of vast open plains with few sights and the forest dungeons are all horrendously similar to the each other similar to repeats of the maze area before the bladlands in Xillia 1. The actual dungeons are even more depressing, save for the 4 shrines and the beginning and ending dungeons, each one is identical in features differing only in the color of the walls  - from blue, red, gray and purple metal/stone among other colors - and their basic layout. The remind me more of fallout out bunkers than any ancient ruin.

And here is where it gets frustrating, because Zestiria isn't just bad, it has a lot of good, which makes the bad worse. The first Dungeon, is an amazing stone ruin featuring a theme of South American temples and shrines, most closely resembling - at least in my view - Mayan, Incan and Aztec architecture. Since this was the first dungeon and I had seen nothing else, going off what I had heard of the game I had hoped the future areas of the game would continue this trend and take various styles of native ruins from around the world or perhaps just the Americas even. I was wrong, and it is quite possibly the best designed and most colorful of the dungeons.

Things unfortunately get worse from there. A JRPG has many unique elements but the essencial one is the story. And that's where Zestira drops the ball... HARD.

I'm not going into a ton of detail but basically the story is abysmal and barely makes sense. It's full of more plot holes that Swiss cheese. Further the story seems to just shift around a lot, I don't know how to describe it more than that, that it's unstable.

A big complaint is that the first Female MC gets replaced 1/3 or the way through the game by another girl who remains the Female MC for the rest of the came. It was poorly advertised and handled. It feels that either the second character was either shoehorned in or her role greatly expanded at the last hour without changing the story to compensate. Some have suggested that perhaps the game was meant to in the second half alternate back and forth between both female protagonists and their respective wind elemental partners, there do remain some parts of the story that might suggest that. The second female MC and her wind element partner are part of a group of assassins that feel like they were forced into the game. You could take at least the assassins if not her and the her partner out of the game and make a few small changes and nothing would be really different.

Further it's clear that the story was cut appart and put back togeather several times and at diffrent stages either to adapt for gameplay or differing ideas. It gives the feeling of several versions of a story from roughest draft to final copy un paper cliped and tossed around then reassembled without any regard that page 44 is from the final draft page 22 from the first and pagest 31-8 from various middle stages.

Because of all of this other segments of the story suffer. A history with most Tales villains is that they are well intentioned extreamists, they do what they do because they sincerely believe it is the key to utopia or a better life for all, even of many must be sacrificed along the way. This is charactistic of Mithos, Van, Ratatosk and Richter, Richard, Nachtigal and Gaius. The villain of Zestiria has none of that, he was basically cursed, by a corrupted god and an insane priest for being a pragmatic miliatary leader. Horrible things happened to him, so he turned evil or rather finally gave into evil and wants to destory the world as it is now his job to do so, if anyting the real villain of the whole story is never really given much back ground and it's just hand waved that he died after cursing the bad guy.

Further evidence of rushing with the game can be found in mentions of a third northern" region that pops up in conversations towards middle of the second half of the game. This region is never visited but had ample map room
date: further more in a desert area in the end of the game there is a giant castle like gate covered with markings similar to Egyptian hieroglyphics. It is never mentiond by the characters or the game and appears as but a piece of scenery. It's attention to detail howerver shows that it must have clearly served a purpose and it is in the perfect position to be a gate to these northern regions that form a large blank spot on the world map.\n\nFurther
recommended: there seems to be no Tales twist
hoursPlayed: the ubiquitous event near the middle of the game that turns the player's and often the character's notion of the world completely on it's head. For Symphonia it's the existence of Te'thala
voteText: Graces Fodra
helpfulPercent: Dawn of a New world Emil is Ratatosk
votesHelpful: Abyss the world is floating over an ocean of miasma and Luke is a clone. Xillia
votesTotal: the existance of Elympios. There is no such twist in Zestiria
votesFunny:
yes there is the idea that you come from the so called "doomed town" but that has no importantance on the story's plot and is found out at the end of the game.

Another thing is all the tales games seem to have some sort of "moral" or center to them. Abyss is "you define who you are" Symphonia is "what is best may not always be right" Dawn is "Walk a mile in another's shoes" Graces is "Friendship conquers all" Xillia "compassion and understanding can build a better world" (it also had an underlying enviromental message). Zestiria ... I don't know what I got out of it..."Killing is okay if the person is evil." And okay I somewhat jest but there's really not much there... maybe "self-sacrifice or don't carry burdens alone" if you squint a look at it at a 42 degree angle in the right light.

So
commentsCount: in the end from a play and visual standpoint Zestiria is a rather good game. But the lack of elaboration given the visual capabilities the game had at it's disposal
column16:
and the train wreck of it's story make it a disaster that at least at it's current price I cannot recommend in good conscience.

-JHEE

reviewText:
A disappointment in the Tales franchise.
This one fell short in several key instances that keep me from honestly recommending it.

I won't say the plot had holes, instead I'll say that the world is inconsistent with how it follows its own rules.
I can't say more without revealing spoilers but it's enough to say that if you start poking around, you'll find more than enough events that make no sense and feel like they were pulled out of nowhere just for dramatic tension.

The combat feels like it's on autoplay half the time, with several multi-hit attacks going off of single button presses.
May seem cool at first but it makes it near impossible to block or dodge when you want to without first coming to a complete stop. You'll be wanting to block but will be stuck in a several second long attack animation.

The dungeons are awful. Most of them have absolutely nothing interesting besides the combat. And that gets old fast, especially when the camera gets stuck looking into a wall when fighting in tight spaces.
There's almost nothing in the way of puzzle solving, something that was a staple of dungeons in previous 'Tales of' games.

When you use a Holy Bottle to avoid combat, and find yourself running through dungeons with absolutely noting to do in them besides run to the end, that's when you know the designers utterly failed.
Not just because there's nothing interesting besides combat but also because the Holy Bottle doesn't fade away until you rest at an inn. And since you aren't getting into combat, that could be for a long while.

This game has too many flaws for me to recommend it.
Go play Tales of Symphonia instead. Graphics may be older but it's so much better in every aspect.
Don't bother with Zestiria unless it's on a really good sale.

reviewText:
I've played almost every Tales game released in English and I have a pretty high tolerance for their typically awful stories and narrative so long as the fighting is good.

Despite that this is the second mainline game I haven't reached the end credits in, the first being Legendia. The combat, and especially the boss fights, are really poor and the story is possibly the worst I've seen; nothing interesting happens in the middle, maybe, thirty hours of the game. For context, this is a forty hour game. Usually these games have some sort of plot twist to keep things engaging, but nothing unexpected happens here. Plot progress is almost entirely relegated to your characters learning about things that have already happened. Despite war being a theme of the game, war doesn't actually happen outside of the designated Ravaged Battlefield area, and even then, only twice in the game.

The combat should have been the game's saving grace but they really trashed the combat from Graces F. Stamina (SC) replaces CC, and it acts similarly but as a gauge rather than a number. This gives more granularity to the system but I'm not sure that this is really necessary. It doesn't limit you as much as Graces F early on, but you're still limited by how long it takes to learn your basic artes. In the end I feel like the CC system gives you a much more concise indicator of what you can do, and was implimented in a way that made it more visible to the player.

Armitization allows you to merge with one of your party members to make a super form relating to one of the four elements. Armitized forms have only three moves per basic combo, rather than four, and are focused on elemental damage whereas normally your basic combo incorporates elements in different branches eg. second right is fire, second left is water etc. What this means is that you are going to be doing the same few attacks over and over, without regard or thought for which you're using, with fewer characters active and less potential for heavy comboing. You're encouraged to use this form a LOT in boss fights because they often are the best way to do damage. Incidentally, bosses have a lot of health so you'll be spending a lot of time doing this, probably thinking about other, better things you could be doing given the remarkable complexity of the human mind.

I'd like to clarify something before I finish. I've finished Phantasia, Destiny, Eternia, Symphonia, Abyss, Vesperia, Graces F, Xillia, Xillia 2, Hearts R. Yes, even Hearts. I didn't really enjoy Xillia that much but it at least got me to the end credits. Early in the game I expected Zesty to pull itself together, like Graces did, and get way better but that point didn't arrive. Nothing happened. If anything, it got worse.

Proper credit to Namco for the port though. Keep bringing games to PC!

reviewText: This game commits the greatest cardinal sin of any creation: Blandness. I can't even call it an abomination because it just doesn't have the depth of character to be one. Every character's lines have been entirely unnatural, forced, rehearsed and sound completely fake. The voice acting is entirely sub par even compared to older Tales of games like Symphonia and Vesparia. The story is a traditional terrible Japanese anime information dump of pointless names, senseless jargon and utterly meaningless connections that interrupt the flow of battle and story at irritating consistencies. The characters are completely one dimensional with no depth, no intrigue and no development. The character controls are abysmal, especially in battle and there is no hierarchical menu system, just disjointed screens tied to different buttons.\n\nNothing about this is good. I can't even say it's bad, because it's just bland with hints of being bad. I dub this game the rotting celery of video games.

reviewText:
It's a painfully average game where the cons outweigh the pros. It has great music and when the battle system is clicking it's a lot of fun.

Problems include:

-Awful camera
-Awkward plot even for a Tales game
-Cut characters
-Bland overworld that's a chore to traverse
-30 FPS
-The game's merge system removes any challenge and hampers combo creativity
-Is terrible to play with friends because of said merge system

I got hyped for a company to start making JRPGs on PC but this isn't a good one. If you can pick it up on sale go for it but at 50 bucks it's not worth it.

reviewText:
Finally, the Tales series is on STEAM!

The Tales series is a traditional style JRPG which has stayed true to it's JRPG roots since it's first release in 1995. And since then has only improved upon and critiqued it's unique style of gameplay over the years. It is hands down, without a doubt, one of my all time favorite game series of all time.  That's because with each installment in the series it delivers what I've come to love and expect from all the Tales games , with added improvements. So here are a few things you can expect when playing a Tales game.

What to expect -

*Free Motion Battle System- A combat system where you actively move around in the battle and can attack freely in real time, using lots of cool combos and skills. The technical name for the  battle system has changed with each improvement so I'll just call it the free motion battle system.

*Engaging character's - What really brings the Tales games to life is it's characters and their interactions together. Even the small chit-chats they have, or skits, make the characters feel alive and the conversations feel real.

*Story - A story driven game over several hours with lot's of side quests to do.

*The world - Exploring the vast world, the towns, the npcs and all the hidden things within that world.

*Longevity - The Tales games are long, great, games. Not  short games you can just blast through in one sitting. And if you plan to unlock everything then it's even longer. Yay!

*NG+ - A feature rarely seen anymore these days but Tales has kept it alive in every installment.

Now I know it's a bit early to post a review since the game just released, so I will edit this review as I play through the game. But in the mean time I just wanted to show some love <3

reviewText:
It's times like these I wish steam had a maybe option instead a binary yes or no recommendation but sadly since it doesn't I can not in good faith recommend this game at its current price.

Tales of Zestiria (ToZ) is the 15th mothership title in the long running Tales of franchise and was released in 2015. The best way to sum up this game is an ambitious game that didn't have enough time, money, or talent to fully realize what the developers were going for.

In the past, battles that the player encountered would take you away into an instanced battle map (think of the Final Fantasy series). ToZ decided to make the battles take place where you encounter them which in theory sounds great but design decisions behind this choice influenced the maps of the world so much so that the open fields became at times 10x bigger than past games with nothing interesting populating these desolate fields. This is not mentioning how the camera fights you in combat to the point where you are unable to fully survey the battle. The camera will get caught on just about everything making battles just the pits sometimes.

Grinding in ToZ isn't for exp but for gear. While you receive exp for killing monsters on the field the exp gains are designed to give the player very little exp but instead you need to kill monsters for the gear that they drop so you can fuse it into other similar gear to level them up to make your characters stronger. This wouldn't be so bad if the AI partners in the game weren't some of the worst programmed in the modern series.

AI partners are brain dead and at higher difficulty settings severely limit the player because of how awful they are. This is because the game is designed around the two human characters to fuse with the four elemental seraphs" and to balance this if you are not fused you have a smaller hp pool and your attacks don't do as much damage but you have 4 characters on the field as opposed to 2 in your fused forms. Because HP is so low and enemy boss encounters will always be about 15+ levels higher than you your AI partners will get beat down very fast because they lack the ability to defend themselves.

The story has many plot holes
date: plot lines that are picked up and dropped off whenever
recommended: and pacing that is downright bad. The game never ups the ante because of the initial premise of the story which makes it very hard for the tension to escalate which is your classic "demon lord going to destroy the world scenario". This wouldn't have been so bad if you cared anything for the characters but it is so hard to care for these characters when they offer very little.\n\nThe point in the story which I literally yelled at my screen because of how stupid it was is when a villain who is introduced very early in the game and then vanishes for 50% of the game only to reappear because the writers forgot about him and they needed someone to do something to make character development happen. Mind you
hoursPlayed: in the time of this villain's disappearance nobody has mentioned him even though the main character
voteText: Sorey
helpfulPercent: would have every reason to ask the other human partner because of the relationship between the villain and her. I can not reiterate it enough this character was completely dropped and picked up because a bad person needed to do a bad thing.\n\nCharacter development in ToZ is baffling there is no other way to put it. Instead of slowly building up characters they either give a huge character dump all at once
votesHelpful: let the character keep hitting the same one note
votesTotal: or very small character development which doesn't get furthered. I cared nothing for these characters save maybe 2
votesFunny:
3 if you really push it.

Dungeon designs save for the four elemental trials are very repetitive and force the player to fight in confined spaces because they are a dungeon. This means that the aforementioned bad camera does the player no favors.

The reasons why I can not recommend this game comes from both a long time fan of the series having played over 10+ of their titles and as a gamer. The fan in me says it a difficult sell to other fans of the series but to them I still wouldn’t recommend it. The gamer in me says that if you took away the “Tales of” and if this was just some random game I would honestly say that it is bad.

After playing the other games in the franchise I can say that this is the only game in which I put down my control got cheat engine and turned on super speed because the nonsensical story

reviewText:
The Problem with Tales of ZestiriaI've seen that the reviews for this game are very mixed, and I just want to really explain why people might and might not like Tales of Zestiria.

First thing, right off the bat, my view of this might be skewed a little bit because my computer is... less than top of the line. Forgive me if I miss something hugely different when playing on a decent system.

The Big Problem The major issue that I had with this game, and what I feel most people had problems with but were unable to articulate, was that it failed to be engaging. I would rather sit and watch all of the skits than actually play the game. The visuals are beautiful, the characters are charming, the story is interesting; however, Zestiria failed to engage me. To put it simply, I would rather watch someone play this game  than play it myself. And even then I would expect them to do a lot of skipping around to get to the important parts that people actually want to see.

Just comparing it to another JRPG I'm going to compare this to what I believe is one of the greatest JRPG's in recent years, Xenoblade Chronicles. Xenoblade is very similar to Zestiria is a lot of ways, but Xenoblade just does it better. The world is immersive and much more interesting than Zestiria, the visuals are fantastic for a game on the Wii and even better on the 3DS, and the characters are so fun that the people in your party are more often decided by how fun they are to have around than their combat potential. And Xenoblade engages the player, much better than Zestiria ever does.

In Zestiria, the combat felt really lackluster to me. Not to say that it wasn't flashy, but  I felt no need to spend my time caring about the combat.  If I felt particularly lazy, I could just set my characters to auto combat and let them take over. And even if I wasn't lazy I didn't have the ability to participate in the story. Sure, you play as Sorey learning about your Shepherd powers and fighting Malevolence but I felt more like an observer than a player.  It wasn't engaging.

Back to Xenoblade, the combat requires the players full attention. Rather than just spamming the attack button (which is an entirely viable strategy in Zestiria), one must pay close attention to which character has the enemy's aggro and what arts your partners are using and what status the enemy has. And the story requires more than just walking places and watching cutscenes. Plus,  Xenoblade has side quests, which Zestiria has none of.  When the story progresses no matter what decision you make, and there aren't any side missions to take your mind off of the endless cutscenes, the game just becomes a slog of walking to the next set of cutscenes and scripted battles.

Zestiria should be an anime Now, Zestiria is not a bad game. It's a good anime. Seriously, if Tales of Zestiria were an anime I would watch the entire thing like three times. But when the game says walk here, which takes twice as long as it should on my slow computer, just to watch another cutscene it really bothers a player who expected to do something during this game.

To conclude, Zestiria has a lot of potential as a game. It has wonderful characters, a really good looking world, and a story that I wish I had time to experience. But this game fails to recognize the players role in advancing the story, aside from walking to the next objective on the map. So I wouldn't recommend it to anybody who wants to play something. But if some studio decided to make Tales of Zestiria as an anime, I'm very interested.

reviewText:
This is a difficult game to like.

If you are into super cheesy Japanese RPGs, and are generally familiar with the Tales genre, it's worth picking up. But even as a fan of the series, it's been difficult for me to sit down and play the game for more than an hour.

Story-wise, the game is...ok.  Tales series are not necessarily known for their wonderous stories, but I've always found them a bit less stereotypical than most typical RPGs.  This title however just feels a bit more forced - you see the gears grinding too hard, and the games nearly 3-hour long tutorial doesn't help.  The plot is also confusing - some characters can't be seen" by most of the characters
